 KYRGYZ REPUBLIC HEALTH SECTOR REFORM STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT PART I. SECTOR BACKGROUND, ISSUES, AND STRATEGIES A. Economic and Sectoral Background 1.1 The Kyrgyz Republic is a small landlocked country in Central Asia with a population of 4.5 million people. It is located in a mountainous area and has common borders with Kazakstan, China, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan. The country became an independent state in 1991 as a result of the disintegration of the Soviet Union. Since then it has been developing as a secular state and attempting to implement market reforms. Price liberalization has, to a large extent, been completed and external trade has become almost free of major restrictions. Similarly, the foreign exchange regime and interest rates have been fully liberalized. Privatization and enterprise restructuring are underway, with the state reducing direct involvement in economic activity, domestic production and distribution. 1.2 The Kyrgyz Republic is among the countries most adversely affected by the transition, which has had a significant negative impact on the health status of the population. Poverty is a prevalent and persistent problem. Even before the disintegration of the Soviet Union in 1991, about one third of the population had a "socially unacceptable standard of living". Much of the existing poverty in the country is, therefore, inherited and structural. According to the 1993 Kyrgyz Living Standards Survey, 40 percent of households then lived in poverty with 25 percent classified as very poor. There were significant disparities in the extent of poverty among the populations of different regions; farnilies headed by people of different age groups; rural and urban populations; families of entrepreneurs and families of non- entrepreneurs; employed and unemployed; families with income generated by employment and families with income based on the provisions of social safety net; as well as among families with many children and families with only a few children in the rural areas. 1.3 The level of financing of broad social programs inherited from the Soviet system was at an unsustainable level. Following independence, in order to stabilize the economy the Kyrgyz Government allowed social expenditures to fall from nearly 17 percent of GDP in 1990 to 9 percent in 1993, although by 1994, the figure had increased to 14 percent. The health expenditures followed the same pattern, dropping from 3.7 percent of GDP to 2.4, and then increased again to 3.6. Social assistance expenditures were most affected, falling from 6.1 percent of GDP in 1991 to 3.4 percent in 1994. The enterprises, which used to be major providers of subsidized social services, have encountered severe financial difficulties and are now forced to divest their social assets. 1.4 World Bank studies show that while in 1994 local governments covered 84 percent of the health expenditures and 74 percent of the expenditures on education, the current intergovernmental system has several features that could jeopardize the social safety net including: (i) revenue sharing arrangements which give subnational governments limited incentive to increase their tax efforts; (ii) a transfer system which provides soft budget constraints for subnational governments and reduces incentives to cut expenditures and/or increase the revenue collection efforts; (iii) local tax administrations which might be more loyal to the local level with a potential non-compliance; (iv) limited correspondence of expenditures and revenues, which forces local governments to accumulate large payment arrears; and (v) full expenditure autonomy at the local level, which leads to ad hoc expenditure cuts or large arrears for social expenditures, especially in the poorer regions.
 2 1.5 Although redefining the role of the state has been successful in the Kyrgyz Republic with respect to its withdrawal from micro-management and liberalizing the economy, the Government now has an even greater challenge to create new institutions which will effectively provide for instances where market forces alone cannot cope. The social sectors, and the health system, in particular, require a careful institutional restructuring while the provision of services cannot be interrupted. The sensitivity and complexity of issues involved in health reform in the Kyrgyz Republic under conditions of severe economic crisis present a strong case for the Bank's participation. 1.6 The Kyrgyz health care financing and delivery system is a vestige of the centrally planned national health service system of the Former Soviet Union (FSU). Such systems performed well in termis of guaranteeing access to health care and promoting a relatively equitable distribution of health resources. These systems were successful in promoting certain types of preventive services such as immunizations and providing access to care in rural areas, and, until recently, resulted in relatively good health outcomes given the amounts of money spent. However, with the epidemiological transition and the resulting changing composition of illness from infectious diseases to chronic conditions, system performance has been disappointing and inefficiencies, both clinical and economic, along with the dismal economic situation in all FSU countries have resulted in very limited gains, and, indeed in some areas, in declines in the health status of the population when compared to either western or other middle income countries. 1.7 The proposed Health Sector Reform Project in the Kyrgyz Republic is designed to assist the Kyrgyz Government in the reform of its health care financing and delivery system. The Project takes as given the underlying economic situation of the country, the basic epidemiological status of the population, and the inherent strengths and weaknesses in the current health care financing and delivery system. A set of health reformn goals have been set forth in the Government's MANAS Health Care Reform Program', and this proposed IDA funded multi-component project targets the major causes of death and disability as well as the basic underlying economic and clinical inefficiencies in the current health care financing and delivery system. Explicit in the Project's design is the introduction of modem clinical practice methods and provider payment reforms separating purchase and payment of health services from delivery of care. These changes would improve clinical practice, target the country's major health problems, and result in a reconfiguration of the service delivery system which will promote efficient use of scarce health resources. Concomitantly, the Project is designed to preserve and strengthen the major positive features of the previous centrally planned system, in particular universal access to care and a relatively equitable distribution of health resources. 1.8 The components of the Health Sector Reform Project are developed on the basis of these reform goals, weaknesses in the current system, the underlying epidemiological patterns, the current configuration of the service delivery system, economic characteristics of the country, and the Government's health priorities. B. Epidemiological Trends 1.9 The Kyrgyz Republic's epidemiological profile and underlying health status compares quite favorably to many middle income countries. Much of this positive performance can be attributed to the strengths of the previous system in terms of widespread availability of basic services, such as children's vaccinations, and universal access to care. However, over the last several years deaths from infectious diseases tend to be higher, while several indicators of health status have been stagnant or declining. 1/ The MANAS Health Care Reform Program was a 1994/95 collaboration between the Government, WHO and other donors which examined the health status of the Kyrgyz Republic and recommended future reforms and priorities.
 3 Overall, cardiovascular diseases are the most common cause of death in both sexes. For males, accidents and intoxications, respiratory diseases, cancer, and infectious and parasitic diseases are the major causes of death. For females, after cardiovascular disease, the most common causes of death are respiratory diseases, cancer, accidents and intoxications, and infectious and parasitic diseases. The system has been particularly unsuccessful in dealing with chronic conditions and the underlying epidemiological factors affecting adults. Moreover, there are also major weaknesses in the women's reproductive (including the matemal) health system, and the system's outdated medical practice patterns are wasting resources and appear to be unable to cope with major increases in the incidence of highly infectious diseases such as tuberculosis (TB) and sexually transmitted diseases (STDs). Mortality 1.10 While the crude death rate dropped substantially over the past 15 years, it has increased since 1991 from 6.9 deaths per thousand population to 8.3 in 1994, comparable to the 9.4 rate in the westem industrialized Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries. The crude birth rate has declined over the past 15 years from 30 births per thousand population in 1978 to 24.3 in 1994, but is still almost double the industrialized country rate. The rapid drop in the birth rate between 1992 and 1994 (28.5 to 24.3) likely reflects the current socio-economic upheaval (Table 1.1). Almost half of all infant deaths are due to acute respiratory infections (ARI), 26 percent are due to perinatal causes, and another 10 percent are due to severe diarrhea. In all, 60 percent of infant deaths are preventable. Since the percentages of low birthweight and premature births are comparable to those found in industrialized countries, it is apparent that poor maternal care is a major causal factor for these high rates of preventable deaths. Over 60 percent of the deaths of children from 1 to 5 years are due to the same causes. Accidents are the major cause of death for children aged 5-14, although ARI still accounts for almost 15 percent of deaths in this age group. 1.12 Life expectancy at birth has been relatively stable over the last several reported years (e.g. 1990- 1992). Unfortunately, the last year with accurate data is 1992, since funds were not available to do the
 4 computations in 1993 (although computations will be done for 1994). In 1992 the Kyrgyz Republic's life expectancy at birth for males of 64 years was 9 years below the OECD average and the 72 year figure for women was 7 years below the OECD average (Table 1.1). The 1994 figures should provide some indication of whether the current economic crisis has significantly affected the longevity of the population as is the case in Russia. 1.13 The main causes of death of young adults 15-24 years of age are motor vehicle accidents, suicides, and homicides. However, chronic respiratory diseases are the leading cause of death for women 15-24, and ischemic heart disease is the second most important cause of death for women. Ischemic heart disease is the leading cause of death for both men and women at age 35 and above. Various cancers are the second leading cause of death in women 35-54, while accidents, homicides and alcohol intoxication are the other major causes of death. Chronic respiratory diseases are also an important cause of death for both men and women in the 35-54 age range. For both males and females age 55 and over, after ischemic heart disease, chronic respiratory infections and cerebrovascular diseases are the main causes of death. Morbidity 1.14 Specific diseases, many of which result in illness not death but nevertheless place significant burdens on the health system, cause significant losses of productivity, and result in major health risks being imposed on the rest of the population. Analyses of morbidity data are difficult due to the lack of comprehensive information and the questionable reliability of reported data. Available data indicate two areas which show large increases in incidence of morbidity and pose major health threats to the population at large: TB and STDs. 1.15 Sexually transmitted diseases not only pose major public health problems, but also have detrimental effects on women's reproductive health. Reported cases of syphilis were 22 per one hundred thousand population in 1994, reflecting a ten-fold increase over the 1992 rate of 2.3. While reported gonorrhea cases dropped from 44 per hundred thousand population in 1992 to 37.9 in 1993, there is strong evidence that detection rates are dropping as people have stopped coming to Government facilities for treatment. While there are no officially documented AIDS cases, the current socio-economic situation increases the risk of a significant spread of this disease in a health system that is ill prepared from a public health or financial perspective to deal with such an epidemic. 1.16 The tuberculosis situation in the Kyrgyz Republic is also grave. Even during the Soviet period tuberculosis case notification and death rates were among the highest of the entire Soviet Union. Since 1989, case rates have increased annually at an average rate of three percent, and mortality has increased annually by eight percent. Taking into account under-reporting, the estimated incidence could be as high as 70 cases per hundred thousand and that of sputum smear positive cases as high as 35 per one hundred thousand. The largest proportion of cases still occur in the young adult age groups: the most productive segment of the population. In 1994, over two-thirds of all cases occurred in persons under 45 years of age. The country's TB mortality rate has doubled from 6.7 deaths per hundred thousand population in 1989 to 13.6 in 1994. In addition to the serious epidemiological situation, drug resistance levels, particularly to the most important anti-tuberculosis drugs, are reported to be increasing from the already high levels recorded in the mid-1980s. Moreover, treatment patterns are out of date with a heavy reliance on inpatient treatment as opposed to newer outpatient approaches. 1.17 Utilizing available morbidity and mortality data, a burden of disease analysis was done for the Kyrgyz Republic using a variant of the DALY (Disability Adjusted Life Years) methodology developed for the 1993 World Development Report. The data on DALYs presented in Table 1.2 indicates the
 5 priority diseases accounting for the highest loss of DALYs. It is to be noted that the DALYs to be gained from reduction in some highly infectious conditions, such as TB (or STDs affecting women's reproductive health), can be as much as three or four times higher than levels indicated here because of dynamic transmission (i.e. the infection of additional persons by an infected person). C. Health Care Delivery System and Resource Utilization 1.19 The Kyrgyz health system is characterized by heavy reliance on inpatient and tertiary hospital- based care. The emphasis of the health system on costly inpatient care is evident in the large numbers of hospital beds and physicians, and high use rates, as compared to western industrialized countries (Table 1.3). Moreover, norms on facility structural standards, on medical practice, and on staffing and salaries perpetuate outmoded medical treatments and economic inefficiency. The number of beds per 1,000 population has declined from 12 in 1981 to 9.5 in 1994, but is still some 15 percent above the average for OECD countries. Similarly, while hospital admissions rates have declined from 25 percent of the population being admitted in 1987 to 18 percent in 1994, they are still 20 percent above the average in westem industrialized countries. While the average length of hospital stay has declined by about one day over the past 15 years to 15.6 days in 1994, slightly above the 14 day OECD average, it has increased from a low of 15 days in 1988. The average number of inpatient days of care per year per person has declined from 3.6 days in 1978 to 2.8 in 1994, but is still some 15 percent above the OECD average. The hospital occupancy has declined from 90 percent in 1978 to 81 percent in 1994, clearly indicating significant excess capacity. The Kyrgyz Republic has significantly more beds and far higher use rates than most western industrialized countries.

Instead of being able to treat patients at these less expensive levels, these lower levels have typically referred patients upwards for treatment at the tertiary level. The major reductions in health spending described below are exacerbating the problems of inappropriate referrals to higher levels of the system as the already under-resourced lower levels are reported to be suffering from particular shortages of consumables, especially pharmaceuticals. As a consequence, the lower facilities have greater incentive to refer patients up the chain to the relatively less under-resourced tertiary care levels. 1.22 The number of physicians per 1,000 population has increased by some 30 percent over the past 15 years to reach 3.1 in 1994 (of which 0.45 are dentists), somewhat above the OECD average of 2.2. More troublesome is the large number of specialists relative to generalists: some 35 percent are
 7 generalists (therapists and pediatricians), whereas the ratio in many OECD countries (excluding the U.S.) is closer to 50-50. The number of physician contacts per year is comparable to the high utilization rates in the OECD countries. As in the case of inpatient beds, the Kyrgyz Republic has large numbers of physicians and high utilization of physician services. 1.23 The current system of health service provision is highly specialized and fragmented. The population of just over 4.5 million people is serviced by specialized research institutes (Infectious Diseases, Cardiology, Oncology, Tuberculosis, Maternal and Child Health, etc.) at the tertiary level; specialized tuberculosis and dermatovenereal hospitals and AIDS clinics at the oblast level; and a tuberculosis dispensary at the raion level. For example, a woman is not able to go to just one primary health facility in order to receive health care for her children and for herself. For gynecological problems she must visit a women's consultation clinic; for contraception, a marriage and family clinic; for venereological problems, a dermatovenereal clinic; and for AIDS testing, an AIDS clinic. While the system is better integrated at the Feldsher/Accoucheur Posts (FAP) and ambulatory level in the rural areas, this generally fragmented system is expensive for the country to run and inconvenient to users. It wastes scarce resources which could be better channeled into fewer and more integrated programs. D. Financing Health Care Budgeting System 1.24 Health financing regulated by budgeting norms based on physical capacity (e.g. numbers of beds or numbers of doctors) perpetuates inefficient resource use in the health sector by encouraging overstaffing, overbedding, and increased utilization of inpatient services. Combined with the rigidly enforced Soviet 18-line budgeting system used to pay medical care providers (hospitals and polyclinics), there are no incentives for primary care providers to use cost-effective ambulatory treatment protocols or to perform a "gate-keeping" function of screening inappropriate referrals. The reliance on capacity- based budgeting and payment norms promotes inefficiency and waste. Although the recent financial crisis in the country has weakened the application of capacity norms as the basis of budgeting, a more rational system for reimbursing providers that encourages efficiency, as well as improved internal management, would need to be clearly defined and instituted. Need for National Health Accounts 1.25 Effective health policy can only be mnade on the basis of understanding the total amount of resources being devoted to the health sector: recurrent and capital spending, spending from all public sources including Ministries other than the Ministry of Health, enterprises, donors, and private spending both legal and informal. National Health Accounts (NHA) provide a frarnework for classifying all expenditures by source of funding (e.g. public and private) and by type of service. They provide the basis for analyzing changes over time of both the total and the individual components. Ideally spending at the oblast and local levels would be analyzed in the same manner. Such accounts are a necessary condition for effective policymaking and are an inherent feature of the health systems of all OECD countries. Unfortunately, the health accounting systems in FSU countries often do not lend themselves to functional classifications or analyses. Moreover, the increasing fragmentation of the financing systems in terms of health insurance-based models and private payments has added to the number of flows of funds and further obfuscated the spending picture. Levels of Public Funding 1.26 The health system in the Kyrgyz Republic, as elsewhere in the FSU, is predominantly publicly financed. Public funds from general revenues are allocated through a complex system of
 8 intergovermnental tax-sharing and transfers to finance facilities through federal (Republican) and local (oblast and raion) level health budgets. Additionally, public enterprises have financed some social services, including health facilities. 1.27 Irrespective of the measures employed, public health spending in the Kyrgyz Republic has fallen dramatically since 1990. As shown in Table 1.5, the decline was especially pronounced between 1990- 1993, with a slight improvement in 1994. Nevertheless, health spending in 1994 is still substantially below the 1990 level for all measures. The ratio of public health expenditures to GDP declined from 4.2 percent of GDP in 1990 to 2.6 percent in 1993 with an increase to 3.6 percent in 1994 (the 1994 public health number reflects only the consolidated budget, so if extra-budgetary funds and enterprise spending were included, the ratio would be higher). The health to GDP ratio in OECD countries exceeds 8 percent on average (Table 1.6). 1.28 Although health spending as a percentage of GDP is seen to have fallen moderately, the real decline in public health funding is far more severe than is indicated by these figures. In real inflation adjusted terms, GDP in 1994 was only 50 percent of the 1990 level. Similarly, 1994 real (GDP deflator adjusted) health expenditures were only 46 percent of the 1990 level, up from 40 percent of the 1990 level in 1993. In short, there has been a 50 percent reduction in real output in the Kyrgyz Republic since 1990, accompanied by a 54 percent reduction in real public health spending. Major reductions in real output and their associated tax revenues have caused equivalent reductions in real public health spending. 1.29 The picture is even more dismal when per person spending is converted into U.S. dollars using purchasing power parities (i.e. exchange rates which adjust for cost of living differences across countries). In 1990, per capita public health spending in the Kyrgyz Republic was US$156. Spending declined to US$133 in 1991, US$74 in 1992, and US$37 in 1993, only one-fourth the 1990 level compared to a 1992 OECD average of almost US$1,400 and spending in Turkey of US$156 (Table 1.6). Allocation of Financial Resources 1.30 The Kyrgyz Republic has not opted for generating earmarked revenues for health through mandated insurance, unlike some of the other FSU countries. An experiment in this regard is underway in one of the oblasts (Issyk-kul), the provider payment reform elements of which are being expanded under the proposed IDA Credit. Changes in medical care provider payments are needed to create financial incentives for all providers of health services to manage care given to patients more efficiently and cost-effectively while improving the quality of health services. Decision-making on the allocation of resources should be decentralized so that both providers of health services and the population have more responsibility and accountability for the efficient provision of high quality health services. 1.31 Further, the concepts of paying providers in accordance with the number of persons covered and the types of services rendered would establish a clear relationship between the quantity and quality of the services dispensed and the financial reimbursement received for those services, and would encourage outpatient treatments, and reductions in the length of hospital stays and unnecessary referrals to higher levels of care. 1.32 The advantages of applying this new method of paying health care providers include: (i) Ability to give more health services with current funding levels due to more efficient allocation of existing health sector resources;
 9 (ii) Increased confidence in the health sector by businesses and the population leading to greater willingness to invest in health; (iii) Increased responsibility and accountability of health providers for the outcome of health services; (iv) Increased consumer participation in decisions about their health care; (v) Improvements in the quality of health services; (vi) Increased access to health services for the population; and (vii) Greater satisfaction and prestige for medical professionals, including attracting and keeping quality professionals.  11 Impact of Funding Crisis 1.35 The current funding crisis has precipitated a series of changes that impact on all levels of the health system. A few of these changes have been beneficial in reforming a chronically overstaffed and overutilized health system. Others have actually reduced the quality of the service provided and seek to undermine both the health workers' and general public's confidence in the system. It has been noted that the population's health seeking behavior has changed in the last few years with people visiting health facilities less often, later in the illness, or not at all. The main reasons for this change in behavior have been the lack of drugs in the health facilities, transport problems, mass unemployment reducing demand for sick notes, and lack of money to pay the fees for service. 1.36 The health system is severely constrained by the reduced availability of drugs, equipment, spareparts and consumables in all health facilities, particularly at the primary health care level. Health facilities maintain a stock of drugs for emergencies and heavy reliance is being placed on humanitarian assistance to provide vaccinations and selective priority drugs. Such humanitarian assistance is sporadic, however, resulting in frequent acute shortages of vaccinations and priority drugs. There are many examples of the problems created by this drug shortage, and people are selling off assets (cows, horses) to buy drugs, or turning to faith healers and herbal remedies. The health system is collapsing due to lack of drugs and supplies, particularly at the primary health care level. In the current situation most patients must provide bedding, food, drugs and syringes for themselves and cover the costs of transport. This collapse is further exacerbated by the use of outmoded treatment regimes, which often include polypharmacy and long periods of unnecessary hospitalization. 1.37 Emergency services have been protected so far, although health officials voice doubts about how long this emergency cover can be maintained. Emergency surgery (i.e. cesarian sections and other emergency obstetric care, acute appendicitis, strangulated hernia repair, acute trauma, etc.) continues but patients must provide many items. Routine surgery (chronic hernia repair, gallbladder removal, gastric ulcer surgery, etc.) has virtually ceased. Many patients with chronic illnesses (chronic bronchitis, angina, diabetes, epilepsy, kidney disease, etc.) have stopped visiting health facilities because of the lack of drugs, and the introduction of a fee for some services. The lack of essential drugs for public health priority programns such as TB and STD control programs signal a breakdown in the basic health system. 1.38 Health worker salary levels are compressed and very low (chief doctor US$25/month, hospital doctors US$13/month, nurses US$11/month), and payment has sometimes been delayed by several months. Several non-cash payment systems have been introduced in different raions to compensate for the lack of revenue flow. Health workers receive part of their salaries in the form of produce from local enterprises (wheat, cloth etc.) or vouchers. Some health staff compensate for these low salaries by working an extra shift in their health facilities. Many compensate by cultivating their gardens to produce extra fruit and vegetables for home consumption or sale in the market. Some of the most talented doctors have left to work in other jobs (mainly business), or migrated to other countries. Mass unemployment has, however, prevented many health workers from seeking alternative employment. The health facilities appear to be adequately staffed, despite these low salaries and long delays in payment. Many health workers are motivated and committed to their health service system, but are finding it a challenge to continue working without drugs for their patients. 1.39 A shortage of gasoline and spareparts have contributed to a reduction in the number of ambulance teams, coinciding with a reduction in the public transport system. Pregnant women are now advised to keep a stock of gasoline in their homes for the ambulance or private vehicles. Disturbingly, some health workers report an increase in the number of home deliveries. Supervision of health staff by
 12 Ministry, oblast and raion health officials remains intact, although reductions in public transport and gasoline shortages have substantially reduced the frequency of visits. 1.40 A variety of cost-saving measures have been introduced by different health facilities to compensate the reduction in their budgets: beds and staff have been reduced; day patient services and fee for service have been introduced; some hospitals now grow wheat and make their own bread; hospital pharmacies have been set up to produce infusion solutions and herbal remedies; garbage is removed by hospital staff in preference to paying outside contractors; coal heaters have been replaced by electric heaters; and physical therapy has partially replaced drug therapy for some ailments. The chief doctors and their staff have shown great resourcefulness in their attempts to reduce costs, while trying to maintain the quality of patient care. E. The Current Status of Physical Facilities 1.41 A comprehensive review on the status of health facilities in the country, with a particular focus on those at the PHC level, revealed that adequate funds are no longer available to pay for running and maintaining buildings, plant and equipment making it increasingly difficult to maintain acceptable levels of efficiency and quality of the facilities. A large part of the equipment is not working due to shortages of spareparts and a widespread lack of maintenance. Furthermore, essential consumables needed to operate the equipment are not available or in short supply, seriously detracting from the quality and effectiveness of the medical services being provided. 1.42 Even though as a result of the mentioned shortages and inefficiencies buildings and equipment are not adequate to respond to medical needs, they also represent a fixed cost to the Government in terms of personnel and energy consumption. A reform program aimed at improving efficiency and decreasing waste will require the closing of some facilities and the adaptation, remodeling and re-equipping of other establishments. At present, there are very few norms and standards regarding physical infrastructure that could respond to current needs. With respect to the human resources that would be needed, while in the past there was apparently a well functioning hierarchy of technical and administrative expertise to support the Ministry of Health's investment activities, including engineers, architects and builders, this is no longer the case. The few remaining members in the Office of Capital Investments are not well trained to manage the technical changes that will be required to reform the network and to bring the facilities up to modern standards, while achieving savings. The Central Office for maintenance has been completely disbanded. 1.43 At present there is no overview of the status of buildings and equipment and it is not possible to make overall plans and establish priorities for reform and maintenance activities of the whole public health network. The scarce resources available should be used for rehabilitation and for organizing an updated system of maintenance, once decisions are taken on partial or total closing of some facilities and on remodeling work and installation of new equipment. For this change of focus, however, a significant reorganization is required including retraining of a small core of technical staff in planning and managing the reform and the improvement of the existing health physical infrastructure network. This may also require contracting of private sector expertise. F. The Current Status of Pharmaceuticals 1.44 Prior to independence, The Kyrgyz Republic received most of its pharmaceuticals from the FSU. With the breakup of the Soviet Union, pharmaceutical availability was severely disrupted. With the collapse of the economy, the country cannot afford to buy drugs at market prices. To compound these problems, state monopolies on procurement and distribution, outmoded storage facilities, and outmoded
 13 lists of clinically inappropriate drugs have all exacerbated the problems of pharmaceutical supply. The Kyrgyz Republic was also left without a quality control system for drugs because determination of safety and efficacy of drugs was done by the Ministry of Health of the USSR in Moscow. To make matters worse, the high costs of outpatient drugs result in individuals being inappropriately hospitalized in order to receive free pharmaceuticals. The situation is so severe that for most non-emergency cases, hospitals can no longer afford to provide drugs, and individuals frequently must provide their own drugs in order to receive appropriate inpatient treatment. An adequate supply of essential drugs is critical to the effectiveness of any health care system, but it is particularly important at a time when resources are being shifted from inpatient to outpatient facilities and from curative to preventive care. However, in order to assure an adequate supply of essential drugs, it is not enough simply to finance the purchase of additional medicines. Without fundamental improvements in pharmaceutical management, much of the potential benefit of increased physical supply is likely to be squandered, and none of the benefit is likely to be sustainable once the additional funds have been spent. Moreover, the danger of ineffective, or even unsafe, medicines being supplied may be rising, in light of the worsening economic conditions, the growing shortage of drugs, and the unscrupulousness of low-quality manufacturers. A more serious source of waste is undisciplined, cost-ineffective public spending. Despite cuts in Government funds for drugs, the funds that are available still are being used to buy an excessively large number of drugs, many of which have never been proven to be effective. Expensive branded drugs are sometimes purchased instead of less expensive, therapeutically equivalent generic products. And, because a large number of different drugs are purchased in relatively small quantities, the demand for many important, widely used medicines often is not met, while the price that must be paid to obtain these drugs is higher than would be the case if larger quantities of fewer drugs were purchased through competitive bidding. Reform of pharmaceutical procurement and management is critical. Lists of essential clinically effective drugs based on the recommendations of WHO must be established, and effective procurement and distribution networks must be put in place. The safety and efficacy of the country's pharmaceutical supply must be assured. G. Need for Long-Term Reform 1.45 Based on the preceding analysis, the following are identified as the main areas of the health system where problems exist: (a) overemphasis on inpatient and tertiary care, with poor diagnostic capacity, treatment protocols, pharmaceutical supplies and facilities at ambulatory levels; (b) federal norms promoting outdated clinical practices and inefficient facility configurations; (c) large numbers of low quality medical treatments, and an excess of hospital beds; (d) rigid 18-line budget procedures for paying polyclinics, hospitals and salaries for all medical care personnel, which provide no incentives for economic efficiency in resource use or referral patterns and perpetuate imbalances toward inpatient care; (e) outmoded health programs in a number of important areas such as maternal and child health (MCH), TB, STDs, and adult health; (f) lack of an up-to-date essential drug list, poorly structured monopolistic state procurement, storage, and distribution systems, and shortages of essential drugs; (g) limited technology and shortages of basic equipment and supplies; and
 14 (h) history of chronic underfunding exacerbated by the current economic situation. 1.46 As a consequence, the quality of health services and effective access to these services has declined in recent years (as evident in falling utilization rates). Total resource availability has declined considerably and the remaining resources are utilized in a highly inefficient way. The incentive structure underlying the resource allocation system in the sector contain limited incentives for inducing cost- effective behavior by medical care providers. 1.47 The issue in the Kyrgyz Republic's health system in the short-run, therefore, is to make the best possible use of the limited resources available, while laying the basis for future enhancements in areas such as quality assurance, accreditation of health facilities and new forms of financial resource mobilization. The major areas of reform in this first stage are identified as: (a) emphasizing cost-effectiveness criteria in public financing of health service delivery: this will require that resources are channeled to diseases which have a high burden and which can be treated through cost-effective ambulatory protocols; (b) re-orientation of resource use towards ambulatory primary care and away from inpatient and tertiary care: this will require strengthening of ambulatory care through investments in new ambulatory treatment protocols, diagnostic capacity, supply of essential drugs, and rehabilitation of facilities for expanded ambulatory care; (c) ensuring that the focus on cost-effective ambulatory care is sustainable through changes in the incentive structure facing medical care providers: this will require separation of purchasing and provision of services with the introduction of a new payment system for providers, such as a capitation-based payment system, which will place responsibility for cost containment on the providers and will encourage use of cost-effective ambulatory protocols and avoidance of inappropriate referrals, while maintaining pre-agreed, specified service quality levels; (d) introducing mechanisms for cost-effective procurement of major consumables, especially pharmaceuticals: this will require identification of clinically effective and cost-effective essential drugs and the strengthening of pharmaceuticals regulatory bodies; and (e) facility and staff rationalization for the health sector in order to realize savings from the shift in service provision from inpatient to ambulatory methods: this will require closure/consolidation of facilities and re-training/release of some staff, especially at the tertiary level and at inviable small inpatient facilities. 1.48 These reforms would be expected to generate structural efficiency (i.e. achievement of health gains with least cost), sustain these cost-savings over time, as well as achieving health gains, ceteris paribus, through improvements in the effectiveness and quality of services provided. H. Government's Goals and Policies for the Health Sector Goals 1.49 Like other member nations of the World Health Organization, the Kyrgyz Republic has developed health goals that it wants to achieve by the year 2000. The Kyrgyz Republic's State Program For A Healthy Nation Targets For the Year 2000 include: (a) reduction of Infant Mortality by 25 percent; (b) reduction of Child Mortality under five by one-third; (c) reduction of Maternal Mortality by 25 percent;
 15 (d) reduction of Cardiovascular Diseases and Cancer by 15 percent; (e) reduction of Mortality by Diabetes by 20 percent; (f) reduction of the Crude Mortality Rate by 15 percent; (g) reduction of the incidence of tuberculosis by 10 percent; and (h) reduction of the incidence of sexually transmitted diseases by 50 percent. Within the context of the MANAS Health Care Reform Program, the Government is attempting to develop a rationalistic framework for developing solutions to these serious health problems of the country, which have been exacerbated by the difficulties of the transition. By December 31, 1996 MOH would, as part of project implementation, present to the Association for review and comments, the MANAS Health Care Reform Program and a schedule of rationalization of health facilities and thereafter carry out the program in accordance with that schedule, taking into account the comments of the Association. Policy 1.50 Before negotiations the Government provided the International Development Association (IDA), hereafter referred to as the Association, with a draft policy statement outlining its health sector reform strategy. This policy statement was reviewed and discussed during negotiations. Signature of the policy statement in a form acceptable to the Association was a condition of Board Presentation. The Prime Minister transmitted the policy statement with a signed letter, dated April 5, 1996, which summarized the policy's main points. A copy of this letter is contained in Annex 1. The full policy statement and letter in both Russian and English are contained in Annex 15. The statement contains undertakings: (a) That during the execution of the Project the level of annual State budgetary expenditures for the health sector will remain executed at a level, not less in real, inflation-adjusted terms than such total executed expenditures in 1994. Savings resulting from carrying out the Project will be put back into the health sector. (b) That the health sector needs to be rationalized and modernized and a first step will be taken during the time the Project is implemented by merging specialty departments and health facilities; increase the emphasis on primary and outpatient care and reduction of health personnel, hospitals and hospital beds. As part of this restructuring, (i) The STD and AIDS programs will be integrated in other primary care programs and new treatment methods and protocols will be introduced to enhance ambulatory treatment of sexually transmitted diseases. (ii) If results of the pilot projects on ambulatory treatment of TB are satisfactory, introduce ambulatory treatment as standard treatment nationwide; reallocate current tuberculosis specialists from tuberculosis in-patient facilities to primary health care facilities; and phased closure of TB sanatoria in the country. (iii) Emphasis will shift from new construction to rehabilitation of health facilities and from specialty hospitals to integrated hospitals. (iv) Allocations in the local and national budgets for repair and maintenance of health facilities will be maintained at the same executed real level of the 1994 budgets and further that these allocations will be utilized only for the purposes intended. (c) That the population will have a free choice of health care provider/physician.

 17 PART II. LESSONS LEARNED FROM PREVIOUS BANK EXPERIENCE 2.1 A review of the analysis of medical systems performed in Russia and the other FSU countries reveals a pattern which is symptomatic of the legacy of Soviet medical practices. First, the lack of discipline inherent in any system where cost is not a factor produced a medical system highly skewed to tertiary level care and hospitalization in specialized and functionally independent facilities with staff and overhead costs out of proportion to patient load. Incentives were biased away from services towards facilities and hospital stays, and providers were paid on a fixed salary. This system has proved not only to be unaffordable under the present fiscal austerity, but unworkable in a market economy. The provider payments component of the Project proposes to deal directly with these issues. Second, lack of exposure to and incorporation of western medical practices has resulted in medical practices and protocols which are not in accord with modern developments. The current cadre of medical professionals need to have their training upgraded and expanded. A significant effort is undertaken in the Project to introduce modern methods, materials, publications, ambulatory techniques, and recent research findings to the primary health care sector. Third, the level and quality of physical construction in the sector has emphasized new construction almost to the virtual exclusion of maintenance and upgrading of present facilities. Community involvement has been generally absent. The facility rehabilitation component focuses on establishing methods and administrative steps to introduce the concept of estate management with community participation in primary health facilities. Fourth, throughout the FSU the actual level of financing directed to health has suffered as the federal level has divested responsibility and financial support to the oblast and raion authorities, and central financial authorities have been under pressure from the IMF with regard to fiscal deficits. There is strong pressure on medical authorities to rationalize expenditures within a shrinking annual allocation. The Project seeks to establish a "floor" for budgetary allocations to health, as well as encourage the hard task of reducing physical and staffing levels to fit current needs without reducing quality of services. The Kyrgyz Republic, in many respects of size, commitment to reform, and ability to make decisions offers an excellent opportunity to attack these issues and provide lessons for its larger neighbors who are all facing the same challenges. 2.2 With respect to implementation this is the first lending operation for the health sector in the Kyrgyz Republic. In general, the Kyrgyz Republic's health sector shares the same characteristics of other FSU countries, i.e. the dispersion of responsibilities among various levels of Government, lack of coordination among various entities involved in health care, inexperience with Bank procedures, weak implementation capacity, and a resistance to credit-funded external technical assistance. In the area of pharmaceuticals, a Rehabilitation Credit had an original allocation of US$1.5 million to finance imported drugs, but due to lengthy delays and changing priorities in Government the preparation and finalization of list of drugs to be purchased, combined with offers of donations from donors, resulted in only US$100,000 of the total amount allocated being used. For small-scale rehabilitation of facilities, the Social Safety Net Project has almost completed rehabilitation on 48 sites around the country. The lessons learned would be applied to the rehabilitation activities under the proposed Health Project, including the early refocusing of MOH on rehabilitation and supervision of works, together with outside engineers, and development of simplified bidding documents for rehabilitation works. Finally, the Project Coordination Unit of the Social Safety Net Project has gained valuable experience with Bank procedures, and the PCU would perform, on a contract basis, the procurement, disbursement and reporting functions for the MOH. 2.3 The use of the Disability Adjusted Life Years (DALY) methodology presented in the World Bank 1993 World Development Report provided an excellent tool of analysis to select those medical conditions which had the highest priority, and to choose only those interventions which are both cost-effective and can be provided in an outpatient care setting. Special efforts have been made to incorporate the lessons of other donors, and one component - provider payments - is a direct extension of the USAID-funded
 18 demonstration project in Issyk-kul, which is part of a larger effort involving several countries of the FSU. The lessons learned throughout the FSU will be incorporated as they emerge. The Bank's Poverty Assessment and Strategy for the Kyrgyz Republic calls for the major causes of death and disability to be targeted, and the basic underlying inefficiencies which remain in the health care system to be addressed. In particular, modern clinical practices will need to be introduced, along with new incentive-based payment mechanisms for medical service providers. The goals and strategy of the proposed Project are entirely congruent with that strategy, and with the Government's health priorities.
 19 PART III. THE PROJECT A. Project Objectives and Concept 3.1 The objectives of the Project are: the reform and improvement of the Borrower's health care system; improvement of the health status of the population; improvement of the clinical effectiveness of the service delivery system; improvement of the economic efficiency of the delivery system; and extension of access of appropriate care, enhancement of the quality of care, and assurance of the long-run financial viability of the system. 3.2 The Project's objectives are also goals which are fully consistent with those developed under the first phase of the MANAS Health Care Reform Program. Policies and programs developed to achieve these goals would be monitored throughout the Project to assure that they also deal with the underlying social and economic problems that undennine health status, as well as with the public goods aspects of certain health services where the benefits and/or costs to society far exceed those to the individual (e.g. immunizations, TB, and STDs), thereby necessitating state financing of goods and services provided in these policy areas. Effective policy development must also deal with the existing economic constraints, and base policies on cost-effectiveness criteria. Policies also deal with inefficiencies in the basic system, whether they relate to ineffective clinical practice or economic inefficiency. Long-run sustainability and maximum improvements (or reductions in the rate of decline) in health status must be achieved in the context of the economic realities facing the country as a whole, and the health sector in particular. 3.3 This proposed four and a half year Project will focus on: primary health care, limited facilities rehabilitation, a medical care provider payment system, and pharmaceutical management. The primary health care focus of the proposed Project corresponds with these priorities. The interventions envisaged under the Project are both clinically and cost-effective. Moreover, focusing on primary care, rationalizing drug procurement and ensuring the availability of essential drugs, and providing financial incentives for system restructuring through a medical care provider payment component will result in cost-effective improvements in the country's health status and improvements in the clinical effectiveness and economic efficiency of the health system, all within the context of the current economic constraints. 3.4 Increasing the effective utilization of the primary health care system will have the effect of decreasing demand at the hospital level. In conjunction with this decreased demand, provider paymnent schemes as proposed in the Project will accelerate the closure of inefficient hospitals. Increasing utilization of the primary health care system will not occur solely by training providers. A reliable drug system operating within the Government sphere is imperative if demand for and utilization of primary health care services is to be sufficient enough to decrease hospital utilization. Another activity encourages more effective and efficient utilization of the primary health care system through the repair, refurbishment and minor alteration of select ambulatory facilities. 3.5 The medical care provider payment component will furnish the financial incentives needed to support the changes in clinical practice and the restructuring of the delivery system inherent in the other components. It will consist of a new system under which the oblasts, acting as purchasing agents, will make payments to providers on the basis of pre-agreed performance indicators. During the phase-in period, payments would be made on a capitation basis. This approach will promote the long-run financial sustainability of the system and rationalize the current base by promoting primary and outpatient care, while providing strong incentives to eliminate unnecessary inpatient bed capacity. It reinforces the other components which also promote and improve the quality of outpatient care through the availability of essential drugs and redesigned outpatient practice protocols. Physicians will assume responsibility for
 20 managing the care of their patients and eliminating unnecessary referrals to other specialists, for diagnostic tests, and to hospitals, and in tum, will be rewarded with increased remuneration. 3.6 The pharmaceutical management component of the Project will finance the purchase and distribution of a large quantity of essential drugs, in an effort to improve fundamentally the availability of needed medicines. The procurement of drugs, however, will be done only in the context of far- reaching reforms in pharmaceutical management aimed at guaranteeing "sustainability" so that improvements in the supply of drugs -- or the increment of "health" produced by a given amount of resources -- will last long after the Project has ended. B. Project Desciiption 3.7 Through working with officials of the Kyrgyz Government, the MANAS team, and other donors active in the sector, a four component Project has been developed as follows: (a) primary health care; (b) facilities rehabilitation; (c) medical care provider payment system; and (d) pharmaceutical management. This Project is designed to achieve the basic goals of health care reform within the current economic and institutional constraints of the Republic. It focuses on the major burdens of disease in the country and is designed to deal with the most egregious inefficiencies in the service delivery system. By emphasizing cost-effective interventions, modern clinical practices, and major structural reform, the design recognizes the current economic realities facing the system and provides the basis for long-run financial sustainability. The Government has provided the Association with a policy statement, acceptable to the Association, outlining its health sector reform strategy, reaffirming its commitment to health reforns expressed in its "Master Plan for Future Developments of the Republic's Health Care System," einphasizing reform in primary health care, pharmnaceuticals and testing of different modalities of provider payments as a way of seeking efficient solutions for resource allocation. During negotiations, assurances were obtained that the Borrower would carry out an action plan agreed with the Association and in a manner satisfactory to the Association, as part of project execution. 3.8 An important activity of the PHC component in support of all the subcomponents is the production of mass media materials for the general public, aimed at promoting healthy lifestyles in the family and the rational utilization of health facilities. Booklets will be widely distributed to the general public from primary health care facilities. This will complement an extensive countrywide program supported by the German Development Agency (GTZ) covering, among other things, adult lifestyle issues. Under the Project local technical assistance will be provided for computer software training and the production of mass media materials. GTZ will provide technical assistance for the production of booklets, TV and radio programs for the general public. Component A: Primary Health Care (US$4.0 million total project cost) 3.9 The objective of the Primary Health Care component is to reorient health services away from hospitals and towards upgraded primary health care centers. To facilitate this process, interventions in this component will provide training to upgrade the skills of primary health care workers, provide them with basic clinical equipment and ensure them an adequate supply of drugs. The longer term objective of the Primary Health Care Component is to develop a more cost-effective health care program through the reduction of hospitals, beds and staff from the merging of specialty hospitals (tuberculosis, dernatovenereal, children's, matemity, infectious diseases, etc.) into the general hospital system at the tertiary, secondary and primary health care levels. Before negotiatons the Government has concluded that no legislation restricts different hospital functions to separate facilities nor forbids the expansion of the range of health services provided at the primary health care level, including ambulatory treatment of
 21 STDs and TB. Not later than December 31, 1996 MOH will establish new case management guidelines for ambulatory treatment of STDs and TB, as part of project implementation. 3.10 The PHC Component would offer nationwide coverage and would be focused on the primary health care facilities which provide health care to the country's 43 raions outside of Bishkek, through three main interventions: (a) redefinition of medical treatment protocols; (b) training of health care workers in priority health interventions; and (c) development of a mass media campaign for the general public to support the health reform activities. The MOH would have overall responsibility for the PHC component in close coordination with oblast and raion health authorities. The Technical Coordination Committee (TCC), organized to support the technical implementation of the Project, has one full-time advisor to coordinate all PHC activities (Annex 6 describes implementation arrangements.) 3.11 There are three subcomponents under the PHC component: (a) strengthening women's reproductive health; (b) acute respiratory infections and control of diarrheal diseases (ARI/CDD); and, (c) tuberculosis control. These programs cover the major health problems faced by the Kyrgyz Republic, namely high maternal, perinatal and infant mortality rates, and rising levels of syphilis and tuberculosis. Reductions in maternal mortality will be achieved by upgrading prenatal, delivery and postnatal care, both in hospital and at the primary health care level; and to prevent deaths from eclampsia, hemorrhage and sepsis. Perinatal mortality will be reduced by upgrading the monitoring of pregnancy and labor, and improving neonatal resuscitation practices to prevent deaths and disability from newborn hypoxia and brain trauma. The component also focuses on reducing the spread of tuberculosis and syphilis, two of the most serious infectious diseases, through the introduction of ambulatory care for treating these conditions, and a public health media campaign on adult health lifestyle issues. Component C: Medical Care Provider Payment (US$4.4 million total project cost) 3.38 The health care system in the Kyrgyz Republic is dominated by the hospital sector, which consumes more than 75 percent of resources. One reason for this inefficient allocation of resources is the financial incentives for facilities contained in the current line item budgeting system. The budgeting system is based on input measures such as number of beds and staff, and rewards increases in capacity rather than the efficient provision of high quality health services. 3.39 Under the Project the methods to be used by the Ministry of Health through the oblasts to pay hospitals, polyclinics, and physicians would be changed to foster efficiency in the health care delivery system and promote the use of primary care. Payment for care would no longer be made on the basis of production input measures but rather on the basis of performance as measured by coverage of the services provided (capitation). The new provider payment methods would strengthen the connection between the quantity and quality of services rendered, and the financial reimbursement received for those services. Incentives would encourage treatment of patients on an outpatient as opposed to inpatient basis, reduce length-of-stay for those patients who do require hospitalization, and reduce unnecessary referrals to specialists and for diagnostic tests. 3.40 Provider payment reforms would change the financing and the organization of care in two important ways. Payment for care would be separated from delivery of care. The payer would focus on paying for the best care at the lowest cost -- purchasing care rather than manage and maintain facilities. The provider would be made responsible for managing the services and would have more flexibility to focus on delivering the most optimal mix of services with the best outcome. Secondly, providers would be "at risk" in that they would now be responsible for any deficits between payments received and costs incurred. Providers would be accountable for more efficient and higher quality of care.
 27 3.41 The Project would extend to two other jurisdictions the provider payment aspect of a USAID- funded pilot program, which is now in the early stages of implementation in Issyk-kul Oblast. The Technical Coordinating Committee (TCC) would monitor the progress of Issyk-kul and the extended pilot, and keep Government officials and providers informed about the design, implementation and results of the pilot. 3.42 Site Selection: The geographic areas selected as most favorable for extending the demonstration are Bishkek City and Chui Oblast. These sites are preferable for several reasons: (i) relatively dense, urban population; (ii) most affluent geo-political units (in terms of per capita income and tax revenues paid); (iii) relative sophistication of medical institutions and trained personnel; (iv) relative excess of medical providers, especially physicians per capita in Bishkek; (v) contiguous geographically, effectively sharing market areas for medical services; (vi) proximity to health sector leadership for observation and evaluation; and, (vii) proximity to technical coordinating staff for implementation purposes under the Credit. Selected data comparing features of these two geographic units and Issyk-kul to national averages are provided in Annex 4, Table 2. 3.43 Pilot Design. Implementation of this component requires structural change in the health services delivery system as well as development of new provider payment systems and the corresponding financial infrastructure to support them. Four major progranmmatic elements or modules of the medical care provider payments component are described below: 3.44 (i) The first element is comprehensive restructuring of the primary care sector through the establishment of new primary care group practices--Family Group Practices. In order to reimburse providers a capitated rate for the provision of all primary health services to an individual, an entity capable of providing the entire range of primary health services must exist and consist of a therapist (internist), pediatrician, and obstetrician/gynecologist. Currently there are very few general practitioners. 3.45 The primary care groups would be the focal point of the new provider payment methods: they would enroll people and receive a capitated rate for providing a specified set of health services. The financial incentive for the groups is to provide services rather than referring patients to other parts of the health delivery system. Different models of primary care should be encouraged, and over time clinical retraining and new medical institute curriculum will lead to the development of general and family practitioners. The primary care groups should be independent, form voluntarily, and be organized as a business. They can initiate the development of non-profit entities within the health sector and also become private practitioners. 3.46 Approximately 300 primary care group practices would be formed to serve the population of Bishkek City and Chui Oblast, estimated at 1.6 million people. Each group would be capable of enrolling and serving approximately 5,300 people. About 150 groups would come on line in the first year of the Project, 100 in the second year and 50 in the third year. A significant portion of the provider payment component budget will be directed at developing the capacity of these entities to respond to the financial incentives of the new payment methods. The Project will fund minor renovations of new practice locations, allowing them to establish a separate identity and be dispersed throughout the community; equipment to enable the groups to treat patients rather than refer them; clinical training to increase clinical capability and begin development of a cadre of general practitioners; and, establishment of financial systems, including development of practice managers providing business skills for the groups. 3.47 (ii) The second element is free choice of primary care provider by the population and enrollment of the entire population into primary care groups. Participation by the population in decisions about their health care gives providers an incentive to provide high quality services. If patients are not satisfied, they
 28 can change providers. Information would be furnished to the population to help them make informed choices about their medical provider. The Project would fund a public awareness and marketing campaign, an enrollment process, and the distribution of comparative information so the population may judge provider performance. 3.48 (iii) The third element is new incentive-based provider payment systems for primary care services, outpatient specialty and ancillary services, and hospital services. These payment systems replace line- item budgets for facilities with payment for health services at the patient level. Although the experience of the Issyk-kul pilot will determine the exact form of these systems, the main concepts are a capitated rate and a case-based hospital payment. A capitated rate is the payment of a set fee to a provider for the provision of certain health services to an individual. A case-base hospital payment system reimburses hospitals a prospectively set fee depending on the type and severity of the treated case. 3.49 Currently, national, oblast, municipal, and raion governments finance and control their own facilities using a budgetary system which allocates funds through predetermined functional categories such as salaries and medical supplies. The health reforms envision the population choosing providers and providers receiving payment for specific services rendered to patients. The focus of payment for health services changes from the facility level to the patient level. A fiscal intermediary is needed to pool the funds from the national, oblast, municipal, and raion sources and reimburse providers for health services they provide to the population. Funds would no longer be delineated by government level and separately allocated to facilities; services would be purchased by the fiscal intermediary from one pool of funds. 3.50 The fiscal intermediary requires institutional capacity to pool the funds and manage the new provider payment systems. The development and installation of new computer systems is especially important. Provider payment on a treated case basis increases the base unit for reimbursement many times. For example, in Issyk-kul the base unit for hospital payment will increase from budgets for about 50 facilities to payment for about 50,000 treated hospital cases. This very large increase in the number of transactions requires the development of automated systems to manage the payment process. 3.51 Computer systems would handle enrollment of the population, construction of rates for the payment systems, recording of clinical information from facility bills, payment of providers for services, operation of a quality assurance system, and analysis of health statistics. An accounting system would record all financial transactions from defined source payment documents, interact with the banking system and provide financial reports for the fiscal intermediary. Current accounting systems provide a good starting point; however, they could benefit from the introduction of accrual accounting and more sophisticated financial reporting to present available information in a more useful form. Internal auditing and control procedures are necessary. Relationships between the fiscal intermediary and the treasury and banking system need to be clearly defined. The transition to a stable market economy may require the banking system to gradually shift its focus toward handling financial transactions efficiently, away from serving as a control mechanism. 3.52 The Issyk-kul pilot is developing and implementing these new systems. This allows for efficient refinement and extension of the products under the proposed project's provider payment component. The Project will fund adaptation of the new provider payment systems to Bishkek and Chui Oblast, procurement of computer hardware, refinement and installation of computer and accounting systems for the fiscal intermediary to track data of enrolled patients, and training of local experts and facility managers to implement the new provider payment systems. 3.53 (iv) The fourth element is development of health sector infrastructure to support the implementation of new provider payment systens. This infrastructure consists of three areas: (a)
 29 integrated management information systems (MIS), such as cost accounting and clinical information systems, to track data on the country's health care delivery, resource use and utilization patterns and provide managers tools to improve their decision-making ability; (b) increased management autonomy, flexibility, and accountability for health care providers; and, (c) quality assurance systems to monitor care and prevent "gaming" or abuse under different financial incentives of new provider payment systems. 3.54 As with the Project's provider payment systems, these infrastructure products are being developed in Issyk-kul. The provider payment component will fund adaptation of the systems, procurement of computer hardware and software to establish the capacity necessary at the facility level, and training of local experts and facility managers. 3.55 Finance and Training Plan: The medical care provider payment component requires US$4.4 million in IDA and counterpart funds to implement over a four and a half year period.
