Component D: Pharmaceutical Management (US$8.3 million total project cost) 3.65 The pharmaceutical management component is aimed at improving the availability of essential drugs both (a) directly, by financing the procurement and distribution of a large quantity of essential drugs, and (b) indirectly, by supporting the implementation of far-reaching reforms designed to strengthen the Government's drug regulatory capabilities and to increase the discipline and cost-effectiveness of public spending. Financial support for the procurement and distribution of essential drugs is contingent on the Government's continued determination to implement these reforms. 3.66 The pharmaceutical management component will support the following activities: (a) renovation of the premises of the national drug regulatory organization and acquisition of office equipment and furniture, laboratory testing equipment and furniture, reagents and chemical glassware, scientific literature, and other goods needed in order for the organization to function effectively; (b) technical assistance and training for the staff of the drug regulatory organization, as well as broad dissemination to other health care officials of information on drug regulatory affairs;
 32 (c) development, production, printing, and widespread distribution of the Kyrgyz Republic's Essential Drugs List, as well as training health care officials and managers concerning the goals and rationale of an Essential Drugs Program; (d) development of new standard medical treatment guidelines, based on and consistent with the Essential Drugs List; and, (e) procurement and distribution of a significant quantity of essential drugs. National Drug Regulatory Organization 3.67 The national drug regulatory authority will be responsible for: (a) the registration of all drugs and vaccines manufactured and/or marketed in the Kyrgyz Republic, including pre-registration review of all technical information on safety and effectiveness, the organization of clinical trials if necessary, and post- registration monitoring of drug utilization and possible adverse drug reactions; and, (b) quality testing and quality assurance of all drugs and vaccines manufactures, imported, marketed, and/or otherwise distributed in the Kyrgyz Republic. 3.68 A national drug regulatory organization was established in 1993 by decree of the Prime Minister. Located within the MOH, the organization is known officially as the Administration for Standardization and Oversight of the Quality of Medicines and Medical Technology. The authority and responsibilities of this organization are reaffirmed in a proposed "Law on Medicines" that has been drafted and its adoption by the Borrower is a condition of effectiveness. The Administration for Standardization includes, among its subordinate departments, a national drug testing laboratory which is responsible for (a) providing technical support of the Administration's registration decisions, and (b) ascertaining the quality of drugs manufactures, imported, and/or otherwise distributed in the Kyrgyz Republic. 3.69 The Drug Regulatory Organization and its subordinate testing laboratory, which are co-located, have rented 340 meters of space at the Institute of Cardiology and are negotiating with the Institute to rent an additional 160 meters of adjoining space. With a total of approximately 500 square meters of space, the organization will have sufficient room to perform its functions. Renovation of the premises has begun, and a small amount of testing equipment has been procured; it will be installed when additional renovation is completed and the necessary laboratory furniture has been acquired. Current staff of the organization numbers 15 of a planned 35. The Project will provide extensive support to enable the organization and laboratory to become fully operational as quickly as possible. The Project will provide US$97,000 for renovation of the premises and US$357,000 for the purchase of: office furniture and equipment; laboratory testing equipment and furniture; reagents and chemical glassware; scientific literature, computer software, and databases; and other necessary supplies. 3.70 The Project will finance a substantial amount of training for the staff of the organization and laboratory, including activities designed to foster close professional relations between officials of the organization and counterparts in drug regulatory agencies of other countries. The Project will finance in-country training in the use of computers and databases, the use of new laboratory equipment, and cost- effectiveness analysis for approximately 75 people during the first two years of the Project. The Project also will finance approximately 50 person-weeks of training and study tours abroad, spread over four years. In order to facilitate widespread dissemination of this information within the Kyrgyz Republic and to support a limited amount of training for persons outside the organization and laboratory, e.g. local health care officials, the Project will also finance an annual two-day national conference on drug regulatory affairs, including participation of foreign experts.
 33 3.71 The Drug Regulatory Organization presently operates as a self-financing body, relying on income from registration and testing fees. As a result, drug regulatory officials may have a direct economic interest in their regulatory decisions, and this may increase the risk that ineffective, or even unsafe, drugs will be made available to patients. In order to avoid potential conflicts of interest, the compensation of senior drug officials and other staff with a direct voice in regulatory decisions should be financed directly from the state budget. Before negotiations the Government did adopt revised procedures for financing the Administration for Standardization, providing that the salaries of senior officials and regulatory decision-makers are financed by the Government and not from fees. 3.72 The TCC Component Coordinator for pharmaceutical management will supervise the implementation of the various activities. In cooperation with the Chief of the Drug Regulatory Organization, other MOH officials, and the Project Coordination Unit, the TCC component coordinator will prepare terms-of-reference for all procurement contracts, including adequately specified lists of equipment, furniture, supplies, and other goods to be purchased with project funds. The TCC component coordinator will prepare, in concert with the Chief of the Drug Regulatory Organization, an annual training plan, including the dates, location, purpose, and names of participants for all in-country training courses and foreign study tours; the TCC component coordinator will exercise personal responsibility for assuring that all technical and logistical requirements of the training are met. The TCC component coordinator will maintain continual communications with other donors, in particular WHO, in order to minimize duplication and to maximize coordination in all drug regulatory technical assistance and training activities. Finally, the Coordinator will, each year, convene and chair a temporary organizing committee to prepare for and to implement the annual national conference on drug regulatory affairs. Essential Drugs Program 3.73 An Essential Drugs List (EDL), numbering 300 different products, has been adopted as a first step toward the creation of an Essential Drugs Program (EDP). Part 1 of this list consists of the 195 "most widely distributed basic medicines" that are expected to be consistently available at, or by prescription from, all primary and secondary health care facilities. Part 2 consists of 105 "basic medicines used in specialized institutions." The EDL has been endorsed by both WHO and the Association. Before negotiations, the Government did adopt and publish the EDL, agreed upon by the Association and WHO. 3.74 The EDL was compiled by a large ad hoc committee in the MOH and is the product of a lengthy dialogue between the MOH and experts from the WHO and the Association. The process for establishing and maintaining the EDL must now be institutionalized. The latest draft of the "Law on Medicines" delegates to the MOH formal authority to compile the EDL. Final passage of this law, with this authority included, and the adoption of formal rules and procedures for compiling and maintaining the EDL, including provisions for its periodic review and, if necessary, revision in the future in a form acceptable to the Association, is a condition of effectiveness. 3.75 In order to become an effective means of influence over the procurement and utilization of drugs, the EDL must be made widely available, and the rationale for an EDL must be understood clearly and supported by physicians, pharmacists, other health care professionals, and health care financing decision- makers. The Project will support development and publication of a brochure, containing the EDL and a lengthy commentary explaining how the EDL was compiled and its purpose. The Project will finance the printing and distribution of several thousand copies of the brochure, which will be made available to all pharmacists and health facilities prior to the start of the sizable procurement of essential drugs under the Project. The Project will help to finance a workshop in each oblast prior to effectiveness, in order to introduce the EDL to local health leaders and to build professional support for an Essential Drugs
 34 Program. In the second and fourth years of the Project, revised editions of the EDL will be published and distributed. 3.76 Equally necessary for effective implementation of the EDL is the development and dissemination of new, standard medical treatment guidelines that are compatible and consistent with the limited range of drugs included on the List. The MOH already has begun to draft new treatment guidelines, and the Project will support a study tour prior to effectiveness, designed to further this effort. 3.77 Maximum benefit of the EDL will be achieved when the List becomes a principal mechanism for regulating public spending on drugs. However, a requirement that public spending for drugs be limited to the EDL is, for the time being, impracticable. Two years will be needed in order to train health care professionals and to win their support and cooperation, but also in order to gain experience with the List and to revise the List in light of this experience, as will inevitably be required. From the start of the third year of the Project, public spending on drugs will be limited to the EDL: from that date, state- owned health facilities will be permitted to buy, and specially "entitled" ambulatory patients will be permitted to receive free of charge or at subsidized prices, only drugs included on its EDL. As part of project implementation, the Government would from January 31, 1998 onwards allocate budget resources for procurement and reimbursement of pharmaceuticals solely to pharmaceuticals listed on its EDL and registered in the country. At the same time, no restrictions will be placed on the privately-financed purchase, distribution, and sale of medicines which are not included on the EDL. 3.78 The establishment and operations of the Kyrgyz Republic's Essential Drugs Program will be undertaken and supervised by a standing commission or committee appointed by the Minister of Health, consistent with authority provided by the proposed "Law on Medicines" and as provided by the rules to be adopted on compiling and maintaining its EDL. As part of project implementation, the Government would establish this standing committee by December 31, 1996. The TCC Component Coordinator for pharmaceutical management will be a member of this body and will coordinate the various project activities intended to support implementation of the EDP. In particular, the TCC component coordinator will: (a) convene and chair a small, informal working group to oversee production and distribution of the EDL; (b) maintain close communications with WHO, UNICEF, and other donors in order to ensure that foreign assistance in the development of new standard treatment guidelines is used with minimum duplication and maximum effectiveness; and (c) convene and chair an informal working group to design and implement a monitoring program which will include regular surveys of pharmacies and physicians in order to measure the availability and utilization of essential drugs.
 35 Procurement of Essential Drugs 3.79 In order (a) to improve significantly the supply of the most important and commonly used essential drugs, and thereby to facilitate introduction of the Essential Drugs Program, and (b) to strengthen financially key elements of the Kyrgyz Republic's drug distribution system now undergoing privatization, funds amounting to US$6.0 million (without contingencies) over the life of the project would finance the purchase and distribution of drugs included on the EDL. All drugs purchased with project funds will be selected from Part 1 of the EDL and procured by the Project Coordinating Unit (PCU). In principle, registration of drugs must be completed or in progress prior to award of contracts, although the Borrower and the Association may agree on certain exceptions to this requirement. They must be labeled in Russian; and all bulk packages and individual vials and containers must be identified as containing an "Essential Drug of the Kyrgyz Republic." In order to give potential vendors sufficient time to register their drugs, a list of drugs to be procured was published in the March 31, 1996 Development Business; final procurement will be limited to drugs included on the initial list. A similar procedure will be observed in the case of subsequent tranches, although the minimum period between publication of the initial procurement list and bidding will be four months. 3.80 In order to minimize supply shocks, funds will be disbursed in four annual tranches of approximately US$2.0 million in each of the first two years and approximately US$1.0 million each in Project Years Three and Four. Initially, onward distribution of the drugs procured with these funds will be organized as follows. Procurements will be divided into six lots, according to a formula approved by the Association prior to effectiveness; winning vendors will deliver shipments, in accordance with this formula, to Naryn Oblast Pharmacia, Issyk-kul Oblast Pharmacia, Osh Oblast Pharmacia, Talas Oblast Pharmacia, Dzhalal-Abad Oblast Pharmacia, and Kyrgyz Pharmacia (for onward distribution in Chui Oblast and Bishkek city)--hereafter, these recipients are called the "Distributors"; bidders' prices will include the cost of transportation and delivery to these destinations. Drugs will be sold to the Distributors on credit, based on an arrangement to be described in distribution agreements. Preparation of bidding documents for the first annual tranche of drug procurement, and distribution agreements for these drugs in six oblasts, in a form acceptable to the Association is a condition of effectiveness. The Distributors will be permitted to sell drugs procured with project funds at prices no higher than the nominal cost of procurement and delivery plus a five percent markup (equal approximately to the cost of handling and distribution). The requirement that the drugs be sold at controlled prices will limit the risk of diversion, while maximizing availability. All prospective buyers, regardless of their form of organization or ownership, will be guaranteed equal opportunities to purchase the drugs. Revenues received by the Distributors, generated by the sale of drugs procured with project funds, will be accounted separately and used (a) to cancel the distributors' substantial debt and (b) to rebuild the distributors' working capital. The Government will present to the Association as part of the bidding documents to be submitted prior to effectiveness, the contract for drug distribution, and a list with the percentages of revenue allocated to these purposes, along with remaining revenue allocated to tax payments. In turn, the hospitals, pharmacies, and distributors that buy Project-financed drugs from the oblast Pharmacias and Kyrgyz Pharmacia will be permitted to sell the drugs to patients at unrestricted prices, except in the case of legally exempted patients, and the revenues resulting from such sales will be taxed according to existing legislation of the Kyrgyz Republic. As part of project implementation, drug procurement and distribution will be reviewed by the Government by June 30, 1997 and thereafter at the end of each procurement cycle so as to assure that privately owned drug wholesalers and retailers are not disadvantaged, compared to remaining state-owned companies. 3.81 In addition to the US$6.0 million to be used to finance the procurement and distribution of drugs from Part 1 of the Essential Drugs Lists, US$2.0 million will be made available to purchase necessary drugs in support of the activities in the Primary Health Care component of the Project. In order to ensure
 36 maximum efficiency and cost effectiveness, these PHC drugs will be procured by the PCU at the samne time as, and in accordance with the same procedures used for, the procurement of essential drugs. However, the PHC drugs will be onward distributed as specified previously in the description of the PHC component of the Project. National Drug Policy 3.82 The Kyrgyz Republic has not yet published a document, or set of documents, sufficiently broad and encompassing as to constitute a national drug policy. Nevertheless, considerable progress has been made in developing the individual components required of such a policy, notably the Law on Medicines. A national Drug Regulatory Authority and associated testing laboratory have been established and are being put into operation. Initial steps to establish an Essential Drugs Program have been taken. The former vertically-integrated and highly centralized state monopoly in charge of drug procurement and distribution is being thoroughly restructured and privatized. In addition, in collaboration with the MANAS project, the MOH has drafted a lengthy, comprehensive "Master Plan" for future development of the Republic's health care system, which includes a detailed discussion of national policy and development priorities in the pharmaceutical sector. Taken together, these individual activities constitute the core elements of a comprehensive national drug policy which, if articulated publicly, would raise the effectiveness of the pharmaceutical management component of the Project and contribute positively to the overall development of the Republic's pharmaceutical sector. The Government's policy statement as described in para. 1.50 reaffirms its commitment.

The Medical Care Provider Payment component methodology is intended to encourage providers to treat patients on an out-patient basis, discourage unnecessary referrals and reduce hospital days. This, along with changes in protocols formed under the other components, is expected to result in savings and efficiencies in the system.
 53 PART VI. ECONOMIC ANALYSIS OF THE PROJECT A. Framework and Justification Integration in Country Assistance Strategy 6.1 The Bank Group's Country Assistance Strategy for FY96-98 for the Kyrgyz Republic is designed to support the transition to a more market-oriented and macroeconomically stable economy by (i) facilitating growth; (ii) supporting structural reform; (iii) assisting the Government to protect vulnerable groups; and, (iv) strengthening institutional capacity. The proposed project is an integral part of this strategy. Health service delivery, predominantly financed and provided by the public sector, is a key area for structural reform. The proposed project aims to assist the Government to rationalize expenditures in the health sector and place it on a more cost-effective and sustainable financial basis through extensive structural reform of the health service delivery system. This is also consistent with the recommendations of the recent Poverty Assessment which emphasized, inter alia, the importance of using public social expenditure funds as effectively as possible in order that quality of, and access to, basic social services can be improved. Choice of Project Interventions 6.2 The Project aims to assist the Government to (a) reorient public resource flows to more cost- effective interventions; (b) sustain cost-effective choices by medical providers through changes in the incentive structure; and, (c) achieve health gains through strengthening the quality of care at primary levels (ambulatory polyclinics and FAPs). 6.3 Although the current financial crisis has placed great strain on the quality and availability of health services, the emphasis of the proposed project is not on short-term financing but on structural reform. The analysis of the health system presented in Part I emphasized the structural inefficiencies which characterize the sector. Additional financial resources for the sector without reforms to encourage cost-effective resource use would result in scarce public funds achieving less health effects than they potentially could. Furthermnore, the pervasive biases in resource allocation patterns indicate that there is considerable scope for savings to be gained through rationalization of resource use in more cost- effective directions. Realization of these potential gains and re-investment into the health sector would enable the Government to improve the quality and availability of services, even in the current fiscal crisis. In other words, application of cost-effectiveness criteria to project design narrows the apparent policy gap between short-term resource needs and longer-term reform needs. 6.4 Cost-effectiveness in the context of the health sector is defined as the achievement of the highest health gains (measured by DALYs) at the lowest cost. Although cost-effectiveness was most explicitly applied in the selection of interventions to be financed within the Primary Health Care component, its broader application resulted in other Project components focusing on the strengthening of ambulatory care more generally, given the current overemphasis on tertiary and inpatient care and given that there are relatively few cost-effective inpatient interventions. 6.5 Successful implementation of a program to upgrade ambulatory care will reduce the demand for hospital based care at the tertiary and secondary levels. The redirection of this demand towards a strengthened integrated PHC level will imply that inpatient resources previously utilized to treat some health conditions will become redundant. Project interventions are likely to demonstrate the potential for savings which would be released if the excess inpatient capacity was reduced. Actual realization of these
 54 savings would require the Government to close redundant facilities and to reassign or release staff from inpatient facilities. 6.6 The Project itself does not design a program of facility or staff rationalization, although it recognizes that these measures would be necessary in order to guarantee potential savings which could be reinvested into primary health care. By strengthening the ability of the primary level to deliver outpatient care, however, the project design will raise the visibility of excess inpatient capacity, demonstrate that this excess capacity could be reduced without adverse health impacts, provide incentives through changes in both provider payment systems and medical practice, and thereby strengthen the ability of the Government to begin the difficult process of closures and staff rationalization. Additionally, even if facility rationalization is undertaken slowly, and potential savings are slow to be realized, health gains can still be expected as a result of improved diagnostic and treatment capacity in the primary care levels. These issues are elaborated in the section on Risks and Limitations. Systemic Approach 6.7 The approach of the proposed project is a systemic one aiming to change clinical protocols and the regulatory, payment and management structures underlying inefficient resource use, rather than a vertical approach targeting specific clinical programs alone (e.g. TB). Although the systemic approach leads to a more complex project than would be expected from a vertical approach, it was the preferred design. This is in view of international experience which suggests poor sustainability of improvements to specific programs without accompanying changes in the system-wide incentives which resulted in inefficient resource allocation and use in the first place. In order to monitor impact of the proposed changes and in view of limited implementation capacity, however, the Project does not attempt to intervene in all areas where structural reforms are deemed necessary. Some of the more significant limitations of the project design are elaborated in section C below on Risks and Limitations. B. Benefits 6.8 An effort is made to identify benefits expected from each component. It is necessary to bear in mind, however, that the proposed interventions are integrally linked to each other and will jointly affect outcomes in many cases. Cost benefit analysis is not attempted because both costs and benefits are shared across components which have different coverage levels, and because it is very difficult to establish direct causal links between project interventions and health benefits, let alone to measure these benefits. The emphasis of the current analysis is on establishing the cost-effectiveness of project interventions. Component A: Primary Health Care Application of Cost-effectiveness Criteria 6.9 In identifying priority interventions within PHC areas, it was necessary to consider the incidence or prevalence of the disease, the likely gains in potential years of life and/or disability adjusted life years (DALY) resulting from the burden of disease, the effectiveness of the intervention, and the cost of the intervention. A variant of the DALY methodology presented in the World Bank's 1993 World Development Report was applied to the Kyrgyz situation (see note to Table 6.1 below).

 56 Potential for Fiscal Benefits 6.11 The introduction of new treatment protocols emphasizing ambulatory care will not directly lead to fiscal savings but will demonstrate the lower cost of provision of a service as compared to the inpatient alternative. The source of these potential savings are from reductions in the hospital length of stay and number of hospitalizations (admissions), which in turn would imply lower inpatient staff and facility needs. To realize these savings, inpatient facilities and staff would have to be reduced. This would lead to realized savings in the form of saved salaries (plus payroll contributions) and utilities costs which together, in 1994, on average accounted for 66% of the operating costs of health facilities. 6.12 An exercise was undertaken to estimate the magnitude of savings expected from changes in the TB treatment protocols. A costing exercise was done for 1996 using 1994 prices to estimate the cost of treatment of all TB cases if current protocols were not changed (the without project scenario) and if 50% of TB cases were treated according to specified combinations of the proposed protocols (three categories) while 50% continued to be treated according to current practice (the expected scenario in the first year of the Project). 3 6.13 The analysis suggests that the cost of treating all TB patients for 1996 could be reduced by about 28% if only 50% of cases are treated using the new protocols. For subsequent years, as adoption of the new protocol expands, the magnitude of potential savings can be expected to increase. Overall, it is estimated that successful adoption of the TB protocols could reduce the cost of TB treatment by 25-50%, relative to costs under current protocols, for each year of the Project and beyond. The main source of these savings is from a reduction in the use of costly inpatient-days and a greater use of outpatient visits in the treatment of TB cases. As mentioned, realization of these savings will depend on closure of excess inpatient capacity. 6.14 The TB exercise provides an order of magnitude of potential savings. The methodology could be applied to the other PHC interventions (ARI/CDD, WRH), data availability permitting. Coverage and Access 6.15 The coverage of the new protocols is intended to be nationwide across all six oblasts, with a population and potential beneficiary pool of 4.5 million. The different subcomponents aim to complete training on different schedules and full coverage of the population will be achieved only by the end of the Project's completion. The PHC component is likely to increase access to services in at least four ways: (i) introduction of ambulatory alternatives to inpatient care will enable the poor, who may not have been able to afford costs associated with inpatient care (e.g. lost wages, food, bed-linen, etc.) to access treatment which they may otherwise have foregone; 3/ It must be noted that the comparison is between the scenarios where the full recommended treatment, including drugs, under the respective protocol is implemented. In reality, many patients under the current protocol are not supplied with the necessary drugs. In actual terms, therefore, actual operating expenses (relative to the current situation) may increase if necessary drugs are supplied as recommended under the new protocols. Comparisons of cost-effectiveness are meaningless, however, if they are not done across comparable outcomes (i.e. equivalent numbers of cases treated and cured). The methodology used here is justified in that the different methods lead to the same number of cases cured and the estimate is of potential costs and savings expected in achieving this equivalent outcome.
 57 (ii) improved quality of services in the network of primary care facilities will also reduce the transportation costs (time and material) which patients would have bome to access inpatient care at the more centralized tertiary care facilities; (iii) provision of basic supplies to all FAPs will especially enable the rural population to access basic services without having to incur transportation costs or delays; and (iv) the integration of services in some model sites will enable catchment area populations (and also those who travel to these facilities) to obtain services with lower transaction costs. Health Impact 6.16 The provision of basic supplies and equipment in support of the new protocols under the PHC component is expected to lead to improvements in the quality of services provided. This will lead to gains in healthy years of life which would not have been achieved in the absence of the Project. It is difficult to quantify expected health impact of the component, however, since exogenous factors (e.g. a decline in nutritional status, changes in pollution levels, etc.) may obscure the causal links between project interventions and health outcome. As demonstrated, however, the interventions target diseases which had a high burden of disease. Moreover, monitorable targets in terms of changes in health outcomes will be tracked as part of project performance monitoring. Demonstration Effect 6.17 The PHC component will also finance integration of basic primary health care provision (Tuberculosis, AIDS control, Dermatology, Venerology and Family Planning) on unified Model sites situated in each oblast at selected oblast and raion facilities. This will demonstrate the feasibility of providing primary care in a unified setting and offer a model to be replicated throughout the country. As stated above, the component can further demonstrate the potential savings to be gained from provision of services on an ambulatory rather than inpatient basis for the selected interventions. These lessons could be replicated for other types of interventions on a nationwide scale. Component B: Facilities Rehabilitation 6.18 The enormous emphasis placed on inpatient care has resulted in the systematic underfunding of primary care facilities such as ambulatories and FAPs. As a consequence of successful implementation of ambulatory protocols under the PHC component and more cost-effective use of inpatient facilities by medical providers under the Medical Care Provider Payment component, greater utilization of outpatient facilities and reduced utilization of inpatient facilities is expected. In support of this anticipated change in the pattern of utilization, the Facilities Rehabilitation component attempts to expand the physical capacity for outpatient care provision. The Project will finance rehabilitation and conversion of existing capacity rather than the creation of new facilities. 6.19 Since the target facilities will be distributed throughout the oblast, the whole population of Chui, of 774,000, may be regarded as beneficiaries. This is also likely to result in higher effective gains to the poor relative to the non-poor within Chui Oblast, since transportation costs to better resourced city facilities are likely to have been more of a constraint to proper medical care for poorer households than for others.
 58 6.20 It is not possible to separately identify the gains from investments under the facilities component alone, since it complements changes under the PHC and Provider Payments components in the strategy to improve ambulatory care provision. For example, services not targeted under the Project, but which can be performed in an outpatient setting (e.g. cataract operations), will also benefit from improved outpatient facilities. Expansion in effective physical capacity for ambulatory care is essentially an enabling factor for implementation of changes under the other project components. In addition, there may be significant demonstration effects of this component for further facility rationalization within Chui Oblast and for replication of criteria, process, organizational forms, etc. in all the other oblasts. 6.21 The sustainability of rehabilitation efforts under the component is addressed through the reformulation and empowerment of a Buildings and Equipment Committee which will be responsible for future maintenance of facilities. Component C: Medical Care Provider Payment 6.22 The Medical Care Provider Payment Component proposes to change the methods used to pay physicians, polyclinics and hospitals in order to introduce incentives for these providers to manage resources and deliver care more efficiently through greater use of primary care. Payment to medical care providers from public funds would no longer be made on the basis of production inputs but on the basis of a combination of expected volume of cases, performance and outcome. The payer (in this case, the proposed Health Fund) would focus on paying for appropriate care at the lowest cost, while the provider (family practitioners and hospitals) would have greater flexibility to manage costs and select protocols in delivering care. Under the reforms, the provider would be 'at risk' in that they would be responsible for payments received and costs of care. 6.23 These features should encourage providers to treat patients on an outpatient rather than an inpatient basis, discourage unnecessary referrals for specialist or diagnostic services, reduce the rate of hospital admissions as well as the length of stay in hospital (LOS). The component will also develop a quality assurance system to ensure that quality of services is not compromised. This component attempts to reinforce the primary care focus of the other components discussed above. 6.24 During a phase in period, capitation based payments (i.e. payments per enrolled person to finance the costs of a set of services) will be introduced for Family Practice Groups and global budgets for hospitals. Over the course of the Project, case-based payment systems will also be introduced in the hospital sector. Fee for service (using a fixed schedule) would be introduced for some priority diseases.  61 Rationali2ing the Composition of Public Spending on Medicines 6.30 Since drugs procured under the Project will be essential drugs, a significant percentage is likely to be dispensed to exempted patients and, hence, to be financed out of local health budgets. If public spending levels remain constant, therefore, a greater proportion of public spending on medicines will be used to buy cost-effective essential drugs. This change in composition of public drug expenditures is expected even prior to the third year of the Project when the Government is required to limit public spending exclusively to the drugs on the Essential Drugs List. Net Consumption of Medicines 6.31 Since the drugs are to be sold, either for cash or for reimbursement from Article 10 funds, the net increase in total consumption of medicines will depend, on the-one-hand, on the budgetary resources available to purchase medicines, and, on the-other-hand, on the financial ability of consumers to incur out-of-pocket expenses. The increase in supply of cheaply procured drugs at the distributor levels may, however, lead to a decline in scarcity premia inflating drug retail prices. Net consumption is likely to increase by a modest amount. As the Project will institute mechanisms to ensure that drugs procured under the Project are distributed to all oblast Pharmacias, the increase in net consumption is expected to be spread across the country. Distribuion System 6.32 The component will assist in the re-capitalization of the weakest link in the pharmaceuticals distribution system in the Republic: the oblast Pharmacias. These Pharmacias, nominally independent, are deeply in debt, have no access to short-term credit, and have meager inventories. By providing these regional distributors with a substantial supply of low-cost drugs, and if the Pharmacias are permitted to retain a significant portion of their earnings from onward sale of the medicines, it is possible that one or more of the distributors will be able to emerge as financially viable. Financially sound distributors which may be able to compete with each other in the future, will help sustain improved availability of medicines well beyond the duration of the Project. Effective Regulation of Medicines 6.33 The component will provide financing critical to strengthen institutional capacity to assure the safety and efficacy of medicines produced and/or distributed locally. Empowered regulatory bodies will be better placed to enforce procurement guidelines and contribute to educating practitioners and users in the use of essential drugs. Successful implementation of regulatory capacity building under the Project is likely to be an effective means of sustaining the benefits from cost-effective procurement, distribution and use of medicines in the country during and beyond the Project. C. Risks and Limitations 6.34 The reforms proposed under the Project target some of the structures in the health sector which are most difficult to change in an orderly manner. The aim is to restructure resource flows in the sector and this necessarily implies that there are winners and losers. Closure and Retrenchment 6.35 The potential efficiency gains identified from reforms cannot be achieved without rationalization of inpatient facilities and staff. The issue of closure of facilities and staff retrenchment is an enormously
 62 difficult one which many countries are grappling with in health and other sectors. Resistance to rationalization efforts can be expected not only from medical professionals and auxiliary staff fearing job losses, but users in catchment areas of facilities which are likely to be closed. Uncertainty and anxiety in this regard may lead to resistance to the adoption of new ambulatory protocols and payment methods even if closure is not an explicit program in the short-term. The Government would need assistance to undertake a process of consultation with different constituencies such as doctors, other medical staff, users in urban and rural areas, MOH staff, the Parliament, etc. to develop a program, design a compensation package, identify re-training opportunities, disseminate information on the need, purpose and measures necessary and generally build a core consensus on the issues. 6.36 The strengthening of primary and ambulatory service delivery is a precursor to inpatient capacity reduction. The Project has focussed on this first process through the already complex set of proposed reforms. While recognizing the necessity of assisting the Government with a capacity rationalization strategy, the project preparation team did not think it feasible to include a facility and staff rationalization program within the Project itself, especially given limited implementation capacity and reduced central staffing levels in the MOH. Efforts have been made to coordinate project planning with relevant efforts being undertaken through other programs. A facility restructuring program currently being developed by the ODA will identify a detailed facility rationalization plan for Bishkek City, including the financing needs. The MANAS group is also developing a master plan for facility rationalization. It is not clear whether these efforts, combined with the urgency created by the continuing fiscal crisis, will be enough to build the political will in Government necessary to undertake physical and human resource rationalization. As results unfold, it will become clearer whether the issue will remain a priority for support under the next Sector Adjustment Loan (SECAL). Potential for Private Sector Displacement 6.37 In a real sense, there is little displacement likely from the large majority of interventions proposed under the Project since the private sector is very small at the moment. Moreover, the primary health interventions to be financed under the Project are mostly of a public goods type, with significant gains to society (e.g. TB, STDs, CDD, ARI, adult/family health education). These are appropriate areas for public financing since a potentially active private financing sector may not find these areas attractive and may finance these services at levels below those which would benefit society at large. 6.38 An area where there is an unknown net impact on the private sector, is that of current pharmaceuticals procurement under the Pharmaceutical Management component. Since the oblast Pharmacias will be receiving drugs at a low cost, it may become more difficult for other distributors to sell the same drugs profitably, i.e. at a price high enough to cover their acquisition costs. It is possible that alternative sourcing of the drugs procured under the Project could decline, especially if quantities procured under the Project represent a substantial portion of annual demand for the medicine. The magnitude of this effect is impossible to predict at the moment because of the lack of information on the composition of current drug consumption, the recent nature of private distributor activity in the country, etc. In order to minimize any displacement effect, it will be necessary to carefully choose the list of drugs to be procured under the Project and to spread out disbursement in simple tranches. 6.39 On the other hand, the Project may facilitate the growth of the private sector. The Project finances a large amount of training in modern clinical and management techniques which can be used by private providers of health care. Changes in provider payment systems promoted by the Project can be utilized to compensate private providers as well as public sector providers. Under the pharmaceuticals management component, the structure of on-lending is designed to re-capitalize distributors who may be able to compete on a financially viable basis in future procurement and distribution activities.
 63 Fiscal Sustainability 6.40 No significant new incremental costs are expected under the Project and the counterpart financing required from the Government over the course of the Project is estimated as averaging annually at I % of the 1994 budgetary expenditures on health. Of greater concern for the overall feasibility of the Project, however, is the level of budgetary commitment expected for the health sector for the duration of the Project. 6.41 Several aspects of the Project require that health sector budgetary expenditures be maintained at the real levels of health budget execution of 1994. (i) As an example, in order to compensate providers under the new payment methods, adequate public resources will be necessary in the Health Fund such that realistic capitation compensation rates and hospital global budgets can be set. If public financing declines beyond current levels, the financial viability and credibility of the new payment system will be severely undernined. (ii) Further, the above analysis demonstrates that the increased volume of utilization of outpatient facilities expected from the reforms will imply capital needs to finance conversion to and rehabilitation of outpatient facilities. This provides one of the arguments for the proposed Covenant requiring Government to maintain public health budgets at a reasonable level: even if savings are expected and realized through closure of inpatient facilities, there would be considerable need to re-invest savings in upgrading and expanding outpatient capacity in order to accommodate the desired changes in utilization patterns. (iii) The public health system's access to the drugs procured under the pharmaceuticals management component (but not the PHC component) is circumscribed by the total public funds available in central and oblast budgets to purchase these drugs directly or through reimbursement of exempted consumption. 6.42 As documented in Part 1, real expenditure levels in the Kyrgyz health sector have already declined significantly during the course of transition, jeopardizing both effective coverage and quality of services provided. In view of these earlier declines, and of the need to re-invest any savings generated by the Project towards sustaining the reform process, it was the judgement of the project appraisal team that further declines in health spending could delay, or effectively negate, the improvements in utilization and health status expected from the reforms. These concerns have been discussed with the Government and a covenant will be included to require that the level of total executed budgetary financing of the health sector is not less than the 1994 executed level in real inflation adjusted terms (using IMF estimates of GDP deflators) for the project implementation period. 6.43 Additional sources of financing of health services are also being explored. The USAID is exploring the feasibility of a payroll tax based mandatory health insurance system through its existing technical assistance program in Issyk-kul Oblast. Given the ongoing revenue shortfalls faced by the Government, the likelihood of any additional financing being raised through payroll taxes seems unlikely in the short-term. User fees for services, while already in operation for some types of services is not extensive. The MANAS Group is discussing the introduction of a minimum package of cost-effective services which would be provided free of charge and beyond which user fees could be introduced for the non-poor. Given the extensive prevalence of poverty in the country and the likely administrative costs of administering a fee system, net revenue expected if fees are introduced are likely to be modest at best.
 64 It was also judged that revision of the exemptions policy for consumption of medicines is neither politically nor administratively feasible in the short term, and again, may not generate significant savings if implemented. Adherence to the covenant will thus require clear Government commnitment and inter- sectoral adjustments within total public sector spending. 6.44 As has been demonstrated, if real budgetary levels are maintained, potential savings are realized through facility rationalization, and realized savings are re-invested in primary care, the delivery of health care in the Republic will be on a far more financially sustainable and cost-effective basis than it is at present.

The MANAS program, as you know, is the result of more than two years' intense, collaborative work between the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic, the World Health Organization, and other donors, and it commands the full support of the Ministry of Health. I relate these details in order to emphasize that the attached Policy Statement is indeed a very carefully considered and true expression of our plans and intentions. During preparation of the project to be financed under the proposed Credit from the Association, a number of questions were raised in connection with the Government's policy. In this context, I wish to take this opportunity to address these questions and to assure you that my Government is fully committed to taking the following steps which, I believe, you will find reflected in the attached Policy Statement: (1) during execution of the Project, the level of annual, consolidated state budgetary expenditures implemented in the health sector will not be less than the level of such expenditures implemented in 1994, taking into account adjustments for inflation, and savings resulting from implementation of the Project will be re-invested in the health sector; (2) during execution of the Project, activities aimed at rationalizing and modernizing the health sector will be continued, including gradual merging of specialized departments and health facilities, an increase in the amount of resources allocated to primary and ambulatory care, and a reduction in numbers of beds, staff, and other resources consumed in hospitals; (3) as part of this restructuring, the following specific actions will be taken: a) programs for the treatment of AIDS and other STDs will be combined with other primary care treatment programs, and new methods and protocols of treatrnent will be introduced in order to permit expanded ambulatory treatment of STDs; b) results of pilot projects demonstrating the effectiveness of ambulatory treatment of tuberculosis will be fully taken into account and reflected in the development of national standards for treatment of TB and specialists and other staff will be re-allocated from in-patient TB facilities to primary health care centers and specialized TB sanatoria will be gradually closed; c) capital expenditures will be
 70 ANNEX 1 concentrated, to the maximum extent possible, on the rehabilitation of existing health care facilities, and capital expenditures will be made available for new construction of only general hospitals and other health facilities that provide a broad range of services; d) during execution of the Project, the level of annual, consolidated state budgetary expenditures allocated to the maintenance and repair of health care facilities will not be less than the level of such expenditures implemented in 1994, taking into account adjustments for inflation; (4) individuals and families will be allowed full freedom to choose from which health service providers and physicians to receive treatment, and this freedom will be assured and protected; (5) a national policy concerning pharmaceuticals will be implemented, including: a) adoption of all necessary legal, organizational and financial measures in order to ensure that only drugs which are safe and of proven effectiveness will be available for use in the Republic; b) implementation of an Essential Drugs Program; (c) starting from the third year of the Project, allocation of state budgetary resources for the procurement, distribution, or provision of only pharmaceuticals which are contained on the Republic's Essential Drugs List; d) continued elimination of obstacles impeding the establishment and financial success of privately-owned pharmacies, distributors of pharmaceuticals, and pharmaceutical manufacturers. During negotiations of the Credit Agreement, held recently in Washington, another key question was raised in connection with the Government's Policy, and I would like to take this opportunity to clarify this as well. The rationalization and modernization of the health care sector, and the allocation of increased resources to support ambulatory methods of treatment, will necessitate the redeployment of a significant number of specialists and other health care personnel. This will be a very complicated and at times painful process and will have to be conducted with utmost care and concern for the people involved. Considerable re-training will be required, some of which is envisioned to take place under the Project. I wish to assure you, however, that the first priority of the Government is to improve the health of the people of our Republic, and that we will not hesitate to take even painful steps if necessary in order to achieve this goal. Sincerely, By Is/ A. Djumagulov Prime Minister of the Kyrgyz Republic
 71 ANNEX 2.A KYRGYZ REPUBLIC HEALTH SECTOR REFORM PROJECT ANNEX 2.A: PRIMARY HEALTH CARE - WOMEN'S REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH SUB-COMPONENT A. Background 1. There are one million women of reproductive age in the Kyrgyz Republic and, in 1993, just over 120,000 live births. This sub-component is designed to reach these women and impact upon their health status and that of their newborns. 2. Maternal, perinatal and reproductive health activities are implemented through the Maternal and Child Health Department at the Ministry of Health (MOH). This department has shrunk from eight positions to five positions in the last couple of years. There are plans to merge this department into the Prevention and Treatment Department at the MOH, and thereby reduce staff positions even further. At the regional level there is a Chief Pediatrician and a Chief Obstetrician for each of the 6 Oblast Health Administrations and also for Bishkek City Health Department. There is one Medical Institute for training medical students; 10 medical colleges for training paramedics; and a Department of Continuous Medical Education for refresher training of doctors and paramedics. The Republican Institute for Obstetrics, Gynecology and Pediatrics acts as a tertiary referral hospital and research center, and trains post-diploma specialists. 3. The Kyrgyz Republic has an extensive health service infrastructure from the district (Raion), to the regional (Oblast) and Republican levels. The existing organizational structures in the health system hamper the provision of optimnal care. For instance, the current system of urban health services is highly specialized and fragmented. For gynecological problems and pregnancy a women must visit a women's consultation center; for contraception and infertility, a marriage and family center; and for AIDS testing, an AIDS center. Similarly, the separation of diagnosis of STDs in women's consultations from their treatment in venerology clinics lessens the likelihood that women and their partners will in fact be treated. Separating delivery in the maternity home from the provision of acute neonatal care in the children's hospitals inhibits prompt treatment of sick babies. There is also a wastage of limited resources through the duplication of services: for example normal maternal patients and "pathological" maternal patients are treated in separate hospital departments with separate labor, delivery, surgical and post-delivery facilities. Premature and sick and full-term babies are also kept in different departments. Some of these shortcomings are identified by the WHO/World Bank consultant Prof. H. Ramic in his report "Maternal and Perinatal Health in the Kyrgyz Republic, June 1995 ". One of the aims of the Primary Health Care Component is to merge specialist facilities and integrate their services at the primary health care level, thereby streamlining the referral system and reducing the need for separate specialized hospitals, departments and clinics. Maternal Mortality Rates per 100,000 live births (MOH data) 1990 1991 1992 1993 1994 81.4 76.4 70.1 80.1 80.1 4. The maternal mortality rate (MMR) at 80.1 per 100,000 live births, is far higher than that of Russia (51), Ukraine (32), Costa Rica (20) or the European Union (10), despite the fact that over 95% of births occur in hospitals and prenatal health care is widely available. The MMR remained stable
 72 ANNEX 2.A between 1993 and 1994 at 80.1 per 100,000 live births having risen from a 1992 rate of 70. 1. The WHO definition of maternal mortality and live births has not been adopted as yet and the true MMR may well be 30% to 50% higher than the official Government rates. Birth intervals are short, only one year in 22% of women. Almost 10% of births are to women less than 19 years of age. The birth rate is dropping in the current difficult socioeconomic conditions. Almost 75% of all maternal deaths are in rural areas. Inter-oblast variation in maternal death rates can be quite substantial. Over the period 1992- 1993, in those oblast where the Ministry of Health made a concerted effort to supply drugs and train primary health care workers, they were able to reduce the maternal death rates considerably. The shortage of resources, constrained the Ministry of Health's ability to extend this support to all oblasts. This sub-component aims to rectify this. 5. The perinatal mortality in 1991 was 26 per 1000 births and is moderately high for a country with universal coverage of maternal and child health services. It has however been dropping slightly since 1991. but the actual contribution of perinatal mortality to the infant mortality rate has been increasing; from 25% in 1994 to 29% in 1995. The main cause of perinatal death are in descending order: respiratory distress syndrome, birth hypoxia/asphyxia, intracranial birth trauma, and sepsis. The rate of low birth weight in the Kyrgyz Republic is below 6 %, quite a low level even in developed countries, but the birth weight specific mortality rates are somewhat high. Most of the problem lies in the survival of newborns with 2,500 grams of birth weight or more. This is likely to be due to the quality of perinatal medical care. The Kyrgyz Republic could probably reduce substantially this current level of perinatal mortality if greater survival could be achieved for the heavier babies. The low rates of Caesarean section (of which two thirds are emergency and only one third elective) and assisted deliveries could explain to a large extent the high rates of mortality among the heavier babies. 6. A comprehensive approach to the inpatient management of pregnant women, her labor and delivery, and the care of her newborn infant has been shown to decrease mortality in other countries. Cooperative efforts between obstetricians and pediatricians is essential to this success. Regionalization of perinatal care consists of treating low risk pregnant women and newborns in raion centers and referring high risk women, sick and/or premature infants to perinatal centers. The current list of risk factors for pregnant women is too stringent and leads to the inclusion of almost 80% of women in the at risk category, leading to unacceptably high referral rates to higher levels of care. As a result, minor problems are overstated and serious ones may be overlooked. Given the difficult conditions for women in the Kyrgyz Republic approximately 20-25 % of pregnant women can be expected to be at risk of morbidity during pregnancy and childbirth. Internationally, the risk group is usually 10% or less. New protocols will be introduced to rationalize this screening of pregnant women into high risk groups, thereby shifting limited resources to the serious cases who need them the most. 7. Deaths from eclarnpsia, hemorrhage and sepsis, the leading causes of maternal death in the Kyrgyz Republic, can all be prevented using a range of cost-effective interventions at the primary health care level. A third of maternal deaths are due to eclampsia (high blood pressure and swelling leading to fits and coma) and these eclamptic deaths have increased in proportion to the other main causes, hemorrhage and sepsis, over the last few years. This increase is thought to be due to lack of training and basic equipment in prenatal care at the primary health care level coupled with a shortage of transport. Abortion is also a leading cause of maternal deaths. Abortion rates are very high, with an average of 2.3 to 2.7 abortions per woman. Although reliable data on contraceptive prevalence is lacking, it would appear that there is a large unmet need for contraceptives. Abortion remains the primary means of fertility control. There is a particular need for contraceptive counselling in the postnatal period and after an abortion. High rates of anemia in Kyrgyz women, about 30% of pregnant women, have consequences for both the mother and her unborn child. Severe anemia in the mother will limit blood supply to the fetus, increasing the risk of newborn asphyxia/hypoxia. In the event of hemorrhage during delivery,
 73 ANNEX 2.A anemia greatly increases the likelihood of the women suffering from shock or death. As a result, routine iron folate and multivitamin supplementation will be introduced for pregnant women. 8. In general, hospital practices during delivery are fairly comparable to European practices, but there are several major shortcomings which must be corrected: first and second stage of labor should be limited in time; the use of forceps and vacuum extractors should be encouraged; the indications for Caesarean section must be revised; the fetus should be monitored regularly; the prevention and management of postpartum hemorrhage must be improved. This sub-component aims to upgrade the obstetric skills of obstetricians and midwives to improve their monitoring of labor and their clinical judgement on when and how to intervene with an intervention (labor induction, augmentation, vacuum extraction, Caesarean section, etc.). Breastfeeding will also be encouraged in this sub-component, in collaboration with UNICEF who plan to establish a Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative, through the development of a supportive environment in maternity homes (rooming-in, early mother-baby contact, on-demand feeding, presence of family members, etc.). 9. The current system does not sufficiently emphasize health education as part of prenatal care, nor do sufficient educational and promotional materials exist. There is also a low level of knowledge of the needs of pregnant women among the general population. In a country, such as the Kyrgyz Republic, with very high literacy levels in males and females, this should not be the case. Information, education and communications are essential to improve knowledge of family planning, nutrition and maternity care, including recognition of danger signs of complications of pregnancy, among women, family members, community leaders and health care providers. To rectify these shortcomings in the health system, this subcomponent will focus on teaching counselling techniques to health workers; and will fund the development, printing and distribution of a health education booklet for the general public. 10. The epidemiological picture for syphilis and gonorrhea has fallen somewhere between the pattern seen in developing countries; that is epidemic levels of diseases, and the picture seen in industrialized countries; that is low and still falling rates of infection confined to high risk groups. Since 1993, there has been a ten fold increase in the incidence of syphilis. This dramatic increase reflects a trend reported in many other republics of the former Soviet Union. At the same time detection rates for gonorrhea have declined after remaining at a stable level over the last two decades. This data suggests that the level of unsafe sexual activity in the Kyrgyz Republic is increasing and less STD cases are seeking treatment in the government health system. Little information is available on the incidence of chlamydia. Up until 1995, HIV had not been detected in the resident population despite a massive screening program. STD and AIDS are managed through two separate vertical organizational structures that merge at the district level. Access to STD treatment is limited to a few specialized dermatovenereal clinics in which people must registers their names in order to obtain free treatment. The result is that most STD cases either treat themselves or seek anonymous care from non-accredited private doctors. Adolescents are particularly vulnerable because of their lack of money and information. More detailed information is available in the World Bank report "Assessment of the Sexually Transmitted Diseases Program in the Kyrgyz Republic: October 1994". One aim of this sub-component is to encourage the anonymous ambulatory management of patients with syphilis and gonorrhea and the integration of venerology services into the primary health care level. 11. In sumnmary, the health infrastructure is extensive, women are educated and relatively mobile. Family planning is still not readily available to the majority of women, but with donor assistance the range of services are expanding. Safe abortion is offered through the government health system. Maternal services are available at primary health care facilities, but are under-utilized. Delivery attendants are trained, the vast majority of deliveries take place in hospital, but the clinical practices need upgrading and a regular supply of essential drugs, supplies and equipment must be established. IEC
 74 ANNEX 2.A capability is available but under-utilized. Improving the quality and efficiency of health care, including decentralizing services, as well as developing a more comprehensive strategy for women's health, and improving information, education and commnunication; will all be priority interventions in this sub- component. This sub-component makes up for a major deficit in the assistance being provided by other donors to priority health programs; namely a comprehensive safe motherhood and perinatal health intervention for implementation nationwide. Many donors are providing small scale activities in a few selected health facilities. USAID and UNFPA have focused on a specific element of safe motherhood; contraceptive supply and family planning activities. This sub-component will focus on all the other components: maternal health, perinatal health, and sexually transmitted diseases case management; and integrate them with the family planning activities. The aim of this sub-component is to reduce the heavy burden of maternal and perinatal deaths and ensure the long-term sustainability of a comprehensive maternal and perinatal health program within the government health structure through a process of rationalization and decentralization.  93 ANNEX 2.B KYRGYZ REPUBLIC HEALTH SECTOR REFORM PROJECT ANNEX 2.B: PRIMARY HEALTH CARE - ACUTE RESPIRATORY INFECTIONS AND DIARRHEAL DISEASE CONTROL SUBCOMPONENT A. Background 1. In 1991, the corrected infant mortality rate (IMR) for the Kyrgyz Republic, 40 per 1000 live births, was slightly lower than the average IMR for upper middle income countries (about 45 per 1,000 live births). A few countries (such as China and Sri Lanka) with lower income per capita report an IMR better than that of the Kyrgyz Republic, but most have an IMR even higher. The mortality indicators however, have shown little improvement over the past ten to fifteen years (the IMR declined only ten percent from 1970 to 1985). Uncorrected Infant Mortality Rates per 1000 live births (source MOH) 1988 1989 1990 1991 1992 1993 1994 36.6 32.7 29.9 29.6 31.5 31.9 29.4 l 2. In the Kyrgyz Republic, as shown in the table below, acute respiratory infections, perinatal conditions and diarrheal diseases are responsible for over 90% of infant deaths. As can be seen in the "Prioritization Framework" table, acute respiratory infections and diarrheal diseases account for most of the potential Disability Adjusted Life Year (DALY) loss per year. An acute respiratory infections program and diarrheal diseases control program (ARI/CDD program) are the most cost-effective health interventions to reduce the IMR in the Kyrgyz Republic. However, international experience has shown that a reduction in IMR would not be expected until 5-6 years after the introduction of the program. Respiratory infections accounted for over half of infant deaths in Naryn, Osh, Djalal Abad and Talas Oblasts. The proportion of diarrhea deaths are particularly high in Osh and Djalal Abad Oblasts in the south of the country. Most acute respiratory disease deaths occur in the long winter months (90% of the Kyrgyz Republic is covered in high mountains) and most diarrhea related deaths in the summer months, particularly in the warmer southern regions. A child who is malnourished and has an acute respiratory infection or diarrhea is more likely to die than a child who is not malnourished and has an acute respiratory infection or diarrhea. Malnutrition is on the increase in the Kyrgyz Republic. Over 7% of all pre-school children are acutely malnourished, and this rises to 15% in some regions (Kyrgyz Multi- Purpose Survey 1994).  94 ANNEX 2.B 3. Most of the infant deaths due to infectious diseases such as acute respiratory infections and diarrhea are concentrated in the rural areas of the Kyrgyz Republic, where the rates of mortality due to these causes is two to three times higher than that of urban areas. The rural areas are more mountainous and health facilities more limited. The infant mortality in rural areas increases sharply during the winter months, probably reflecting variations in mortality rates due to acute respiratory infections, as seasonality is negligible in urban areas. Children reach the health facility too late: leading to a high proportion of deaths within the first 24 hours of admission (32% of admissions in 1993). At the same time hospitalization rates for children with ARIs is very high and the majority of children with ARI do not need to be admitted. The high rates of acute respiratory infections is probably due to a combination of three factors: intra-household combustion of wood, the ignorance of parents of the early signs and symptoms of severe acute respiratory infection, and inadequate clinical management of the disease. These ARI deaths are concentrated particularly in under 5 year olds. 4. Although the rate of mortality due to diarrheal diseases is only one fourth of the rate due to acute respiratory diseases, the majority of the deaths are probably preventable. The average case fatality rate of 1.2% and hospital case fatality rate of 3% are very high, but could be due to the high under reporting of diarrhea cases. Two main strategies are needed: promotion of exclusive breastfeeding for the first four months of life and prolonged to one year, and better home and health facility case management of diarrheal episodes following WHO guidelines, including rehydration therapy with home fluids and ORS packets and antibiotics for dysenteric cases. Oral rehydration therapy has been promoted in the Kyrgyz Republic since 1985. ORT corners were established at primary health care facilities. The Ministry of Health in collaboration with UNICEF initiated a control of diarrheal disease program in 1992, and UNICEF is supplying 500,000 ORS packets annually. Despite these efforts ORS is not on the newly developed national list of essential drugs. Outmoded treatments such as bacterium bifidum and "biostimulators" are still recommended for diarrhea treatment in MOH guidelines and the major teaching hospitals. USAID (through Wellstart) and UNICEF have funded breastfeeding promotion activities and UNICEF plan to launch a Baby Friendly Hospital Initiative. It is the practice, in all the former Soviet countries, to have pediatricians treating ARIs; and infectious diseases specialists treating diarrhea in separate infectious disease wards and hospitals. Acute respiratory infections and diarrheal diseases are also the most common childhood diseases seen in clinics and admitted to hospitals. In 1991, 47% of all children under one year suffered from a respiratory infection. Nearly half of all hospital admissions in children are for respiratory diseases. In 1991, 70% of all under one year olds seen in the outpatient department with a respiratory infection were admitted to hospital. In the same year, 40% of all under fifteen year olds were hospitalized. These very high hospitalization rates for what is usually a mild viral infection, are quite inappropriate. This is confirmed by observations in the field. Hospital beds are indeed occupied by children with mild respiratory infections who could be equally well managed at home. At the same time there are very sick children in
 95 ANNEX 2.B the community, who are arriving at the hospital too late. What is required is a comprehensive mass media campaign for the general public, combined with major retraining of health workers. In addition, reduced capacity in the government drug procurement and distribution agency, Pharmacia, has resulted in a shortage of ARI/CDD drugs throughout the government health system. 6. Acute respiratory infections and diarrheal disease in under five year olds have already been identified by the government and the donor community as priority health problems. In the government's "Health For All 1994-2000" program, breastfeeding, ARI and diarrheal disease control have been included as the priority interventions. In collaboration with the Ministry of Health (MOH), a UNICEF funded ARI/CDD program started in 1993. In 1994, the MOH developed a National ARI/CDD Program and appointed a National ARI/CDD programn manager, Dr. Apisa Kushbakeeva, the Chief Pediatrician at the MOH. A National ARI/CDD Policy has not been finalized or endorsed. A report of a World Bank/WHO consultant, Dr. E. Kudlova, "Evaluation of the Status of ARI/CDD Program in Kyrgyzstan- July 1995" revealed that even in the Republican Institute hospitals, children with ARIs and diarrhea are admitted unnecessarily and treated with inappropriate case management protocols. Her report identified the following shortcomings in the MOH/UNICEF ARI/CDD programs: (i) Lack of national CDD/ARI policy and case management guidelines; (ii) Inadequate supervision, management, surveillance of ARI/CDD activities at all levels; (iii) Lack of WHO ARI/CDD Russian materials in the Kyrgyz Republic, despite being available. (iv) Lack of ARI/CDD case management training including clinical "hands-on" practice; (v) Inappropriate use of drugs for the treatment of diarrhea and ARI, inappropriate rehydration of dehydrated cases, unnecessary hospitalization of CDD/ARI cases at tertiary, secondary and primary health care levels; and (vi) Some incorrect mass media health messages on the home management of ARI/CDD. B. Role of Other Donors 7. UNICEF, in collaboration with the MOH, began an ARI/CDD control program in 1992, using the case management guidelines developed by WHO. UNICEF funded some training activities, provided a television and VCR (which were lost), and supplied and transported essential drugs to primary health care facilities bypassing the Government system. This case management training has not reached health workers at all levels of the health system. The Republican Health Education Center has limited capacity to mobilize the general public in appropriate health seeking behavior for ARI/CDD and UNICEF has been forced to use the private sector to get ARI/CDD television messages out to the general public. The full implementation of this program has been patchy due to limited resources and the diminished capacity in several MOH departments. UNICEF will continue to take the lead in the training of health workers at the primary health level and the World Bank subcomponent will focus on the development of model training centers and a core of trainers. UNICEF will continue to supply ARI and CDD drugs through a series of winter and summer programs, targeted at under 5 year olds. The World Bank/WHO consultant calculated that the UNICEF contribution of 500,000 ORS packets cover about 70% of the estimated need. The World Bank supply of ARI/CDD drugs will cover this shortfall in national drug requirements. The UNICEF and World Bank drug supplies to the primary health care level will need to be closely coordinated. 8. Rationale for Bank Involvement 9. In the short term, the current economic crisis will slow down or reverse improvements in living conditions, but a significant reduction in the burden of disease can still be achieved at low cost through improving the coverage and quality of some health interventions. This should be possible in view of the high level of education of the population, and the vast health infrastructure. About sixty percent of the Kyrgyz Republic's infant mortality is caused by acute respiratory infections and diarrhea. ARI and CDD programs using WHO guidelines are two of the most cost-effective programs; as shown in the 1993 World Development Report: Investing in Health. 10. The World Bank activities will complement the more comprehensive nation-wide primary health care training program planned by UNICEF for 1996-2001, by focusing on the hospital level. An evaluation of the ARI/CDD program in 1995, by a WHO consultant, showed that although some progress had been made in training at the peripheral level, case management is patchy, and a comprehensive retraining program throughout all levels of the health system, from the major teaching institutes downwards, is required. The Bank project will focus on improving the quality of "hands-on" case management training and institutionalizing this practical training within the Department of Continuous Medical Education and a network of Oblast model health facilities (one hospital, one polyclinic and one FAP per Oblast) to be developed under the PHC component. The Bank project will also strengthen the capacities of government institutions to provide essential ARI/CDD drugs and promote health education. D. ARI/CDD Subcomponent Description I 1. - The long term goals of the Acute Respiratory Infections and Control of Diarrheal Disease subcomponent are to reduce deaths in children from acute respiratory tract infections and diarrhea. 12. To realize these goals, the activities within the four years of this project are to: (i) Strengthen Program Management: (a) Improve ARI/CDD program management at the Ministry of Health and Oblast Health Administration levels (training, study tour, supply computer); (b) Develop a national strategy for the rationalization and integration of ARI/CDD services. (ii) Upgrade Health Provider Skills: (a) Develop a training package; (b) Strengthen and decentralize training sites; (c) Train a core of National and Oblast trainers (d) Train hospital health providers at national, Oblast and Raion levels; (e) Introduce adapted WHO ARI/CDD case management guidelines in pre-service and in-service training curricula of doctors and paramnedics.
