Develop a training package: A well defined set of national policies will be developed and these will be used as the basis for the technical guidelines on case management of diarrheal diseases and acute respiratory infections. The guidelines will be developed by a team of national experts, with the assistance of an international technical advisor. The guidelines will cover two major areas of the program activities: first - management of the patient at home and in the outpatient departments, and, second - management of complicated cases in hospital. Different types of guidelines will be developed for different types of health workers and different types of program activities: rational use of drugs, community involvement, prevention, etc.. These guidelines will involve reduction in the inappropriate use of antibiotics and other drugs; in order to decrease the cost of treatment, the need for hospitalization, and the harmful consequences of inappropriate drug treatment. 26. The focus of the case management training is on the recognition of clinical signs in the child and the appropriate use of antibiotics for a few specified disease categories. Participants will learn how to give oral rehydration salts to a child with different grades of dehydration. The current case management of respiratory diseases and diarrheal diseases in the major hospitals will need considerable upgrading before they can be used as training units. Many children with respiratory infections and diarrheal diseases receive multiple antibiotic therapy and unnecessary hospitalization. Children with diarrhea and no signs of dehydration receive intravenous fluids often under sedation. The outmoded hospital case management practices have considerably impeded the impact of the UNICEF funded training at the PHC level. Unless

G. Benefits and Risks 42. It has been agreed between the World Bank mission and UNICEF, that UNICEF has the larger budget for ARI/CDD and should be the lead agency. This subcomponent has been carefully designed with the UNICEF Regional Mission for Central Asia, to complement UNICEF planned activities. There is always a risk that these plans may change. In 1995, a World Bank/WHO consultant's review of the UNICEF funded ARI/CDD program has revealed a rather patchy training strategy to date. Although UNICEF now plans a more comprehensive approach, there is still a risk that their training activities will not be institutionalized, and therefore not sustainable. One to avoid this is for UNICEF to use the National and Oblast core trainers, the CCMEs, and model health facilities in their training program. The benefit to UNICEF taking the lead, is that the MOH has been used to working with UNICEF on ARI/CDD, and this collaboration will now continue. 43. The Ministry of Health, has been downsized, and plans are underway to cut staffing levels even further. This is coupled with a lack of management capacity. The ability of the MOH to supervise the program effectively is in doubt. However, there is tremendous government commitment to health reform and ARI/CDD programs and some very talented and dedicated people in the government health system. The project design includes a phased implementation of the PHC Component to avoid excessive burden on the MOH. Changing case management protocols is notoriously difficult, particularly at the tertiary health facilities level. Unless case management at these Republican hospitals (the training ground for future doctors) are improved, it will be difficult to make changes lower down the health system. Attempts to integrate services will meet with strong opposition from health personnel at all levels of the health system whose jobs are at stake. H. Monitoring and Evaluation 44.  113 ANNEX 2.C KYRGYZ REPUBLIC HEALTH SECTOR REFORM PROJECT ANNEX 2.C: PRIMARY HEALTH CARE - TUBERCULOSIS CONTROL SUB-COMPONENT A. Background 1. A WHO analysis in March 1995 found the tuberculosis situation in the Kyrgyz Republic to be grave. Even during the Soviet period, tuberculosis case notification rates were among the highest of the whole USSR. More recently, after a few years of decline, case rates have increased by an average 3.9% annually between 1989 and 1994, when 60 cases per 100,000 population were reported. In Bishkek city this rate was 90.7 per 100.000 in 1994, i.e., similar to that of some of the most affected developing countries. The largest proportion of cases still occurs in the young adult age groups, i.e., the most productive segment of the population, and in 1994, over two thirds of all cases occurred in persons less than 45 years of age. Using the very scarce data available from tuberculin surveys, 25 cases of smear positive tuberculosis would occur annually in the Kyrgyz Republic. However, this estimate must be taken with caution. Considering the poor attractiveness of the current Program, the fact that many patients may not be diagnosed because of the current constraints, and the very high rate among the young adults, the incidence of tuberculosis (all cases) in the Kyrgyz Republic may be higher than reported, i.e., up to 70 per 100,000. 2. Mortality from tuberculosis has increased by an average 13.6% per year between 1988 and 1994, when it was 13.6 per 100,000 population, i.e., the one of the highest in the whole Europe and the former USSR. In Bishkek city the mortality rate was 29.7 per 100.000 in 1994. Because of reduced case finding activities, the mortality rate could be much higher than reported. At present, it can be estimated that more 20% of all cases result in deaths; therefore, true tuberculosis mortality may be in the order of 15-20 per 100,000, if undiagnosed and untreated cases are included. 3. In addition to this serious epidemiological situation, drug resistance levels, particularly to the most important antituberculosis drugs, isoniazid and rifamnpicin, are reported to be on the increase from already very high levels recorded in 1985-1987. This situation may even be worsening due to the current inadequate treatment regimens and the increasing defaulting rate. 4. The are two types of problems which are compromising the effectiveness of the Tuberculosis Program. The first is that the economic crisis is affecting the budget for health, resulting in lack of drugs and supplies. The second is that the existing well developed infrastructure is not utilized in a cost- effective manner, as the policies of the National Tuberculosis Program are not in line with the recent WHO strategy for global tuberculosis control, which is based on provision of short-course chemotherapy to, at least, all sputum smear-positive cases. 5. The analysis of the findings on TB control activities revealed a number of major problems. The expensive and poor-yielding active screening of large proportions of the population by mass miniature radiography is still being conducted, although to a limited extent due to lack of funds for maintenance of the mobile van teams. Diagnosis is based on various tests and gives priority to chest radiography rather than emphasizing smear microscopy. Tuberculosis patients are hospitalized for an excessive period of time, although recently less than in the past due to lack of funds, and often kept in a convalescent status in sanatoria for months. Patients are not treated with standard regimens, but drug combinations are often individualized, also due to a serious lack of essential drugs; this results in low cure rates and the production of chronic infectious cases, often infected with strains of M. tuberculosis resistant to drugs.
 114 ANNEX 2.C In addition, because of the weaknesses of the Program, defaulting rates are increasing rapidly, therefore favoring continued transmission of tubercle bacilli in the community and onset of drug resistance. Finally, WHO recommended recording and reporting systems are not in place; therefore, evaluation of treatment cannot be accomplished. 6. The WHO tuberculosis Program consultants made specific recommendations in order to have a 5-point policy package for effective tuberculosis control adopted by the Government. Discussions with Dr A. Alisherov (Director of the National Tuberculosis Research Institute - NTRI) and Dr P.I. Limarev (NTRI Chief Epidemiologist) during the October mission, as well as the recommendations from the First Meeting of the National Tuberculosis Program Managers from the countries of Eastern Europe and the former USSR held in Warsaw, Poland on 20-22 June 1994, resulted in the production of a document adopting the WHO modern strategy of tuberculosis control in a cost-effective manner. This document, already approved by the MOH, will be submitted for approval to the Cabinet of Ministers, showing the commitment of the Program managers seriously to renovate the control strategy. B. Role of Other Donors 7. Despite the severity of this public health problem, no donor agency has undertaken any serious, comprehensive and sustainable activity to help the National Program cope with the ongoing deterioration of tuberculosis control. C. Rationale for Bank Involvement 8. Tuberculosis control, according to the "World Development Report 1993" is among the most cost-effective of all interventions. A new strategy of tuberculosis control in the Kyrgyz Republic may indeed have a profound impact, as it will prevent deaths and disabilities among the most productive age groups, and, at the same time, make more effective'use of scarce resources by simply reducing length of hospitalization, number of beds, and other costly interventions. D. The Sub-Component 9. The overall goal of the sub-component is to improve the management of the tuberculosis control program in the Kyrgyz Republic. The two specific objectives are: (a) To reduce the risk of tuberculosis transmission in the community and tuberculosis morbidity and mortality. The project would aim at expanding and improving free, mostly ambulatory, treatment with short course chemotherapy of patients with infectious tuberculosis to achieve reduction of infection rate in the population of the Kyrgyz Republic. (b) To institute policy reforms and improve program management to achieve greater efficiency and effectiveness of tuberculosis control activities. The project would aim at a better integration within the revitalized primary health system, at strengthening the institution management and financing system, personnel and operational methods for disease control, and at developing and disseminating cost-effective methods and materials for improving control and sustaining the progress made. 10. The project would revitalize the National Tuberculosis Program (NTP) by providing support for program implementation to the existing central (NTRI), oblast, and raion structures and to the primary health care services countrywide.
 115 ANNEX 2.C 11. The tuberculosis control sub-component will consist of the following activities implemented during the period 1996-2000. (a) Improvement and free provision of tuberculosis diagnostic services in at least one facility per raion or city (be it a tuberculosis dispensary or a general health facility), and upgrading of the quality of bacteriological services at raion and city level. (b) Provision of free short course chemotherapy and other treatment services to all tuberculosis cases, with directly observed therapy during, at least, the initial phase of chemotherapy, and achievement of high cure rates among all smear positive pulmonary cases. (c) Improvement of case management by adoption of WHO recommended recording and reporting system, and adequate supervision. 12. Institutional strengthening of tuberculosis control will include the following: (a) Establishing, within the MOH, a formal NTP and under its leadership guarantee the operational support to the three levels of tuberculosis care, i.e., the oblast, the raion/city and the primary health care structure. The central unit of the NTP, based at the NTRI should have adequate staff facilities and budgets to be responsible for formulating, supervising and enforcing national tuberculosis control policies. (b) Reorganizing and upgrading the oblast level of the NTP within the oblast tuberculosis Dispensary to plan, manage and supervise activities conducted within the oblast. (c) Reorganizing and upgrading the raion level of the NTP in each raion in order to plan, manage and supervise control activities within the PHC system. (d) Implementing administrative, technical and financial reforms to improve the system by which the central unit finances and manages control activities through the oblast level. 13. The following investment and activities will be implemented in the Kyrgyz Republic during a 5- year period of implementation (1996-2000). A detailed tuberculosis policy package of administrative and technical reforms governing tuberculosis control activities has been agreed with the NTRI. Assurances were obtained that the Kyrgyz MOH will guarantee that the tuberculosis policy package is implemented stepwise in the country in all its terms and conditions, and maintain its provisions in effect for the full project implementation period. The tuberculosis policy package constitutes the basis for the development of a national manual for tuberculosis control. It addresses the main issues currently facing the Kyrgyz control program and provides a basis from which rapid progress on tuberculosis control can be expected. Its main features provide: (a) Chemotherapy for eligible patients and all case detection examinations, follow up, and other procedures done by existing tuberculosis and PHC facilities, and supervision of chemotherapy within hospitals or by feldshers and polyclinics, shall be free of charge to the patient. (b) Only approved short course chemotherapy (SCC) regimens would be stocked and prescribed by the raion tuberculosis coordinator.
 116 ANNEX 2.C 14. Diagnostic services will rely on self referral by symptomatic cases (passive case finding). However, health workers at all levels, and particularly, peripheral doctors and feldshers, will be encouraged to actively identify suspected tuberculosis cases and refer them to the nearest raion facility for confirmation of diagnosis. The project encourages reorganization of the diagnostic services by which at each raion there is at least one facility (preferably a raion hospital, alternatively a tuberculosis dispensary or a general health polyclinic) where a microscopy center and an X-ray unit are accommodated. These facilities should be supervised for their tuberculosis component by the raion coordinator who should, therefore, be based ideally at the central raion hospital. Each microscopy center will have at least one binocular microscope for rapid and reliable screening of stained sputum smears. In raions where distances or population densities are such that reliance on one single facility for diagnosis is inappropriate, additional diagnostic services located at polyclinics or ambulatories must be available. 15. Chest radiography examination will be provided to all persons with symptoms suggestive of tuberculosis referred by doctors or feldshers at the designated raion facility (a general hospital or a tuberculosis dispensary, if available) capable of accommodating the X-ray unit and the microscopy center. Patients with abnormal films will have at least three sputum specimens examined for tubercle bacilli. For patients living in distant parts of the raion, a brief 6-7 day hospitalization may be necessary to complete the diagnostic screening and make the decision on treatment. Procedures to be followed for diagnosis will be based on clear instructions. In brief, patients with abnormal chest X-ray and positive sputum smears will be considered tuberculosis cases and treated accordingly. Those with abnormal chest X-ray and negative sputum will be reviewed by a doctor of the facility where the diagnostic screening was done (preferably a tuberculosis specialist or a physician who has been trained on tuberculosis) and a decision on treatment will be made; in these cases, sputum cultures should be obtained. Those with negative chest X- ray will receive broad spectrum antibiotics and be discharged to their referring health care worker for reevaluation. Naturally, as treatment decisions will depend largely on primary health care doctors, adequate training will be required by the tuberculosis specialists available in the Raion. It would be preferable if, during the process of primary health care reorganization, tuberculosis specialists are designated to work in primary health care facilities or at general hospitals, so that a specialist is present for rapid consultation in each institution where decisions on treatment are made. 16. About 30,000 chest X-ray films and about 350,000 smears are expected to be required. As radiographic screening to rule-out tuberculosis will be performed within primary health care facilities, cost of films should be covered by the primary care structure, except in those cases where tuberculosis is confirmed (in such instances, the project will cover the cost of the initial film and of a second one when this is necessary). The project provides appropriate equipment (about 170 binocular microscopes, 1 fluorescent microscopes and other essential laboratory equipment), along with ancillary supplies for microscopy (containers, slides, and stains), and radiography (X-ray films). Training for PHC doctors and feldshers to recognize and refer tuberculosis symptomatics will be provided by the raion tuberculosis coordinators. 17. Chemotherapy: The primary target of the tuberculosis component is the achievement of high cure rates (usually more than 85%), as rapid case detection and sputum conversions of infectious cases are the best means for prevention of tuberculosis transmission. The cure rate indicates not only the proportion of cases who convert to negative sputum smear, but also the proportion of those who remain sources of infection. Since the lives of patients not cured are prolonged by inadequate treatment over the expected survival of untreated cases, their cumulative number increases the pool of infectious cases. In addition, inadequate treatment is likely to produce drug resistant strains and their spread. Therefore, the main target of tuberculosis control is to reduce drastically the sputum smear positive sources of infection. In order to achieve this target, specific technical criteria must be strictly followed. In brief, regimens must be adequate, and standardized according to specific patient categories. In addition, chemotherapy
 117 ANNEX 2.C must be supervised, i.e., drug intake must be directly observed by the administering doctor, feldsher or nurse, at least during the 2-month initial phase of treatment. Treatment will be mostly on an ambulatory basis, although hospitalization may be necessary for advanced and severe forms of tuberculosis. A final decision on treatment modality (fully ambulatory vs. hospitalization for the initial phase) will be made only after analysis of results from pilot projects. Finally, to facilitate drug administration, to improve patient compliance, especially during the continuation phase, and to protect against the onset of drug resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin, drug combinations are essential. The project would provide for the purchase and distribution of the five basic drugs required. Drug types and dosages have been estimated. 18. Monitoring of treatment results is indispensable to evaluate efficacy of chemotherapy. This is accomplished by regular sputum smear microscopy at the end of the initial phase of treatment, and at least twice during the continuation phase, of which one at the end of it. Therefore, an additional 6 sputum smears per patients enrolled, i.e., about 50.000 sputum smears, will be done. Treatment results will be monitored utilizing cohort analysis of all enrolled patients based on six clearly defined categories of treatment outcomes. 19. Case management: The revitalized NTP will adopt and maintain a standard WHO recommended recording and reporting system. This include the following forms: tuberculosis raion register, laboratory register, tuberculosis treatment card, request for sputum examination, and quarterly and yearly reports. These forms will be approved by the MOH. Translation and printing of the forms will be supported by the project. 20. Financial Incentives: The government should approve and introduce a system of financial incentives for case detection and cure of tuberculosis patients. Funds can be derived from the savings resulting from ambulatory treatment and abandoning previous expensive practices. Key elements for incentives will be: (a) A 30 som payment to any health worker who originally refers tuberculosis suspects for examination, if the diagnosis of tuberculosis is confirmed by microscopy. (b) Primary health workers who manage a tuberculosis case will be paid 60 soms at the end of treatment of a smear-positive patient in whom cure is documented. Health workers will be paid 30 soms for the management of smear negative patients after treatment completion. These additional payments, as well as the regular salaries, will be ensured by the Government and paid by the raion health administration on a regular basis. If drug administration is not fully supervised in the initial phase, as shown by the treatment cards and registry, payment will not be made. Payment will not be made to the tuberculosis facilities staff and to hospital staff managing hospitalized patients. 21. All oblasts implementing the new program will adopt the standard registry and forms at the beginning of the project. The registry will make it possible to identify raions with lower than average case detection rates and low proportion of bacteriologically confirmed cases. This will allow the oblast supervisors and the central unit to target management efforts and training to improve the situation. It will allow the oblast tuberculosis coordinator to monitor and evaluate treatment results in each raion and to identify those who need additional training and supervision. These registry, forms and reports will provide the most important tool for program supervision and monitoring. 22. Institutional strengthening: Selected staff at the NTRI have been historically responsible for control activities in the Kyrgyz Republic. The MOH will need to formalize the establishment of a central unit responsible for planning of the operational steps in implementing, monitoring, and evaluating the

A supervision input of the WHO tuberculosis Program is planned for about 4-6 staff weeks per year. Benefits and Risks 30. Benefits: There will be various types of benefits: disease transmission benefits and illnessideath avoided benefits. They will result from rapid reduction in the pool of previously treated smear-positive cases, and more rapid treatment and cure of new smear positive cases, and, as a consequence, from a decrease in infection rate, resulting in permanently lowered incidence rates. The project would increase the cure rate to over 85 % of newly treated infectious cases and improve the case detection rate to at least
 120 ANNEX 2.C 70%. In epidemiological terms, the benefits should be a rapid reduction of tuberculosis prevalence by 50- 60% from current levels and a, at lest, 5% yearly decline in the annual risk of tuberculosis infection. In addition, mortality from tuberculosis will sharply decline within as short a period of one or two years. Eventually a decline of the annual number of new cases due to reduced transmission of tubercle bacilli in the community will follow. Thus, enormous benefits could be achieved in a relatively short period of time, considering that the health infrastructure is still largely in existence. However, further delays in addressing this key health issue would definitely impact on future efforts of control, particularly if a high number of chronic cases resistant to drugs are produced. 31. By the end of the project, a few thousand people will be saved from premature deaths due to tuberculosis and thousands of new infectious cases will be prevented. Patients, their families and communities will directly benefit from avoidance of illness costs, disability and from preservation of productive capacity. In addition, long term benefits can be expected for the next several years as incident cases will start to decrease significantly. 32. Finally, since hard-to-justify numbers of facilities and beds dedicated to tuberculosis control are available in the Kyrgyz Republic, the project will, by its accompanying changes, rationalize the number of beds and reduce the number of facilities. 33. Risks: If implemented as conceived and designed, risks of this project component are small. However, strong guidance from the central unit to oblast and raion units is necessary to ensure that the new control strategy is strictly implemented. In fact, the main risk is that the lower levels of the Program will persist with old technical practices emphasizing case finding rather than focusing on the achievement of high cure rates. This may result from an ineffective adoption of the new strategy of diagnosis, treatment and monitoring, and from defective implementation of the new policy changes. To help guard against these risks, the government must guarantee that financial and technical policy changes are adequately implemented at all levels. 34. Another major risk, linked with the difficult transition phase of the Kyrgyz economy and political system, could be the failure by the GOK to provide salaries for the officers involved with tuberculosis control at various levels and the failure to introduce and sustain incentives for primary health care workers diagnosing and treating tuberculosis cases. Government commitment on this issue is essential. 35. As the new tuberculosis control strategy relies on adequate organization and structure of the revitalized primary health care system, a failure or delay in implementing such a system will negatively impact on efforts to successfully shift from hospital based-treatment to fully ambulatory treatment. In addition, lack of training of general practitioners on tuberculosis control may endanger the project effectiveness to diagnose cases. This can be addressed by the inclusion of tuberculosis in the educational curriculum of primary health care workers, as well as by the reallocation of tuberculosis specialists within primary health care facilities to guarantee adequate assistance to general practitioners during the initial years of the project. Indicators for measuring progress towards project implementation are:

Indicators for measuring progress towards project development objectives (i) Achievement of an organizational structure of the program based on the WHO recommendations (central, oblast, raion, and phc); (ii) Production of a project protocol reflecting the WHO strategy for tuberculosis control from which a national manual will be eventually obtained; (iii) Rationalized use of beds for tuberculosis; (iv) Number of trained staff at all levels (4 at central level, 3 per each oblast, 1 per each raion). Trained staff will be aware of the new tuberculosis control strategy, be able to supervise staff, set objectives, develop work-plans, prepare quarterly reports, and will be able to identify and correct management problems. 38. Indicators of Program Management: The maintenance of accurate records on each individual patient, and periodic reporting is essential to the good management of the NTP at each level. (i) Recording: Data collected should give as true a picture as possible of what is actually happening in the program of diagnosing and treating. The data should be reliable, relevant, and uniform. To achieve this a standard set of documents and reports will be used in all units involved in the sub-component. These are attached and shall not be modified by the Kyrgyz in any way. (ii) Reporting: Reports on case finding and treatment results will be reported from the Raion or City TB coordinator to the Central Unit via the Oblast TB coordinator. Three forms (attached) to be used are: (a) Quarterly report on new cases and relapses of tuberculosis; (b) Quarterly report on the results of treatment of the patients registered 12 - 15 months earlier; (c) Quarterly report on Program management. These three fonns will be completed by each Raion or City TB coordinator, checked by the Oblast coordinator and submitted to the Central Unit where the results will be computerized for easy retrieval and production of analytical reports. 39. These indicators will be verified respectively by the following means: (i) training course participation and trainers' feed-back; (ii) site visits and progress reports by WHO consultants (twice a year); (iii) assessment of the quality of documents produced; (iv) surveillance data sent to WHO; (v) cohort analysis reports sent to WHO. 40. Progress indicators will clearly show whether and where project objectives are being achieved. A quarterly report system will allow to assess the progress of case finding and treatment results.
 122 ANNEX 2.C 41. Loan covenants requiring special attention. To ensure success of the project there must be commitment by the GOK to approve the following conditions: (a) Formalization of the proposed three-level structure of the revitalized National Tuberculosis Program (central, oblast, raion) and approval of the policy package for tuberculosis control prepared by the NTRI based on the following 5 elements; (i) The Kyrgyz Government must be committed to a National Tuberculosis Program aiming at a nation-wide coverage, as a permanent health system activity, better integrated into the existing primary health structure with technical leadership from a strong central unit based at the National Tuberculosis Research Institute in Bishkek. The structure should be appropriate to the country health system and guarantee rational utilization of existing health services; (ii) Case detection through predominantly passive case-finding (i.e., detection of cases which spontaneously present at the health services) ensuring that 3 smears are obtained from every patient with radiologic abnormalities; (iii) Standardized case definitions of all tuberculosis cases, with supervised administration of short-course chemotherapy in, at least, the initial phase for all smear-positive cases; (iv) A system of regular drug supply and adequate stocks of drugs at each level (Central, Oblast, Raion); (v) A standardized recording and reporting system for monitoring case detection and treatment outcomes. (b) In order to ensure adequate case management of tuberculosis patients through the primary health care system, the government should introduce a system of financial incentives for case detection and cure of tuberculosis patients utilizing its own resources (part of them could be derived from savings resulting from ambulatory treatment and abandoning of previous expensive services). Elements of this system are: (i) A 30 som payment to any health worker who originally refers tuberculosis suspects for examination, if the diagnosis of tuberculosis is confirmed by microscopy. (ii) Primary health workers who manage a tuberculosis case will be paid 60 soms at the end of treatment of a smear-positive patient in whom cure is documented. Health workers will be paid 30 soms for the management of smear negative patients after treatment completion. These additional payments, as well as the regular salaries, will be ensured by the Government and paid by the raion health administration on a regular basis. If drug admninistration is not fully supervised in the initial phase, as shown by the treatment cards and registry, payment will not be made. Payment will not be made to the tuberculosis facilities staff and to hospital staff managing hospitalized patients. (c) As the case detection and treatment of tuberculosis patients will become the responsibility of primary health care workers, the GOK should consider reallocating current
 123 ANNEX 2.C tuberculosis specialists from tuberculosis in-patient facilities to primary health care facilities. It will be desirable to have in each facility where major decisions are made on diagnosis and treatment (Raion hospital and/or polyclinic) a tuberculosis specialist who could train and assist primary health care physicians until they acquire adequate knowledge on tuberculosis case management. It is essential that tuberculosis be established as a major topic in the educational curriculum of a primary health care physician and/or feldsher, in view of the larger role they will have in tuberculosis case management. These conditions should be met in order to safely shift from a vertical tuberculosis control program to the one integrated into the primary health care. (d) As ambulatory care seems an adequate and cost-effective manner to provide tuberculosis treatment, two pilot projects before countrywide program implementation should be established to evaluate the feasibility of providing ambulatory treatment during the initial phase of chemotherapy through the primary health care system, as compared to drug administration through hospitalization of all patients. The GOK should be committed to approve fully ambulatory treatment of tuberculosis, if results of the pilot projects demonstrate similarity of treatment outcomes. In addition, the GOK should limit the provision of antituberculosis drugs to the raion coordinators or to institutions directly involved with the tuberculosis program. (e) Study protocols similar to that for pilot project should be prepared by NTRI with the assistance of WHO, and, translated in Russian should be ready by the project effectiveness. All necessary documentation, i.e., treatment cards, registers, and forms should be reproduced and distributed to the areas proposed for implementation in the year 1. 42. ImDlementation plan: The first step towards implementation of the project is government's agreement on the proposed framework for tuberculosis control and on the commitment to support the project. As it is essential to define the operational problems which might arise from a completely new approach to tuberculosis control, pilot projects are necessary which implement the new strategy of tuberculosis control. Two 1-year pilot projects covering each between 100.000 and 150.000 population have been established. Both these projects, expected to cover up to 200 patients in one year, would call for better integration within the existing primary health care system regarding diagnostic procedures and provision of treatment. One project will evaluate treatment results hospitalizing patients during the initial phase of chemotherapy, whereas the other will assess the feasibility of fully ambulatory treatment through primary health care providers. Funding for these projects has been obtained from a separate World Bank grant. These pilot projects began in November, 1995. In order to ensure adequate methodology, pilot project principal coordinators from NTRI were trained on the modem strategy of tuberculosis control during the International Training Course held at the WHO Collaborating Center in Warsaw, Poland on 24-29 April 1995. Travel and accommodation costs were covered by WHO. The training course for selected raion coordinators involved in the pilot project was held in Bishkek in September 1995. The Central Reference Laboratory Coordinator was retrained in smear-microscopy during a course organized by WHO in Tbilisi, Georgia in June 1995. In September 1995 the training course in smear-microscopy for raion laboratory technicians was established in Bishkek. Training tools consisting of standard WHO training modules translated in Russian, WHO treatment guidelines and laboratory manual in Russian were provided by WHO. A protocol for a pilot project of tuberculosis control programs was prepared by the NTRI with the assistance of WHO. This protocol translated in Russian and reproduced, was distributed among the pilot project raions TB coordinators. Registers, treatment cards and report forms were translated in Russian and distributed. Drugs and necessary laboratory equipment were purchased and
 124 ANNEX 2.C stocked by the project coordinators, and will be disbursed gradually during the entire period of pilot project. 43. The results of the pilot projects, as well as the progress of implementation of the new primary health care system, will guide the final choice of diagnostic and treatment policies for the nationwide World Bank assisted project. A detailed project manual will be produced by the central unit with the assistance of WHO. In the first year of the project the oblast of Issyk-kul and Chui and the city of Bishkek will be covered. Before implementation of the full project, a number of training courses will be held. Training tools tested during the pilot projects will be reproduced and distributed. Training of primary health care workers must be particularly intensive in order for them to become acquainted with tuberculosis diagnosis and treatment. In addition, as the decision of enrolment of a patient for treatment will become responsibility of primary health care workers, consideration should be made to reallocate current tuberculosis specialists from tuberculosis in-patient facilities to primary health care. Diagnostic services will be upgraded with necessary equipment and provided with necessary supplies. Procurement and distribution of those will be coordinated by the central unit. The necessary drugs will be purchased and stocked by the project coordinator according to the expected number of cases in each area. Based on the progress of the initial implementation steps, the project will be expanded to the oblast of Naryn and Talas during year 2 and to the rest of the country during year 3.  147 ANNEX 3 KYRGYZ REPUBLIC HEALTH SECTOR REFORM PROJECT ANNEX 3: FACILITIES REHABILITATION COMPONENT A. Introduction 1. The extent and content of facilities in a health infrastructure directly influence quality and efficiency, and thereby the recurrent expenditure required in the health sector. The need for staff, their production capacity, the need for consumables and supplies, maintenance services and energy can all be measured in relationship to the buildings in which services are provided. 2. At present an intense re-evaluation is being made in the Kyrgyz Republic, of the goals, capabilities and responsibilities of the health as well as other public sectors. In particular attempts are being made to address the consequences of the present drastic reduction in available resources. It was therefore that the World Bank in the process of preparing a broad reaching health sector rehabilitation project, included an evaluation of the physical and functional condition of health facilities and equipment, and the frame-work within which the health infrastructure is financed and managed 3. Four missions were undertaken in the periods between 3rd and 19th October 1994, 22nd February to 10th March, 18th June to 11th July and 15th to 31st October 1995. During these missions meetings were held in Bishkek with senior officers in the Ministry of Health, in particular those dealing with the provision of health services, and the management of capital investment. Further meetings were held with leading experts on architecture, capital projects management and equipment procurement. 4. In the October 1994 mission visits were made to the Diagnostic Center, the National TB Institute and the National Dermatology and STD Institute in Bishkek, the Raion Hospital at Kochkor, and various facilities in the Naryn Oblast including the central hospital, the TB center, the Mental Diseases hospital and the Dermatology and STD clinic. 5. In the February and June 1995 missions, health facility sites in the Chui Oblast where emphasis was made on visiting primary health care facilities including raion hospitals, rural hospitals, ambulatory care centers and feldsher/midwife posts (FAP's) 6. The following is a report based on those meetings and visits. Summary of Findings 7. In visiting a number of all types of health institutions in the Kyrgyz republic, the following main problems are apparent: (i) The government is no longer making adequate funds available to pay for running and maintaining buildings, plant and equipment in the health sector, and therefore correct levels of efficiency and quality within the system are becoming increasingly difficult to maintain (ii) A large amount of equipment is not working due to shortages of spare parts and lack of servicing. Further important consumables are in short supply or are not available. These factors seriously detract from the efficiency of the health delivery system.
 148 ANNEX 3 (iii) The present over-provision of health facilities and equipment (working or not working) at all levels, implies that correct financing of their use will require resources which at present are not available (iv) Any introduction of new health programs aimed at improving efficiency in the provision of services will often imply changes in the use of existing facilities, in some cases also implying changes to the facilities themselves. (v) Very few norms and standards for health facilities have been formulated which relate to the present situation. (vi) Administrators of health facilities are not well trained in estates management. They are given very little support when introducing technical changes to their buildings and plant (such as installing new heating systems, or when implementing changes or trying to achieve savings. (vii) Though originally there was apparently a well functioning hierarchy of technical and administrative expertise available to support MOH capital investment activities, including MOH staff and sister ministry's architects, engineers and builders, this is no longer easy to assemble. Further, although the Ministry of Health's office for Capital Investments is still operating, though with a negligible work-load, the Ministry's Central Office for Maintenance has been completely disbanded. (viii) The Ministry of Health has no overview of the buildings, plant estates etc, which constitute the health service infrastructure. It is not able to make overall plans and priorities for realignment activities. 8. Where improvements are required to the efficiency and quality of health services provided in the country in the existing health infrastructure, it is extremely difficult for the Ministry to implement the changes required which will facilitate these. 9. A significant reorganization is required within the Ministry of Health in order to re-orientate present technical expertise on the repair, rehabilitation and reutilization of existing structures and plant. That is to say to move away for the development of completely new and totally unnecessary capital investment projects. 10. In this new concept the Ministry will require tools to create an adequate organization, to collect the necessary information and to implement the correct policies. It is suggested that the World Bank project, through implementing limited constructional works in connection with the implementation of its health reform project, could contribute significantly to helping the Ministry to develop these tools. B. Background 11. The health service system in the Kyrgyz republic is based on a very comprehensive infra-structure of health facilities at all levels, which in spite of the country's difficult topological characteristics, provides good access to the system for most members of the population. 12. The health facilities include central hospitals, district hospitals, polyclinics, feldsher/midwife stations, village ambulatory stations, as well as special separate institutions for tuberculosis,
 149 ANNEX 3 dermatology/sexually transmitted diseases. Together they provide a very wide range of services for both out patients and in-patients, with an extensive portfolio of medical equipment and a large total of beds Quality of the Health Infrastructure 13. Usually planned on large open sites, the facilities making up the health infrastructure are generally of very substantial construction with thick masonry walls both internally and externally and with heavy reinforced concrete floors. Carpentry- and joinery work is also generally very substantially dimensioned, though electrical and plumbing installations are usually of poor quality and less than adequate in terms of the numbers and quality of installations and fittings. 14. Generally the buildings reflect the quality of provision found in all other public buildings in the country and no attempt has been made to pinch and save. However it is considered surprising that in an environment with relatively extreme temperatures, passive means of energy conservation through the improvement of insulation, -particularly in floors, ceilings and roofs, do not seem to have been given very much attention Central Health Institutes 15. The central health institutes located in Bishkek, as typified by the Diagnostic Center and the National Tuberculosis Center appear openly to have been establish on a 'no expense spared' concept. These buildings are very impressive, in the case of the TB institute, almost flamboyant. There have apparently been several approaches from different governments with a view to purchasing the hospital to convert into an Embassy. 16. Though still apparently functioning satisfactorily, there is evidence that both these institutes are beginning to deteriorate functionally through a lack of routine maintenance and absence of spare parts. The initial solution here is the injection of large amounts of finance which obviously is not available, before the whole financing of the sector has been reorganized. 17. It could also be relevant to encourage these institutes to pool the technical expertise that they individually have access to and at the same time to carefully evaluate the appropriateness of the technology that they use. It is suggested that any infusion of capital in present conditions would not achieve any sustainable improvements. Hospitals 18. The hospitals are usually made up of a large number of individual departments. A relatively small hospital with less than 400 beds, usually has separate self-contained departments for Urology, Pulmonary /gastroenterology, Surgery, Trauma, Resuscitation, Ophthalmology, Paediatrics, Cardiology, Infectious diseases. 19. On the same site there is also usually a polyclinic containing units reflecting all these departmnents, as well as a multi-disciplinary veterans hospital. On separate sites will often be located independent institutions for obstetrics and gynecology, TB, dermatology and STD and psychiatric patients. 20. It is suggested that this ensconcement of the departments in independent units does not easily support modem coordinated nursing and treatment methods. It is also noted that there is very little cross- utilization of equipment and facilities between departments, even when they are located in the same building.
 150 ANNEX 3 21. Generally space standards in hospitals are low and the rooms in the buildings are small in relationship to the activities which go on there. 22. Operating theater rooms are usually adequate in size, though many of the necessary secondary rooms such as utility rooms, sterile set up rooms, duty rooms and change rooms for staff are missing. 23. In the ward sections, rooms for in-patients often contain 8-9 beds, where there is only reasonable space for 4-6 beds, and often other important rooms, (such as utility rooms, ward stores, patients and staff toilets, bath rooms, staff duty rooms and patient day rooms) are either under-dimensioned or missing. Rural Hospitals 24. There appears to be two distinct types of rural hospitals in the regions visited. One is the 'Blenheim Palace' type of building, with very heavy two story structure with often very elaborate ornamentation in the form of columns, porticos and plinths. Usually containing as few as 30 in-patient beds they are very inflexible in use. They are also very expensive to heat. In future use it is very difficult to conceive what the upper story can successfully be utilized for. 25. The other type of building is a one story rural type structure which is infinitely more appropriate and flexible. These buildings lend themselves considerably more readily to the changes in function being suggested 26. The rural hospitals contain suites of different types of consultation rooms, for general medicine, surgery, gynecology, dentistry and rehabilitation. Further there are often well equipped delivery suites and operating rooms. Wards are usually very cramped. Throughout the buildings toilet, sanitary and utility facilities are very minimal, and important functions are missing. 27. A present large numbers of staff seem to be dealing with comparatively small numbers of patients Health Centers 28. Generally the health centers visited were reasonably well planned, with well dimensioned spaces and adequate numbers of item of equipment and furniture. However conditions varied and the structural problems seen, usually the result of leaking roofs, appear to be increasing. Equipment and furniture were also generally in poor condition. 29. Health centers generally seem to be still very well staffed, with usually 2 to 3 general clinicians, as well as pediatricians, gynecologists and dentists. However the total 10-15 staff which appear to be present at most health centers do not appear to be overflooded with patients, a staff to patient ratio of 1 to between 4 and 6 being typical on a daily basis. FAP'S 30. These are usually small buildings where a limited staff of a nurse and a midwife carry out something comparable to a district nursing function on behalf of a small local population. These buildings with 3-4 rooms are usually domestic in character, with few installations and little equipment. 31. The neatness and cleanliness of these units was always impressive and on the basis of present functions, there does not appear any need for technical or financial support.
 151 ANNEX 3 Health Facility Design 32. There are many details of design in the institutions which were visited, which are not considered appropriate for health buildings. For example; no effort is made to ease access to buildings, rooms, toilets, etc., for patients on wheeled stretchers or wheel chairs, trolleys, or any other wheeled transport or carrying vehicles. Door widths and the positions of doors do not give good access to buildings and rooms; There are not sufficient hand wash basins in ward rooms and procedure rooms for staff to be able to wash their hands between dealing with patients; and floor coverings, wall finishes, design and installation of sanitary fittings, etc., do not easily facilitate the maintenance of correct conditions of hygiene. Installations 33. Heating installations, electrical and sanitary reticulations and fittings, drainage and sewage disposal facilities, are not always adequate. Further there appears to be no attempt to conserve energy. 34. Hot water is not readily available in any areas of the institutions. 35. Electrical reticulations appear very basic. Electrical fittings, such as socket outlets, switches etc., are often damaged, indicating that they are not strong enough for use in public buildings. 36. Sanitary fittings are usually very inadequate. They are difficult to keep clean, and in many institutions large amounts of water is allowed to run to waste due to the lack of simple maintenance to sanitary fittings and to the water reticulation. 37. Refuse disposal seems mostly well organized, both sites and buildings seem to be efficiently cleared of refuse and litter. The exceptions here appear to be the central hospitals in Bishkek. Medical Equipment 38. Inspection of a limited number of facilities suggests that at present there is an adequate number of items of equipment of all different types, which with correct redistribution where problems have occurred, will in most cases be sufficient to reasonably satisfy requirements over the coming period. 39. However the situation with spare parts is in many cases very acute, in particular as the total lack of maintenance and thereby lack of use of the items of equipment involved will quickly lead to total dilapidation, and the destruction of valuable resources. 40. During the inspections it was observed that in many institutions, there were no autoclaves available or functioning, and instruments and syringes required for patient procedures were usually 'sterilized' in ovens. It is very doubtful whether this treatment is adequate. There was also observed an acute shortage of surgical instruments and syringes. Supplies 41. There is now an acute shortage of all types of software, such as mattresses, pillows, bed linen, covers and uniforms, medical supplies such as bandages, syringes and utensils and consumable, such as x-ray film, chemicals and reagents and filters etc., as well as all forms of detergents and cleaning solutions. All contribute significantly in reducing the quality of the activities taking place in the
 152 ANNEX 3 institutions, and also increasing efficiency. In particular the shortages of consumables seriously inhibit the satisfactory functioning of services provided at the institutions. 42. These problems require urgent attention and action. Maintenance 43. Though there are standard allotments in the recurrent budgets for the different health institutions to pay for maintenance, these monies have not during the last three years, been made available. The Ministry of Health has further closed down its central maintenance department and in effect the concept of providing maintenance for buildings and equipment outside the Bishkek area has mainly been discontinued, at least until finance is again made available. 44. It is recommended that in spite of the extreme shortage of resources for maintenance, a policy is established by MOH on appropriate and feasible (possible) maintenance for health institutions. Management of Buildings and Estates 45. In the question of the management of health building complexes, in providing equipment and furniture to the different rooms, in ensuring that cleaning procedures are correct and adequate, in carrying out maintenance and in making adaptations to existing plant and facilities, (for example when adapting heating systems for changes of fuel), the managers of health institutions do not seem to be getting adequate technical support for their decisions. 46. Managers of health institutions should be correctly instructed regarding different aspects of the management of buildings and grounds of health facilities. They should be informed of correct procedures for carrying out the various necessary procedures. They should also be provided with qualified technical support for decision making, design, ordering and implementation. 47. At central level the previously well functioning hierarchy of Ministry technicians, consulting architects and engineers, appears to have been disbanded through lack of work. Members of the MANAS project group have been assigned this area of interest but there is still urgent need to reconstitute a qualified forum of technical expertise. 48. This should not be too difficult, as it has existed previously. The difficulty may now relate to the changed status of individual architects and engineers who previously provided technical guidance but who now consider that their input should be correctly financed. 49. It should be relatively simple to solve the financial problems. If civil works are carried out in the project and are eligible for containing with Local Competitive Bidding, it will be necessary to include in budgets for paying fees to local private consultants. Their activities in developing the documentation required for carrying out the projects should also allow for them participating actively as consultants to the MOH civil works advisory committee. Norms and Standards for Health Facilities 50. The MOH civil works advisory committee should also be the forum where relevant building space and quality norms are determined for health facilities in the Kyrgyz Republic. This would apply both for the evaluation and effective utilization and also repair of existing buildings, as well as the formulation long term budgets and investment plans for future constructions.
 153 ANNEX 3 Building Costs 51. Due to the apparent lack of recent examples of completed health facility construction in the Kyrgyz Republic, the local architects and quantity surveyors did not feel able to give precise rates for different types of building construction activities. However rough figures were given and in this respect it was agreed that it would be appropriate (in view of the imminent (though limited) activities being now considered), that a price system should be established and developed, in order that in the near future reasonably accurate and transparent / adaptable / escalatable estimates can be made. Rationale for Bank Involvement 52. The Bank emphasizes strongly the need to iniprove efficiency in the delivery of health services in the Kyrgyz Republic and, through concentrating on essentially primary health care programs, emphasizes the potential for reorganizing activities from being essentially in-patient orientated, to be essentially out-patient orientated. 53. Improvement of Primary Health Care facilities will naturally improve the status and acceptability of the services provided there to the population. 54. The results which can be achieved through improving the effectiveness of different medical programs, will be reinforced by systematic efforts made improve functional and hygienic conditions in the health infra-structure to ensure that the necessary improvements in efficiency are achieved. 55. Further benefits which can be a result of including civil works activities in the various sub- components of this project is that it will be possible to influence the way in which the Ministry of Health administers hospitals and other health buildings and their grounds. It will further encourage a greater readiness to consider the recurrent costs effects of buildings and equipment, it will demonstrate the potential for carrying out maintenance on minimal budgets, it will show how existing buildings can be utilized reducing the need for new ones and it will involve different disciplines in a collaboration to determine relevant norms and standards for use in the Kyrgyz Republic. C. Activities Related to the Health Infrastructure 56. Any effort to reduce the recurrent costs requirement for the health sector will imply significant changes in the health service infrastructure. There are many possible strategies for this, all requiring carefully planned and implemented programs. However it is recommended that future health programs and activities should have the following main aims: (i) To reduce the extent of the health services delivery system 57. This implies setting precise targets for future provision. (For example aiming to limit the numbers of beds available in health institutions to 8 beds per 1000 population) 58. These targets can be achieved by a number of means, including closing wards at lower level institutions, by closing departments and by reducing the number of beds in individual wards, and by reducing the average length of stay of in-patients in wards. This in turn can be achieved by improving functional and hygienic conditions and thereby increasing efficiency at the institutions. (That is to say that if all equipment is in working order and that there are sufficient drugs, reagents, X-ray film etc., and if risks of cross-infection are kept a minimum and if the care programs aim to shorten the average length of stay... .etc.).
 154 ANNEX 3 (ii) To rationalize high technology within the health delivery system 59. This can be achieved by concentrating surgical and specialized services at facilities at Raion level, and also by evaluating carefully the distribution of equipment and installations to the lower levels. (iui) To improve the efficient use of energy and promote the concept of enviromnental protection 60. This can be achieved by introducing more economical heating systems which will also provide water heating, by implementing water conservation and commodity material (eg. medical gasses) conserving measures. (iv) To reintroduce appropriate maintenance services for both buildings and equipment 61. This can be supported by establishing 'requirements for maintenance' as important procurement criteria, and by the development of information systems for planning and administering maintenance. The establishment of appropriate maintenance services can in the long term only be achieved by making funds available through economies in other areas. (v) To inprove the overall management of the health infrastructure 62. This can be supported by the development of app.opriate norms and standards for use in health facility planning and evaluation. The norms would cover spacial provision norms , utilization criteria, specification standards for materials and installations. It could further be supported by the development and implementation of an information collecting system for providing data on the extent and condition of facilities in the health service infrastructure. 63. It should be emphasized that considerable more resources are used in hospitals and that the potential in this sector for making savings is considerably greater. This fact in itself motivates for not only focusing on Primary health. COMPONENT ELEMENTS 64. It can be anticipated that it will take a number of years to achieve the above goals, much longer than the anticipated duration of the project. However, it is important to address the whole question of the relationship of the Kyrgyz health infrastructure, its buildings, installations and equipment, to the quality and efficiency of health services and thereafter to the recurrent costs required to finance those services 65. The following activities would be included in the project and where possible integrated into the various project components which are being proposed: (a) Carrying out pilot construction and procurement activities in connection with project components. Essentially this will involve converting rural hospitals into polyclinics , upgrading ambulatory centers and providing the equipment and supplies necessary to ensure efficient performance. (b) The training of technicians and administrators at all levels in estates management, (c) Development of norms and standards together with local experts,
 155 ANNEX 3 (d) Development and implementation of information system for collecting data on health facilities and for making masterplans for future development, ANTICIPATED ACHEVEMENTS FROM THE INPUTS 66. The results which can be anticipated from the input being proposed are as follows: 67. In connection with programs being proposed in the project for the improvement of services, in particular within the concept of primary care, Civil works and procurement activities will be carried out as a basis for ensuring the successful implementation of the new services. Here in almost every case works will concern the adaptation of existing facilities, and it is anticipated that the Ministry of Health will here be able to obtain practical experience of the various (for them new) concepts being promoted. 'Reuse of existing structures', 'appropriate technology', 'user participation', 'energy conservation', 'estates management', will be concepts which it is anticipated will be demonstrated as essential for incorporating in future work in connection with the health infrastructure of the Kyrgyz health services. 68. As a consequence of the preparatory and development work necessary as a normal part of the project development process for the above civil works and procurement activities, 'Estates management' will be developed as an important concept which influences the efficient utilization of health facilities. Using the norms and standards described below and participating in the implementation in the project of an agreed information collection system, MOH managers will automatically be given a greater insight into the means available to solve problems concerning the maintenance and development of the buildings and plant under their supervision. Further in the procurement and contract management activities relating to the project, it is aimed to effectively utilize resources available at local level. This is also anticipated to fturther contribute to providing a basis for improving the performance of local managers in estates management 69. In order to carry out the intended civil works and equipment procurement activities it will be necessary to develop in collaboration with Kyrgyz experts, appropriate Norms and Standards for evaluating, planning, rehabilitating and constructing health facilities will be established. Generally these norms will always refer to the present shortage of resources, and will strive to relate to accepted concepts of appropriateness, and economy in use. The norms and standards will hopefully form the basis for all future activities concerning the health infrastructure and will influence activities by both the government and donors, influencing decisions which will be appropriate and sustainable. 70. In the same way Masterplans will be developed to provide information of the condition and content of the health facilities which will be the subjects of project activity. In this way the Ministry of Health will be provided with a simple system for collecting comparable data on the scope and quality of all facilities within the health infrastructure and at the same time a basis will be provided with tools for making priorities and assessing the feasibility of making changes. 71. The results of the project activities therefore are anticipated also to influence utilization and costs in the secondary and tertiary health sectors. D. Infrastructure Objectives 72. The main objective of this activity is to make repairs and functional changes required at raion level health service facilities and provide specific items of equipment and consumables which will ensure
 156 ANNEX 3 that the correct conditions are available for both existing activities as well as for supporting the implementation of new and revised programs 73. A secondary objective is that through the development of the brief, in establishing norms and standards, in developing routines for contracting and administration, in collecting data required for these works, the Ministry of Health will be provided with a basis for improving its own Estates Management and for defining the appropriate content and emphases for future rehabilitation projects. Main Features 74. The main feature of the activities proposed is the emphasis made on involvement of MOH/Kyrgyz expertise, in order to ensure that the results attained are both appropriate and acceptable to local needs and thereby are sustainable. Requirements from the Ministry of Health 75. The Ministry of Health would establish an appropriate policy with regards capital investments and the management health infrastructure. It would acknowledge that every increase in buildings and plant will imply unacceptable recurrent costs implications. The Ministry has already today many more square meters of buildings than it requires to provide its different services, and the theme in future should be acknowledged to be 'consolidate' 'rehabilitate', 'reuse', if possible 'decommission', rather than 'new construction' and 'expansion'. 76. New policy would therefore emphasize a complete freeze on the construction of new health facilities and would indicate that investments and civil works activities should concentrate through repair maintenance and adaption, on attaining maximum efficiency and appropriate functional quality in existing structures. 77. The organization of the Ministry's civil works administration would reflect this change of emphasis, and present Ministry officers would have their Descriptions of Employment amended accordingly. 78. It is further desirable that the Ministry would establish advisory committees and stakeholder groups, in order to receive technical support in matters dealing with both civil works activities and the procurement and maintenance of medical equipment. The stakeholder groups are small communities of users--both health authorities and local government officials, established at each facility to be rehabilitated/upgraded. The work of the group will be to provide information as required on functional problems and requirements, and to approve the proposals made for improvements and alterations. In this way it is anticipated that the results of the investments will be better appreciated by local staff and users, and log term aims regarding increased efficiency and quality will more easily be attained. Needs for Rehabilitation of Facilities 79. During the June/July 1995 mission a MOH/World Bank team carried out surveys at 27 selected health facilities. Though mainly concentrating on ambulatory centers and rural hospitals which are agreed will be the subject of the activities financed by the project, comprehensive data was also collected at Raion Hospitals, District Hospitals etc., where it was considered that conditions were particularly acute, and where it was anticipated that considerable savings could be made in recurrent costs requirements through the consolidation and functional decondition of individual buildings.
 157 ANNEX 3 Results of the Inspections 80. The result of the inspections is that more detailed information has been obtained on the actual condition of a reasonable number of health facilities in one Oblast, and the requirements which exist for rebuilding, renovation and refurbishing in order to provide conditions which are acceptable. Evaluation of conditions at the different facilities has been based on assessment of two main factors, FUNCTIONAL QUALITY considered in terms of OPERATIONAL EFFICIENCY. 81. Observations confirm that in these areas there are a lot of improvements which should be made. Especially that: (i) There are too many facilities (Provision norms,-beds, clinics, staff, are high, utilization and productivity is low. Departments are over-institutionalized, there is no flexibility) (ii) Hygienic conditions are very poor (Wards are very cramped, toilet facilities limited, working conditions for staff are poor, important equipment (such as sterilizing equipment etc..) is not functioning, materials for cleaning is in short supply, staff are often badly motivated). (iii) Functional conditions are very poor (Shortages of working equipment, physical separation of relating departments, lack of consunumables, etc.) (iv) Equipment and buildings are in bad repair (Equipment and buildings often are too difficult or too costly to maintain. Resources for maintenance are not available, maintenance is giving low priority by administrators) (v) Running costs are far too high (Over provision of facilities and amenities as mentioned above. Further heating systems are often extremely expensive to run and maintain. Many district heating systems have above-ground-none-insulated pipe reticulations which may be contributing to atmospheric overheating but waste fuel and are not adequately heating the buildings). 82. The implication of the surveys therefore is that it is easily apparent that refurbishment work is required at all institutions, possibly with the exception of the FAP's. However it would be very wrong for this or any other project to merely repair and repaint the facilities in their present form without making an effort to correct the serious faults which have been observed which seriously detract from the quality and efficiency with which services are provided, thereby incurring unreasonably high recurrent costs. 83. The costings included for the proposals made include for required functional changes. However at this stage the detail of the provision still must be defined and agreed designs and specifications are finally issued. 84. Attached are illustrative drawings and specifications for three representative facilities; a raion hospital, polyclinic, and health center. A complete set is in the project's working papers.
