 175 ANNEX 4 KYRGYZ REPUBLIC HEALTH SECTOR REFORM PROJECT ANNEX 4: MEDICAL CARE PROVIDER PAYMENT COMPONENT A. Background 1. The Kyrgyz Republic's health financing and delivery system reflects -- to a relatively large extent -- the old regime of rational planning and hierarchic structure found throughout the former Soviet Union health system.' Historically, the system has been financed in a centralized "top-down" bureaucratic allocation process, based upon national budgets formulated and passed by the central legislative and policy-making bodies. 2. The health financing system has been beset by two significant issues, however, related to sources of funds and uses of funds. The first is that allocated budget levels historically have tended toward chronic underfunding. The old Soviet system allocated funds for health protection on a "residual" basis from general tax revenues; levels of funds were determnined only after budgets were allocated for other "productive" sectors such as industry, manufacturing, and defense. Over the last several years, national independence and the general economic decline has exacerbated the issue of underfunding. Independence from the Soviet Union has forced self-sufficiency for the Republic which historically enjoyed a positive net transfer of resources from Moscow through the tax system (World Bank, 1992). The economic decline that the Kyrgyz Republic (and most other parts of the NIS) has suffered over the past several years has resulted in reduced tax revenues being generated locally. An emerging funding crisis in health services has been the result. 3. The share of the region's GDP devoted to health historically has been low, and also erratic since the 1980s--falling from 6% of GDP to just over 3% for the New Independent States (NIS) as a whole. In the Kyrgyz Republic, spending as a percent of GDP was 4.1 % in 1990, but has fallen for 3 of the last four years. Schieber (World Bank, 1995) reports that the most complete information available is for public spending including spending from the consolidated budget (including all Ministries not just the MOH), extra-budgetary public expenditures on health, and enterprise spending on health. The ratio of public health expenditures to GDP declined from 4.2% of GDP in 1990 to 2.6% in 1993, with an increase to 3.6% in 1994. The GDP in 1994 is only 50% of the 1990 level. Similarly, 1994 real (GDP deflator adjusted) health expenditures are only 46 % of the 1990 level, up from 40% of the 1990 level in 1993. In short, there has been a 50% reduction in real output in the Kyrgyz Republic since 1990, accompanied by a 54% reduction in real public health spending.2 4. Schieber (World Bank, 1995) further found the picture even more bleak when per person spending is converted into U.S. dollars using purchasing power parities (i.e., exchange rates which adjust for cost of living differences across countries). Public budget health spending in the Kyrgyz Republic in 1993 dropped to only one-fourth the 1990 level. I Each individual in urban areas is assigned to a polyclinic and has a primary care physician (not a general practitioner, but a therapist, pediatrician, or obstetrician/gynecologist); in rural areas, there is a basic health unit, called a FAP, of one or more physician-extenders (e.g., feldshers or nurses), and rural ambulatory centers. 2 According to Abel-Smith (1994), there has been a fall in output of the industrial sector of 50 per cent, and a drop in export revenue by 65 per cent between 1991 and the end of 1993. Between 1992 and 1993, there was a decline in real GDP by 16 per cent and tax revenue fell from 14 per cent of GDP to 8 per cent. The economy has further suffered from hyperinflation. Retail prices have been rising by 15-25 per cent a month.
 176 ANNEX 4 5. A second problem with the former Soviet approach to health care delivery is that it does not encourage the efficient use of resources by providers or between them. This was due in part to a system which allocated resources based on traditional central planning production input measures, such as occupancy and numbers of staff and beds, rather than services performed, relative complexity of services, or changes in health status. Schieber (World Bank, 1995) reports that recent trends are somewhat encouraging, but overall numbers suggest a system that remains bloated. The number of beds per 1,000 population has declined from 12 in 1981 to 9.5 in 1994, but is still some 15 percent above the OECD average. Similarly, while hospital admissions rates have declined from 25 percent of the population being admitted in 1987 to 18 percent in 1994, the Kyrgyz Republic is still 20 percent above the OECD average. The average length of hospital stay has declined by about one day over the past 15 years to 15.6 days in 1994, but remains slightly above the 14 day OECD average. The average number of inpatient days of care per year per person has declined from 3.6 days in 1978 to 2.8 in 1994, but is still some 15 percent above the OECD average. The hospital occupancy has declined from 90 percent in 1978 to 81 percent in 1994, compared to an OECD average of 75 percent. 6. The number of physicians per 1,000 population has increased by some 30 percent over the past 15 years to reach 3.1 in 1994 (of which 0.45 are dentists), somewhat above the OECD average of 2.2. Only 35 percent are generalists (defined to include therapists, pediatricians, and obstetricians), whereas the percent share in many OECD countries (excluding the U.S.) is closer to 50 (e.g., United Kingdom) to 70 percent (e.g., Canada). The number of physician contacts per year is comparable to the high utilization rates in the OECD countries. 7. There are other health financing sector problems as well including an acute shortage of pharmaceuticals, equipment, and supplies.3 These shortages have occurred partly at the expense of an overemphasis of resources placed in staff and beds. Facility budgets based on production input measures such as beds provide incentives to increase capacity. A high level of facility capacity within the system results in high fixed costs. This problem has worsened over the last few years with the deregulation of energy prices, exacerbated by inefficient heating systems. For example, in Issyk-kul Oblast utilities consume approximately 30% of total costs. For small rural hospitals the problem is even worse, utilities consume approximately 67 % of total costs. The decrease in financing and an increase in the proportion of expenses allocated to fixed costs have combined to produce critical shortages and depletion of inventory levels in pharmaceuticals, equipment, and supplies. B. Current Flow of Funds for Health Care 8. The health sector is financed (at least formally) from general taxation revenues. In general, the responsibility of collecting general taxes has devolved over the last few years to the oblasts and rayons, not the central government. At the same time, the scope and authority to tax remains inflexible and is largely determined by the central govermnent. Once collected, money is either passed on to the central Ministry of Finance or kept at the individual oblast level depending upon the central allocation formulas. In some cases, the oblast receives additional subsidies beyond the general taxation base. Currently, Bishkek and Chui pass along some of their revenues to the central goverrnent, while two oblasts -- Osh and Djal Abad -- keep what they have collected. The remaining oblasts -- Naryn, Talas, and Issyk-Kul - - receive central government subsidies in addition to what they collect. Shortages mentioned specifically include anesthetics, X-ray plates, surgical supplies, food for patients, gasoline for ambulances, fuel for heating water and even sheets. There is often no replacement or repair of equipment needing spare parts. Equipment includes ambulances, incubators, respiratory equipment, autoclaves and washing machines. Schieber (1995) nicely summarizes the pharmaceuticals problem.

The allocation or disbursement of funds works in a parallel fashion, with the central government developing allocation norms across and within sectors, while the actual budget process has generally devolved to the oblast and rayon levels. 10. A recent Bank study (May 1995) by Helga Muller found that in 1994 oblast and local governments collected 84 percent of the health expenditure. The report suggests that while it makes sense to delegate social programs to a subnational level, that there is increasing inequities across oblasts in terms of revenues raised versus needs for social programs. Per capita public health spending varied by 1.7:1 across oblasts in the Kyrgyz Republic in 1994, but the report implies increased variations could occur over time. The study recommends that the central government should mandate minimum service levels and develop allocation formulas for critical expenditures in health in order to better equalize fiscal capacity with actual collections as well as to better match collections versus actual needs and demands for services. 11. Within the health sector itself, there are four levels of disbursement of funds for facilities. The first level is comprised of the Republican institutions, designed to serve the whole population and generally highly specialized. At the second level the six oblasts and Bishkek city operate institutions of a mixed primary and specialized nature, open to all citizens within the oblast. Each oblast is further subdivided into rayons which operate primary care facilities, and local and district hospitals -- largely for rural areas. After fourth sentence, add sentence: Finally, within the oblast, municipalities also operate primary care facilities and hospitals, largely for urban residents. The central Kyrgyz Ministry of Finance does allocate funds directly towards budgets for the national specialty facilities or the Republican institutions. The central government also allocate budgets directly for medical education and research, and more traditional public health activities.5 About six percent of the federal budget is earmarked for certain pre-determined health care activities such as public health. 12. The Ministry of Finance also sets expenditure norms for oblast and rayon level administrations. With these norms, individual facilities at the oblast and rayon levels develop proposed budgets. For inpatient facilities, the norms include nominal numbers of beds and senior medical personnel. For outpatient facilities, the norms are based on capacity as measured by numbers of physicians and "potential" numbers of visits. Budgets are reviewed and approved by local oblast and rayon finance administrations, after consultation with facilities, the local ministries of health, and the local exchequer office. The budgets are handed down in 18 restrictive budget categories such as salary, utilities, and pharmaceuticals. Traditionally, funds could not be spent outside of categories, though there are reports A good example is the recent Presidential Decree on the Budget for the First Quarter of 1995 (dated January 25, 1995) which states that 'the size of allocations to the local budgets of provinces and Bishkek city in the following amounts: o from the VAT tax on Osh, Issyk-Rul, Naryn, Talas, Jalal-Abad provinces - 100 percent; on Chui province 42 percent, on Bishkek city 22 percent; o from the excise tax on Osb, Issyk-Kul, Naryn, Talas, Jalal-Abad provinces -- 100 percent, on Chui province 42 percent, on Bishkek city 23 percent; o from the profit tax on enterprises, incorporation, and organizations on all forms of ownership on Osh, Issyk-Kul, Naryn, Talas provinces -- 100 percent; on Jalal-Abad province, 31.8 percent. Chui province 42 percent, on Bishkek city 23 percent; o from the tax on tumover in retail trade and service to the population on Osh, Issyk-Kul, Naryn, Talas, Jalal-Abad provinces -- 100 percent; on Chui province 42 percent, on Bishkek city 23 percent." However, there is also anecdotal evidence that the implementation of the Treasury system has acted to further restrict the flexibility of facilities to allocate funds outside the budget categories. 13. Local and oblast budgets are aggregated and returned to the central Ministry of Finance which uses them to develop a tax plan to match expected revenue and spending.6 The central Ministry of Finance then informs the oblast administrations of the final approval for public spending levels with a recommendation (but not a necessary condition) for allocation between the sectors (Haycock, 1995). This means that spending patterns between local sectors can be altered (for fiscal, political or other reasons), though discussions with oblast and rayon leaders in other parts of the NIS suggest the shifts are minor and infrequent (see Schieber, Back-to-Office Report, February 1995). C. Recent Reforms 14. The Kyrgyz Government proposed a series of health sector reforms, including the Health Protection Act which was passed and signed into law in July 1992. The Health Protection Act calls for a shift in priorities toward health promotion and disease prevention policies and a new emphasis on primary and family-based care. It calls for changes in the form of property - conversion of pharmacies and pharmaceutical institutions into private and joint-stock companies; conversion of medical institutions into joint-stock companies; incentives to establish private hospitals, polyclinics, and physician practice; and private pay and leasing arrangements within public facilities. 15. The law provides for diversification and decentralization of sources of revenue as well. Financing of health care can be moved "off-budget", and no longer be solely reliant on general government revenues. At least one public health insurance fund ("Territorial Health Insurance Fund' -- or "THIF") can be created in each oblast, to be financed through multiple sources of revenue.' Additional sources of revenue include private or "voluntary" health insurance coverage, local user fees for pharnaceuticals and outpatient services,8 and donor funding. 16. More importantly, the recent legislation separates financing and payment for services from the I For example, the Prsidential Decree on the Budget for the First Quarter of 1995 (dated January 25, 1995) stated that the income tax 'levied from the citizens by enterprises, institudons, and organizations in Chui province in the size of 58 percent and in Bishkek city 78 percent.' ' Sources of revenue include: o funds from the current 34.5% Social Insurance and Pension Fund payroll tax, which are currently used for payment of temporary and permanent disability, social security, other forms of cash assistance, and health. (Approximately 86% of the payroll tax is used for sick leave, pregnancy, adoption of children, child care up to 3 years of age, care of disabled children up to 14 years, sanitoria and resort smy entitlements of from 18-24 days per year per worker. The remaining 14% is used for "other purposes".) o a new, minimum 6% payroll contribution paid by employers; o a capitated rate paid by the oblast govermment into the fund to cover non-working and exempted populations not contribudng through the employer payroll - emnployees of "public budget organizations" (e.g., schools and hospitals), elderly, unemployed, disabled, women and children. While the payments would continue to be made by the oblast government, actual source of funding would be split about 75%/25% between revenues raised by the oblast and central government. The oblast government would also continue to allocate funds directly to hospitals and clinics for construction/capital improvements, expensive equipment, and education/training programs. The central government would continue support of medical education and research, and more traditional public health activities. While this funding approach decentralizes decision making, it also raises concems about perpetuating or exacerbating inequities in funding across individual oblasts (see Haycock, 1995). Third-party payers of services act as a catalyst for the prudent purchase of care on behalf of individual consumers, by changing the incentives faced by hospitals, polyclinics, and individual providers.9 17. Likewise, administrators could receive payments based on the number of cases, the severity of the case, and the performance of treatment. These payment changes would create incentives that encourage more efficient organization and management of service delivery and improved quality of the care. The focus of care could shift toward primary and outpatient care. Polyclinic and hospital administrators would have increased flexibility to utilize resources as they see fit to produce services efficiently. Public sector providers now provide the bulk of services, though private sector providers could compete to provide services. 18. Payment changes are consistent with donor organization recommendations over the last few years. Bobodilla and Ellis (World Bank, 1992), for example, called for incentive-based payment systems to replace the current budgeting approaches. Abel-Smith (1993) and Holmes (June 1994 Manas Conference) have called for capitation-based physician payments and bulk-billing arrangements for inpatient care. 19. The insurance reform law was originally written to be implemented in 1993. Concerns about its design and rapid implementation schedule, as well as problems with reforms in other sectors (e.g., the banking system) and general lack of technical expertise have delayed the implementation date several times since."' Other health sector changes have occurred. Most notably, direct payments for outpatient services and for outpatient pharmaceuticals have been introduced. Haycock (1995) notes that current law prohibits users fees for inpatient services. Nevertheless, there is a sizable base of anecdotal evidence (e.g., discussions with hospital administrators) indicating user fees are applied to inpatient services. Patients also frequently must provide their own food, drugs and consumables for inpatient stays." The recent United Nations Development Program (UNDP) report (1995) found that user fees account for an increasing and sometimes majority portion of revenues for some facilities. More troubling is the recent ODA survey showing that user fees are both increasing rapidly but also affecting economically vulnerable Importantly. the reform law generally follows an approach familiar to NIS countries that stems from initiates strting in 1989 when the so-clled New Economic Mechanisms (NEM) were announced as approved in Moscow under the former Soviet structure. The NEM provided for greater local autonomy and a number of demonstration sites in each of the republics. For example, Kemnerovo, Kaluga. Samira, and St. Petersburg were demonstration sites in the Russian Federation. Three areas of change were focused on: o restructuring of financing -- health budgets would be developed differendy. A formula of 18 production input categories was replaced by a stndard per capita payment based on a mix of measures of resource use and historic trends; o organization and management restructuring - through greater autonomy and management systems; o improved internal efficiency in the delivery of care - through improved payments for services within nd across facilities. The NEM demonstration sites were cancelled or superseded by subsequent health insurance laws in Russia and other NIS countries, but the general principles of NEM took root in terms of the recognition of the need for greater flexibility of resource aflocation, payment to personnel and some limited management restructuring approaches. These activities point to a health sector in transition in the Kyrgyz Republic, moving from a publicly-based central planning scheme to a more privatized, public/private mix in the organization and financing of care. At the same time, these activities are incremental and may have unintended consequences for efficiency and access to care. As a result, the government decided to test its legislated financing and delivery system reform model as a way of implementing a more comprehensive strategy for change. While implementation of its 1992 law is still delayed, it has chosen to pilot test the model in at least one geographic area, Issyk-kul Oblast. 21. Problem: The health care system in the Kyrgyz Republic is dominated by the hospital sector, which consumes more than 70% of resources. One reason for this inefficient allocation of resources is the financial incentives for facilities contained in the current line item budgeting system. The budgeting system is based on input measures such as number of beds and staff, and rewards increases in capacity rather than the efficient provision of high quality health services. 30. Purpose and Benefits: The medical care provider payment component would create financial incentives for all providers of health services to manage care provided to patients more efficiently and cost-effectively while maintaining or improving the quality of health services provided to the population. Decision-making on the allocation of resources would be decentralized so that both providers of health services and the population have more responsibility and accountability for the efficient provision of high quality health services. 31. The methods used to pay hospitals, polyclinics, and physicians would be changed to foster efficiency in the health care delivery system and promote the use of primary care. Payment for care would no longer be made on the basis of production input measures but rather on the basis of performance as measured by services provided, or episodes of care completed. The new provider payment methods would strengthen the connection between the quantity and quality of services provided, and the financial reimbursement received for those services. Incentives would encourage treatment of patients on an outpatient as opposed to inpatient basis, reduce length-of-stay for those patients who do require hospitalization, and reduce unnecessary referrals to specialists and for diagnostic tests. 32. Benefits resulting from achieving the goal of increasing the efficiency of the health care sector include the following: (i) Ability to provide more health services with current funding levels due to more efficient allocation of existing health sector resources. (ii) Increased confidence in the health sector by businesses and the population leading to greater willingness to invest in health. (iii) Increased responsibility and accountability of health providers for the outcome of health services provided to the population. (iv) Increased consumer participation in decisions about their health care. (v) Improvements in the quality of health services. (vi) Increased access to health services for the population.
 183 ANNEX 4 (vii) Greater satisfaction and prestige for medical professionals, including attracting and keeping quality professionals. 33. Provider payment reforns would change the financing and the organization of care in two important ways. Payment for care would be separated from delivery of care. The payer would focus on paying for the best care at the lowest cost -- it would purchase care rather than maintain facilities. The provider would have more flexibility to focus on delivering the most optimal mix of services with the best outcome. Secondly, providers would be "at risk" in that they would now be responsible for differences between payments received and costs incurred. Providers would be accountable for more efficient and higher quality of care. 34. This provider payment component does not directly address the institution of new forms of financing for the health sector, such as an employer tax, or the creation or organization of insurance. General reforms already occurring in the Kyrgyz Republic exhibit a broad range of activity related to new sources of financing and insurance. The German donor fund GTZ also is providing support and technical assistance related to insurance. The Bank can provide only marginal benefit in including this component. 35. Implementation: Although the Government is concerned about the level of foreign technical assistance, by definition, the institution of new provider payment methods requires substantial technical expertise in hospital payment, physician payment, clinical practice, cost accounting, clinical information systems, management, finance and internal auditing, computer systems, accreditation, and quality improvement. Although most of the products would have been developed in the Issyk-kul pilot, they will need to be adjusted to fit Bishkek and Chui Oblast because the population composition is different. 36. The implementation strategy of this component is to use foreign experts selectively to produce defined products. Each product, for example hospital payment, would have a dedicated foreign expert or module leader. Module leaders would have three goals in their work: 1.) Refine the Issyk-kul products to fit Bishkek and Chui; 2.) provide initial training to a broad audience on the systems/products through workshops, and intensively train a local expert in the specialty area; and 3.) work with the local expert to implement this aspect of the project. 37. The local expert for each programmatic area would be responsible for imnplementation of the product and continued training of health personnel. Qualified computer specialists would support them. They would both work for the fiscal intermediary or one of three associations formed to facilitate the implementation of the provider payment reforms. The three associations are a Primary Care Physicians Association, a Hospital Association, and an Accreditation Commission. Establishing these three organizations should contribute to the sustainability of the reforms. The Accreditation Commission needs to be independent to objectively determine whether a facility meets the minimum standards required to operate and receive payment for services. In the medium to long-term, the Primary Care Physicians Association and Hospital Association will serve as representative bodies in a more decentralized, market- oriented health sector. While the local experts serving as their employees are initially supported by the project, they are developing marketable skills which will be in demand in the future. 38. Description: The medical care provider payment component requires US$4.3 million in Bank funds to implement over a four year period. The Government of the Kyrgyz Republic would be required to provide contributions in terms of staff time and expertise. Implementation of this component requires structural change in the health services delivery system as well as development of new provider payment systems and the corresponding fmnancial infrastructure to support them. There are four major programmatic elements of the medical care provider payments component encompassing both structural change in the delivery system and new provider payment systems.

The firt element is comprehensive restructuring of the primary care sector through the establishment of new primary care group practices (called Family Group Practices in the Issyk-kul pilot). Currently, there are very few general or family practitioners. A group consisting of a therapist (internist), pediatrician, and obstetrician/gynecologist is required to provide comprehensive primary care services. In order to reimburse providers a capitated rate for the provision of all primary health services to an individual, a entity capable of providing the entire range of primary health services must exist. 40. The primary care groups would be the focal point of the new provider payment methods: they would enroll people and receive a capitated rate for providing a specified set of health services. The financial incentive for the groups is to provide services rather than referring patients to other parts of the health delivery system. Different models of primary care should be encouraged, and over time clinical retraining and new medical institute curriculum will lead to the development of general and family practitioners. The primary care groups should be independent, form voluntarily, and be organized as a business. They can initiate the development of non-profit entities within the health sector and also become private practitioners. 41. Approximately 300 Family Practice Groups would be needed to serve the population of Bishkek City and Chui Oblast, estimated at 1.6 million people. Each group would be capable of enrolling and serving approximately 5,300 people. A significant portion of the provider payment component budget will be directed at developing the capacity of these entities to respond to the financial incentives of the new payment methods. 42. The project activities included in this element are as follows:"6 (i) Formation of a Primary Care Physicians Association to coordinate physician formation of groups, and provide continuing education and representation for primary care physicians. In addition, the Association would employ the local experts to implement this element including practice managers, fundholding specialists, and computer specialists. (ii) Identification of potential locations for Family Practice Groups (FPGs), determination of policies on leasing publicly owned health premises to FPGs, and initiation of process of establishing FPGs as non-profit entities. (iii) Form approximately 150 FPGs in the first year of the project, 100 in the second year and 50 in the third year. Formation of the groups consists of physicians voluntarily choosing their partners; funding minor renovations of new practice locations - allowing FPGs to establish a separate identity and be dispersed throughout the community; funding equipment to enable the groups to treat patients rather than refer them; funding clinical training to increase clinical capability and begin development of a cadre of general practitioners; and establishment of financial systems, including procurement of computers and development of practice managers providing business skills for the groups. The groups should be established in both urban and rural areas, the Issyk-kul experience shows that the FPGs integrate well into the current rural health delivery system. (iv) Retraining of 1200 primary care physicians would occur over the first three years to coincide with the establishment of primary care groups. Internists, pediatricians, and obstetricians/gynecologists would receive both classroom and on-site training to improve their capability to manage care on an outpatient basis and begin the conversion to general 16see the Gantt Chart for detailed implementation timeframe

Training for specialists would be offered as they begin to redefine their role in the new health care delivery system. To develop the business skills necessary for the FPGs, one doctor from each group as well as practice managers, at a ratio of one for each 20 FPGs, would receive training on FPG financial and information systems. This in-country training would be enhanced by study tours for practice managers and primary care physicians. 43. A clinical training center would be established and provided with equipment and materials at the Republican Department of Continuous Medical Education (DCME) to provide clinical training to physicians. The development and provision of clinical training materials, books, and curriculum materials will magnify and sustain the impact of training activities. 44. The second element is free choice of primary care provider by the population and enrollment of the entire population into primary care groups. Participation by the population in decisions about their health care gives providers an incentive to provide high quality services. If patients are not satisfied, they can change providers. Information would be provided to the population to help them make informed choices about their medical provider. 45. The project activities included in this element are as follows: (i) A public awareness and marketing campaign to inform the population about FPGs and their right to choose their physician. (ii) Actual enrollment of the population in FPGs and establishment of a enrollment database for the new provider payment methods. (iii) Production of information comparing the performance of FPGs across various indicators, allowing the population to evaluate providers and make educated choices. 46. The third element is new incentive-based provider payment systems for primary care services, outpatient specialty and ancillary servlces, and hospital services. These payment systemns replace line item budgets for facilities with payment for health services at the patient level. Although the experience of the Issyk-kul pilot will determine the exact form of these systems, the main concepts are a capitated rate and case-based hospital payment. A capitated rate is the payment of a set fee to a provider for the provision of certain health services to an individual. A case-base hospital payment system reimburses hospitals a prospectively set fee depending on the type and severity of the treated case. 47. Currently, national, oblast, municipal, and rayon governments finance and control their own facilities using a budgetary system which allocates funds through predetermined functional categories such as salaries and medical supplies. The health reforms envision the population choosing providers and providers receiving payment for specific services provided to patients. The focus of payment for health services changes from the facility level to the patient level. A fiscal intermediary is needed to pool the funds from the national, oblast, municipal, and rayon sources and reimburse providers for health services they provide to the population. Funds would no longer be delineated by government level and separately allocated to facilities; services would be purchased by the fiscal intermediary from one pool of funds. 48. The fiscal intermediary requires institutional capacity to pool the funds and manage the new
 186 ANNEX 4 provider payment systems. The development and installation of new computer systems is especially important. Provider payment on a treated case basis increases the base unit for reimbursement many times. For example, in Issyk-kul, the base unit for hospital payment will increase from budgets for about 50 facilities to payment for about 50,000 treated hospital cases. This very large increase in the number of transactions requires the development of automated systems to manage the payment process. 49. Current accounting systems provide a good starting point; however, they could benefit from the introduction of accrual accounting and more sophisticated financial reporting to present available information in a more useful form. Internal auditing and control procedures are necessary. Relationships between the fiscal intermediary and the treasury and banking system need to be clearly defined. The transition to a stable market economy may require the banking system to gradually shift its focus toward handling financial transactions efficiently, away from serving as a control mechanism. 50. The project activities included in this element are as follows: (i) Formation of a Accreditation Commission to license and accredit providers to operate and receive reimbursement. In addition, the Commission would employ the local experts to implement this element including accreditation specialists, facility surveyors, quality assurance specialists, and computer specialists. (ii) Formation of a Hospital Association to represent facilities. In addition, the Association would employ the local experts to implement this element including hospital payment specialists, cost accounting and clinical information specialists, management specialists and computer specialists. (iii) Define organizational structure, build institutional capacity, create banking relationships, and develop regulations for the fiscal intermediary required to pool funds from different budget sources. (iv) Procure computer hardware, and refine computer and accounting systems for the fiscal intermediary. Computer systems would handle enrollment of the population, construction of rates for the payment systems, recording of clinical information from facility bills, payment of providers for services, operation of a quality assurance system, and analysis of health statistics. An accounting system would record all financial transactions from defined source payment documents, interact with the banking system and provide financial reports for the fiscal intermediary. (v) Development and implementation of a rationalization plan to close or consolidate some facilities. Rationalization should result in initial capacity reduction, alignment of facilities to improve competition, and savings which can be invested in more equitable payment rates for providers. (vi) Refine and extend the provider payment methods developed in the Issyk-kul pilot (again, the specific design will be adapted to the environment in Bishkek City and Chui Oblast througlWa process of evaluating options). The provider payment systems include: (a) A fundholding system with FPGs as fundholders receiving a capitated rate (predetermined fee per individual for provision of a defined set of health services) for each person enrolled. They would provide all health services required by their enrollees either directly or by purchasing them from specialists,
 187 ANNEX 4 diagnostic facilities, or hospitals. The capitated rate paid to FPGs would be initially be adjusted for age and sex. FPGs would have the right to refer to any accredited specialist or facility. To accomplish the objective of moving health resources to the primary care sector, the FPGs would be the clinical and fmnancial center of the health delivery system. (b) Payment methods for outpatient specialists and diagnostic tests. The Issyk-kul pilot is developing a schedule of fees for different services which will serve as the maximum amount the FPG would pay. However, these services can also be based on rates negotiated between FPGs and specialists and providers of diagnostic tests. (c) A case-based hospital payment system which could either reimburse hospitals on a per case basis or establish a global budget based on the type and severity of treated cases. The Medical Economic Standards system developed in Russia should not be used. Payment on a per case basis requires a patient classification system to group cases into categories based on clinical cohesiveness and homogeneity of resource use. Costs are then estimated for the categories and a relative weight calculated which reflects how much greater or less than average the resource use is for this particular diagnosis. The relative weight for the classified case is then used to reimburse hospitals a predetermined fee for that particular hospital. Technical issues needing resolution include how to maintain budget neutrality, how to avoid placing FPGs at too much risk, and determination of other payment adjustments.  191 ANNEX 5 KYRGYZ REPUBLIC HEALTH SECTOR REFORM PROJECT ANNEX 5: PHARMACEUTICAL MANAGEMENT AND REFORM COMPONENT A. Introduction 1. The availability of drugs in the Kyrgyz Republic has fallen precipitously since the breakup of the Soviet Union in 1991, caused primarily by the collapse of public finances. According to rough estimates by Kyrgyz Pharmacia, the partly Government-owned and still Government-controlled company that dominates the drug wholesale market in the republic, total sales in 1995 for the country as a whole should be approximately US$ 10 million, or a little more than US$ two dollars per capita. Annual sales reportedly totaled 80 million Russian rubles in the late 1980s, i.e. approximately US$ 120 million at the official exchange rate, or slightly more than US$ 26 per capita. 2. The poor availability of medicines is significantly aggravated, however, by wasteful and cost- ineffective pharmaceutical management. There are two major sources of waste and ineffectiveness in the current management of pharmaceuticals in the Kyrgyz Republic. One is the inadequate regulation of drugs. When the Kyrgyz Republic was part of the Soviet Union, all drug regulatory institutions and functions were located in Moscow; since independence, the Republic has lacked an institutional capability to assure the safety and efficacy of medicines produced and/or distributed locally. Moreover, the danger of ineffective, or even unsafe, medicines being supplied may be rising, in light of the worsening economic conditions, the growing shortage of drugs, and the unscrupulousness of low-quality manufacturers. A more serious source of waste is undisciplined, cost-ineffective public spending. Despite cuts in government funds for drugs, the funds that are available still are being used to buy an excessively large number of drugs, many of which have never been proven to be effective. Expensive branded drugs are sometimes purchased instead of less expensive, therapeutically equivalent generic products. And because a large number of different drugs are purchased in relatively small quantities, the demand for many important, widely used medicines often is not met, while the price that must be paid to obtain these drugs is higher than would be the case if larger quantities of fewer drugs were purchased through competitive bidding. 3. The pharmaceutical management component of the project is designed to improve the availability of essential drugs in the Kyrgyz Republic both (a) directly, by financing the procurement and distribution of a large quantity of essential drugs, and (b) indirectly, by supporting the implementation of far-reaching reforms designed to strengthen the Government's drug regulatory capabilities and to increase the discipline and cost-effectiveness of public spending. Financial support for the procurement and distribution of essential drugs is contingent on the Government's continued determination to implement these reforms. These reforms, taken together, will lead to a significant improvement in the availability of essential drugs in the republic and to a permanent increase in the cost effectiveness of public and private spending on drugs--that is, the amount of health provided by any given amount of public and/or private resources. 4. The financing of approximately US$ 6.0 million of essential drugs, besides helping to improve directly the availability of needed medicines, also is intended to help improve the overall efficiency of drug distribution, by supporting, albeit indirectly, the continued restructuring and privatization of the government monopoly previously in charge of the drug trade in the republic. In view of the large size of the contemplated procurement, the complex procedures that will be used to implement the procurement and the subsequent distribution of drugs need to be described and explained in detail and that is the primary purpose of this Annex.
 192 ANNEX 5 B. Pharmaceutical Management Reforms 5. National Drug Regulatory Organization. The national drug regulatory authority will be responsible for: (a) the registration of all drugs and vaccines manufactured and/or marketed in the Kyrgyz Republic, including pre-registration review of all technical information on safety and effectiveness, the organization of clinical trials if necessary, and post-registration monitoring of drug utilization and possible adverse drug reactions; (b) quality testing and quality assurance of all drugs and vaccines manufactured, imported into, marketed, and/or otherwise distributed in the Kyrgyz Republic. 6. A national drug regulatory organization was established in 1993 by decree of the Prime Minister. Located within the MOH, the organization is known officially as the Administration for Standardization and Oversight of the Quality of Medicines and Medical Technology. The authority and responsibilities of this organization are reaffirmed in a proposed "Law on Medicines" that has been drafted. The Administration for Standardization includes, among its subordinate departments, a national drug testing laboratory which is responsible for (a) providing technical support of the Administration's registration decisions and (b) ascertaining the quality of drugs manufactures, imported, and/or otherwise distributed in the Kyrgyz Republic. 7. The Drug Regulatory Organization and its subordinate testing laboratory, which are co-located, have rented 340 meters of space at the Institute of Cardiology and are negotiating with the Institute to rent an additional 160 meters of adjoining space. With a total of approximately 500 square meters of space, the organization will have sufficient room to perform its functions. Renovation of the premises has begun, and a small amount of testing equipment has been procured; it will be installed when additional renovation is completed and the necessary laboratory furniture has been acquired. Current staff of the organization numbers 15 of a planned 35. The project will provide extensive support to enable the organization and laboratory to become fully operational as quickly as possible. The project will provide US$97,000 for renovation of the premises and US$357,000 for the purchase of: office furniture and equipment; laboratory testing equipment and furniture; reagents and chemical glassware; scientific literature, computer software, and databases; and other necessary supplies. 8. The project will finance a substantial amount of training for the staff of the organization and laboratory, including activities designed to foster close professional relations between officials of the organization and counterparts in drug regulatory agencies of other countries. The project will finance in-country training in the use of computers and databases, the use of new laboratory equipment, and cost- effectiveness analysis for approximately 75 people during the first two years of the project. The project also will finance approximately 50 person-weeks of training and study tours abroad, spread over four years. In order to facilitate widespread dissemination of this information within the Kyrgyz Republic and to support a limited amount of training for persons outside the organization and laboratory, e.g. local health care officials, the project will finance an annual two-day national conference on drug regulatory affairs, including participation of foreign experts. 9. The Drug Regulatory Organization presently operates as a self-financing body, relying on incoii.- from registration and testing fees. As a result, drug regulatory officials may have a direct economic interest in their regulatory decisions, and this may increase the risk that ineffective, or even unsafe, drugs will be made available to patients. Part of the costs of the drug regulatory organization can and should continue to be financed out of registration and testing fees. The labor costs of the staff that process

The costs of reagents and other consumables used in laboratory analyses, as weli as the labor costs of technicians, likewise should be charges to the vendors whose products are being tested. However, in order to avoid potential conflicts of interest, the compensation of senior drug officials and other staff with a direct voice in regulatory decisions should be financed solely and directly from the state budget. The adoption of revised procedures for financing the Administration for Standardization, which provide that the salaries of senior officials and regulatory decision-makers are financed by the Government and not from fees, was a condition of negotiatons. 10. The TCC component coordinator for pharmaceutical management will supervise the implementation of the various activities. The TCC component coordinator will prepare, in concert with the Chief of the Drug Regulatory Organization, an annual training plan, including the dates, location, purpose, and names of participants for all in-country training courses and foreign study tours; the TCC component coordinator will exercise personal responsibility for assuring that all technical and logistical requirements of the training are met. The TCC component coordinator will maintain continual communications with other donors, in particular the WHO, in order to minimize duplication and to maximize coordination in all drug regulatory technical assistance and training activities. Finally, the Coordinator will, each year, convene and chair a temporary organizing committee to prepare for and to implement the annual national conference on drug regulatory affairs. 11. Essential Drugs Program: An Essential Drugs List (EDL), numbering 300 different products, has been adopted as a first step toward the creation of an Essential Drugs Program (EDP). Part 1 of this list, which has received the WHO's endorsement, consists of the 195 "most widely distributed basic medicines" that are expected to be consistently available at, or by prescription from, all primary and secondary health care facilities. Part 2 consists of 105 "basic medicines used in specialized institutions." Formal adoption and publication of the EDL by the MOH, was a condition of negotiations. 12. The draft EDL was compiled by a large ad hoc committee in the MOH and is the product of a lengthy dialogue between the MOH and experts from the WHO and the World Bank. The process for establishing and maintaining the EDL must now be institutionalized. The "Law on Medicines" delegates to the MOH formal authority to compile the EDL. Final passage of this law, with this authority included, and the adoption of formal rules and procedures for compiling and maintaining the EDL, including provisions for its periodic review and, if necessary, revision in the future, are to be accomplished prior to December 31, 1996. 13. In order to become an effective means of influence over the procurement and utilization of drugs, the EDL must be made widely available, and the rationale for an EDL must be understood clearly and supported by physicians, pharmacists, other health care professionals, and health care financing decision- makers. The project will support development and publication of a brochure, containing the EDL and a lengthy commentary explaining how the List was compiled and its purpose. The project will finance the printing and distribution of several thousand copies of the brochure, which will be made available to all pharmacists and health facilities prior to the start of the sizable procurement of essential drugs under the project. The project will help to finance a workshop in each oblast prior to effectiveness, in order to introduce the EDL to local health leaders and to build professional support for an Essential Drugs Program. In the second and fourth years of the project, revised editions of the EDL will be published and distributed.

Duning negotiations, assurances were obtained from the Government that it will formally adopt and effectively implement this rule by the beginning of 1998. At the samne time, no restrictions will be placed on the privately-financed purchase, distribution, and sale of medicines which are not included on the EDL. 16. The establishment and operations of the Kyryyz Republic's Essential Drugs Program will be undertaken and supervised by a standing commission or committee appointed by the Minister of Health, consistent with authority provided by the proposed "Law on Medicines" and as provided by the rules to be adopted on compiling and maintaining the EDL. During negotiations, assurances were obtained that the formation of this committee will be done by December 31, 1996. The TCC component coordinator for pharmaceutical management will be a member of this body and will coordinate the various project activities intended to support implementation of the EDP. In particular, the TCC component coordinator will: (a) convene and chair a small, informal working group to oversee production and distribution of the EDL; (b) maintain close communications with the WHO, UNICEF, and other donors in order to ensure that foreign assistance in the development of new standard treatment guidelines is used with minimum duplication and maximum effectiveness; and (c) convene and chair an informal working group to design and implement a monitoring program which will include regular surveys of pharmacies and physicians in order to measure the availability and utilization of essential drugs. C. Drug Distribution in the Kyrgyz Republic 17. The Old System: Until recently, the procurement and distribution of pharmaceuticals in the Kyrgyz Republic was the exclusive responsibility of Pharmacia, a centralized, vertically integrated, semi- commercial government corporation headquartered in Moscow that, during the Soviet period, monopolized the drug trade throughout the former' Soviet Union. As in every other union republic, Kyrgyz Pharmacia consisted of a central office and warehouse in the republican capital, Bishkek (then known as Frunze); regional offices and warehouses at the oblast level; and a large network of hospital, inter-hospital, and community (retail) pharmacies. Although concentrated disproportionately in the largest cities, pharmacies were numerous and widely dispersed, so that medicines were generally accessible to patients and health facilities alike, even in rural areas. The system was administered by a large cadre of trained professional pharrnacists and pharmacy technicians. 18. There being almost no domestic pharmaceutical industry in the Kyrgyz Republic, approximately 96-98% of the drugs distributed locally were--and are still--imported. Most shipments were delivered to Kyrgyz Pharmacia's central warehouse in Bishkek, where they were divided into lots and onward shipped to the oblast Pharmacias which, in turn, acted as distributors for the pharmacies and health care facilities located in their respective regions. In Chui Oblast, the regional Pharmacia recently was
 195 ANNEX 5 disbanded; the national office of Kyrgyz Pharmacia now supplies pharmnacies and health care facilities located in Chui Oblast, as well as those in Bishkek city, out of its central warehouse. 19. At the point of distribution to patients, the pharmacy system functioned--and continues to function--like that in most countries. In hospitals, physicians ordered or prescribed drugs which were supplied by the hospital pharmacy or, if the hospital was too small to warrant its own pharmacy, by the inter-hospital pharmacy designated as the hospital's regular supplier. [It should be remembered that these pharmacies, although physically located in the hospitals, belonged to the Pharmacia system, not the Ministry of Health or local health department.] In similar fashion, out-patients could have their prescriptions filled at any retail pharmacy, although some pharmacies specialized in particular illnesses or patient groups. 20. Relatively few patients paid for their medicines. By law, all drugs dispensed in hospitals were (are) supposed to be provided to patients free of charge; and there was (is) a long list of ambulatory patients similarly entitled to receive medicines free of charge or at heavily subsidized prices. The entitlement list has been frequently amended but usually has consisted of approximately 20 categories of illness--e.g. dysentery, bronchial asthma, AIDS--and anywhere from 15 to 30 population groups-e.g. World War n veterans, Chernobyl victims, children up to the age of three. Overall, before the breakup of the Soviet Union, probably 80-90% of all drugs consumed in the republic were dispensed to patients at no charge. 21. However, while mostly free to patients, drugs were not free--at least not on paper--to the pharmacies and health care facilities that dispensed them. The hospital "bought" drugs from its pharmacy at controlled prices equal to the pharmacy's acquisition cost plus a standard, fixed markup to cover operating expenses. The hospital generally "paid" the pharmacy out of its own budget, although sometimes the pharmacy was paid directly by the city or oblast health department. Funds needed to cover these costs, i.e. the fiscal cost of drugs supplied to in-patients, have long been appropriated separately under Article 10 of the republic and oblast health budgets. A similar payment mechanism functioned in the case of exempted ambulatory patients. Every month, retail pharmacies billed the city or oblast health department for the cost of drugs dispensed to exempted out-patients, again based on prices equal to acquisition cost plus a standard markup. The anticipated fiscal cost of treating these patients was included in Article 10 budgets as well. [Pharmacies also sold drugs for cash to patients who were not exempt from payment, although these receipts reportedly constituted a relatively small portion of total revenues.] 22. The financing of drug procurement was based largely on this system of inter-organizational payments. Hospital and retail pharmacies bought drugs from their oblast Pharmacia, paying out of revenues received from their local health department (for the treatment of exempted patients) and from cash-paying customers. Oblast Pharmacias, in turn, botight their drugs from Kyrgyz Pharmacia's republic warehouse and paid out of the revenues they received from their pharmacies. The Kyrgyz Republic Pharmacia bought drugs from the national Pharmacia in Moscow. In this fashion, the procurement and distribution of drugs were financed indirectly by: (1) the republic's consolidated health budget line appropriations for drugs, i.e. the sum of all Article 10 appropriations; and (2) a comparatively much smaller amount of private spending on drugs. 23. In addition, given the controls on prices, finances at each level of the system and in each institution were expected to be more or less in balance; that is, for any given oblast Pharmacia or individual pharmacy, total revenues ought to have been approximately equal to total operating (non- capital) costs. In practice, the system's finances were often not in balance. Some Pharmacias and pharmacies earned "excess" revenues which, if discovered, generally were confiscated by the tax authorities; others accumulated arrears, caused by various contingencies, including late or non-payment
 196 ANNEX 5 by local health authorities. Although the managers of loss-making enterprises might be disciplined, or even fired on occasion, the arrears apparently had no financial consequences nor any effect on the supply of drugs. At the end of the year, financial imbalances were invariably cleared and debts written off; excess earners had their surplus taken away, those in debt were given added funds, and the cycle began again. 24. Post Independence: When the Soviet Union broke up and Kyrgyzstan became an independent republic, this accounting system suddenly began to work as a financing system as well. The republic Pharmacia's debts no longer were covered automatically by Moscow, and the republic's traditional suppliers--mostly Russian and Ukrainian manufacturers--no longer would ship drugs to the Bishkek warehouse without strong assurances they would be paid. Increasingly, pre-payment in a convertible currency has been required. In order to maintain the same volume of supply as before, either the republican company (now known as Kyrgyz Pharmacia) needs to receive sufficient income from its subordinate companies and to be able to convert the revenue into a useable currency; or the Kyrgyz Govermnent needs to make up the shortfall directly, either from its budget or by means of a credit. In fact, economic depression and the Government's strong fiscal stabilization policy have, in combination, prevented the direct subsidization of Kyrgyz Pharmacia and have led, in addition, to a significant decline in public spending overall, including consolidated Article 10 appropriations. As a result, receipts to Kyrgyz Pharmacia and to each oblast Pharmacia, financed out of public spending and measured in constant prices, have fallen substantially. 25. As public spending on drugs has fallen, private spending has grown. Informal sources claim that as much as 50 percent or more of the drugs consumed in the republic's hospitals are paid for out of pocket by the patients or their families. In a 1994 survey sponsored by the British foreign assistance agency, ODA, nearly three-fifths of 285 respondents who reported having been hospitalized in the previous year claimed to have spent at least US$ five dollars to obtain drugs prescribed during their hospital stay. Nevertheless, total spending on drugs has, by all available evidence, declined dramatically. Kyrgyz Pharmacia and the oblast Pharmacias are still the only significant distributors in the republic, and their current budgets are but a fraction of what they were previously, before independence. 26. At the level of health care facilities and patients, the availability of drugs has worsened commensurately. Although most hospitals, especially in major urban centers, reportedly have been able to maintain minimum supplies of essential drugs, it supposedly has become a common practice, especially in "elective" procedures, to present the patient a list of necessary supplies, including drugs, which the patient him or herself must supply before care is provided. Previously, it was thought that the policy of free in-patient drugs was a cause of excessive hospitalization rates and long average lengths of stay; now, the diminishing supply of drugs probably is a cause of the decline observed in the use of hospital services. Exempted ambulatory patients have experienced a similar decline in availability. Some physicians reportedly have reduced their prescribing, not wanting to add to the frustrations of their patients or to their facilities' debts; and some pharmacies reportedly have refused to dispense drugs to exempted patients, often claiming stock outages. Supplies nominally reserved for exempt patients reportedly have been diverted from state to the new private pharmacies where they are sold at market-clearing prices. 27. Kyrgyz Government Policy: In response to the worsening drug situation, the Kyrgyz Government is making what appears to be a serious effort to break up the Pharmacia system. The plan is to make each level of the system independent, to fully commercialize the various successor companies, and gradually to privatize them. The central office and warehouse, Kyrgyz Pharmacia, and the five oblast Pharnnacias have each been made into an independent, joint-stock company. Most hospital pharmacies have been formally transferred to the facilities in which they are located or to the corresponding oblast health department. At the retail level, some pharmacies have been auctioned off
 197 ANNEX 5 for cash, others have been privatized "administratively," i.e. given to their employees, and still others remain the property of their parent Pharmacias. Kyrgyz Pharmacia, for example, operates 33 pharmacies in the city of Bishkek. In addition, a number of new, private pharmacies have appeared, mainly in Bishkek where, according to Kyrgyz Pharmacia officials, new entrants may account for as much as 30 percent of local sales. 28. The restructuring of Pharmacia is far from complete. Kyrgyz Pharmacia and the oblast companies still are the only significant local distributors active in the republic. Also, the financial condition of most of the system reportedly is weak, aggravated in particular by the Govermnent's insistence that all of the inherited debt be fully apportioned to the successor companies. Especially vulnerable are the oblast Pharmacias which reportedly owe Kyrgyz Pharmacia approximately US$5 million for previous deliveries, and whose warehouses are described as nearly empty for lack of working capital. Moreover, despite decentralization, the influence of government in Pharmacia operations remains very strong. For examnple, on paper only 35 percent of the stock of Kyrgyz Pharmacia belongs to the national Government; another 35 percent has been assigned to the company's employees; and the remaining 30 percent supposedly has been sold to private investors, including several foreign firms. Yet, the shares assigned to employees have not yet been distributed, leaving management solidly in control of those votes; neither management nor the Government will identify the private investors who have bought shares; and it is abundantly clear to any casual observer that informal relations between senior managers at Kyrgyz Pharmacia and senior officials in the Ministry of Health and elsewhere in government remain extremely close and cooperative. At the oblast level, where the level of government ownership is said to be as high as 70 percent, relations must be even tightel 29. On the other hand, the drug distribution system obviously is in transition, and the changes made so far are significant and clearly in the right direction, for there can be no doubt that a privately-owned, competitive system of drug wholesalers and retailers is likely to operate far more efficiently and cost effectively than one run by the Government. At the same time, the effects of continued strong government control over the Pharmacia companies should not be misconstrued or overstated. The oblast governments in Naryn and Osh, for example, may exercise a decisive voice in the operations of "their" Pharmacias, as strong or stronger than the national Government's voice in Kyrgyz Pharmacia. But these three governments are today much less unified and in sync with one another than they were previously under Communism. More important, the Pharmacia monopoly has been broken, and competition at all levels is rising. The oblast Pharmacias no longer buy exclusively from Kyrgyz Pharmacia, but increasingly are engaging in direct negotiations with traditional Pharmacia suppliers (chiefly Russian manufacturers) and with the old and new distributors that have proliferated throughout the NIS. Kyrgyz Pharnacia, for its part, has begun to compete with its former oblast subordinates over supply contracts with pharmacies and health care facilities. Probably it is only a matter of time before the oblast Pharmacias reach out across oblast borders and begin to compete directly with one another. 30. Apart from organizational questions, the Government's response to the worsening drug situation has been much more tepid. Particularly disappointing has been the marked lack of interest shown in reviewing and revising the exemptions policy that promises free in-patient drugs to all and free out-patient drugs to as much as two-thirds of the population. The effects of this exemptions policy and the prospects of change will be discussed in more detail below. Here, the following should be said. First, although very generous on paper, the Government's drug entitlement policy has become seriously under-funded in practice, with the result that fewer patients than before are getting free or subsidized drugs, while many formally exempt patients are having to pay for them. However, the cuts in supply have been implemented in an ad hoc, and therefore haphazard, f-shion. As a result, some relatively affluent patients who could--and would--pay for their drugs still are getting them free of charge, while many very poor patients are having to pay or to do without. Meanwhile, free drugs still are being dispensed in cases
 198 ANNEX 5 of non-urgent care, when in cases requiring immediate attention the necessary drugs are unavailable. Such outcomes are neither equitable nor cost-effective in terms of health policy. 31. Nor is the system any more rational in terms of budget and finance policy, for there is virtually no connection between the cost of the exemptions and actual spending decisions. The Ministry of Health continues to calculate annual drug needs of the population--i.e., what is required to satisfy the Government's obligations in this area--and to convey this information to the Parliament. But the Ministry has made no effort to rank in order of priority the exemptions or associated demand for drugs, and because resources are wholly inadequate to fully fund the Ministry's requests, the national Parliament's Article 10 appropriations have been based mainly on the previous year's budget and the current year's anticipated revenues. At the same time, decisions by the national Parliament are mainly indicative, not prescriptive, for most health spending is budgeted and financed locally where the cost of exemptions is not calculated and where the connection between these costs and spending decisions is virtually non- existent. In theory, the substance of an entitlements policy and its financing should be closely coordinated. In practice, the Kyrgyz Government's present approach to drug entitlements precludes such coordination, virtually assuring that the cost of patient exemptions and the financing of those exemptions will be permanently out of sync. 32. Summary: There exists in the Kyrgyz Republic a well-developed drug distribution system that is professionally run and easily accessible to health facilities and most of the population. This system is in transition, and while much ground remains to be covered, the pace of change is impressive and its direction is decidedly progressive. The weaknesses in the current system, apart from its incomplete restructuring, should not be minimized. There probably are too many retail pharmacies in operation, and some will likely have to be closed as uneconomical. The system's technological level is generally low; accounting, pricing, anti inventory operations especially need to be computerized. The professional training of most pharmacists is similarly inadequate. The growing emphasis on primary and preventive care, combined with recent advances in drug therapy, demand that pharmacists play an increasingly active role in treatment decisions, but this will require that local pharmacists receive much more preparation in, for example, clinical pharmacology. Perhaps most serious for the immediate future is the near-total absence of professionals trained in the economics, finances, and management of drug procurement and distribution. 33. However, on balance the strengths of the existing system seem more impressive than its weaknesses, and this has decided implications for the project. Clearly it is unnecessary, and probably it would be counterproductive, to encourage the formation of a new mechanism to handle the procurement and distribution of essential drugs financed under the project. Indeed, care should be taken not to impede or undermine the generally progressive changes now taking place in the Pharmacia system. Particularly undesirable, from the standpoint of thefuture effectiveness of the Kyrgyz Republic's health system, would be the inadvertent reconstitution of a government monopoly in charge of the drug trade. In addition, there are embedded in this system well-established principles and mechanisms of accounting and financing, including means of cost recovery. Cost recovery in practice is limited by the Government's exemption policy and will improve only when that policy is changed and fewer patients are entitled to receive free drugs. Sufficient mechanisms for cost recovery already exist, however, and do not need to be created or encouraged.
 199 ANNEX 5 D. The Procurement and Distribution of Essential Drugs Under the Project 34. The project will make available approximately $US 6.9 million (including contingencies) to finance the purchase and distribution of essential drugs. The purpose is twofold: to help ensure minimum health standards during the most wrenching phase of the country's transition to democracy and a market economy, when social and economic dislocations are the most severe; and to reinforce needed reforms specifically in the health sector, aimed at raising the efficiency and cost-effectiveness with which public funds are used. 35. There exist, in principle, a variety of ways by which essential drugs might be procured and distributed. The Association and the Government have agreed that several key principles must be observed, regardless of the method chosen: (i) Only the most essential, cost-effective drugs should be purchased in order to maximize the health effects of the available funds; (ii) Drugs procured under the project should be sold to distributors, and then to the public, at near-market prices in order to prevent their diversion to neighboring countries or the black market; (iii) Prices to health care facilities should be limited in order to maximize availability; (iv) Final retail prices to ambulatory patients, except in the case of exempted patients, should be unrestricted in order to limit market distortions and to raise the maximum amount of additional private spending; (v) Drugs procured under the project should be made equally available to all regions in the republic; (vi) Drugs procured under the project should be made equally available to all onward distributors and retailers, regardless of their form of ownership. 36. All final arrangements must be reviewed and approved by the Association prior to effectiveness. In addition, these rules and procedures will be reviewed by the Association at the end of each procurement cycle and revised, if necessary, by mutual agreement with the Kyrgyz Government, so as to ensure that new, financially viable, privately-owned drug wholesalers and retailers are in no way disadvantages, compared to remaining state-owned companies.
