Alternative Methods of Distribution 39. As noted, there are other ways that essential drugs might be procured and distributed under the project; when examined closely, however, these turned out to be either significantly more complicated and expensive administratively, at odds with one or more of the goals or principles of the project as described above, or simply impractical. For example, one proposal considered at length was to establish a Drug Revolving Fund (DRF), a quasi-public corporation that would attempt to sell as many of the drugs as possible in order to maximize cost recovery. The idea ultimnately was rejected for several reasons. Since there already exists in the Kyrgyz Republic a well-developed, accessible, and professionally operated drug distribution system, there would seem to be little advantage in creating a new structure, particularly one that would require considerable oversight by the Government and the Association. Moreover, in view of the restructuring and ongoing privatization of the existing system, it surely would be counterproductive to at this point in time encourage the Government to get back into the drug trade. Finally, as previously discussed, there already exist well-established principles and mechanisms of cost recovery. What limits cost recovery in practice is the Government's exemption policy, and the creation of a DRF would not, by itself, alter this fact. 40. Another possibility would be for the Government to procure drugs through the PCU, as currently envisioned; and then to sell the drugs at cost to Kyrgyz Pharmacia and to let Kyrgyz Pharmacia distribute
 201 ANNEX 5 them according to general guidelines and/or specific tasks, as agreed to in a contract with the Government. The chief difficulty with this idea is that Kyrgyz Pharmacia very likely would choose not to participate, i.e. would not buy the drugs at a price equal to the procurement cost, because it probably would not be profitable to do so. [If it were profitable, then Kyrgyz Pharmacia would not need the Association to help finance the procurement.] One reason is that even generic products bought under the project are likely to be significantly more expensive than many of the drugs Kyrgyz Pharmacia presently buys from Russian manufacturers--drugs which, in most cases, will not be eligible for procurement under the project because the factories in question do not meet the standards of Good Manufacturing Practices (GMPs). Another reason is that because the drugs purchased under the project all will be Essential Drugs, many will end up being dispensed to exempted in- or out-patients. [Even if there was sufficient demand from non-exempt patients, it would be wholly impractical to try to sell project-financed drugs to cash-paying customers, while distributing free of charge to exempt patients the very same drugs procured with budget funds.] The ability of distributors and pharmacies to make money from the sale of project-financed drugs will depend significantly on the ability and willingness of local health authorities to use their Article 10 funds to buy these products. 41. A third possibility, closely related to the second, would be for the Government to onward sell the drugs to Kyrgyz Pharmacia at subsidized prices, e.g. through a concessionary on-lending arrangement similar to what is presently envisioned vis-a-vis the oblast Pharnacias. The main objection here is political, namely: why undermine the progressive restructuring of the Pharmacia system that is now taking place, by giving the entire subsidy to Kyrgyz Pharmacia which already dominates the wholesale market and which appears to be doing reasonably well financially, particularly when compared to the now-independent oblast Pharmacias? If a subsidy is to be provided-as probably it must, if project- financed drugs are to be onward distributed--surely it would be more sensible to try to reinforce the progressive changes occurring in the republic's pharmaceutical market by giving most of the subsidy to Kyrgyz Pharmacia's prospective, but financially weaker, competitors. 42. A fourth possibility would be for the Government to procure drugs through the PCU, perhaps hiring Kyrgyz Pharmacia physically to receive shipments; and then to auction the drugs to any and all bidders, subject only to the provision that they subsequently distribute the drugs exclusively within the Kyrgyz Republic. For reasons already discussed, it is likely that the drugs distributed in this manner would be sold at prices significantly below their procurement cost, so that the buyers would in effect receive a subsidy. However, in this case the Government would not be able to choose the recipients of the subsidy (Kyrgyz Phannacia would likely gamer a sizable percentage), nor would it be able to prevent the subsequent distribution of the drugs disproportionately in the republic's richest markets (i.e. Bishkek) to the disadvantage of other, less wealthy regions. E. The Kyrgyz Government's Drug Exemptions Policy 43. It has been noted several times previously that potentially adequate mechanisms of cost recovery for drugs bought with public funds already exist, and that cost recovery has been limited severely in practice by the Government's generous policy of exempting large numbers of patients from paying the full cost of their drugs. Although this policy is now seriously under-funded, which has led to rationing in practice, the cuts in funding and supplies have been distributed in a largely ad hoc, haphazard fashion that has been both inequitable and cost-ineffective in its effects. The rationalization of this policy, i.e. the reduction of exemptions and/or their cost to what the Government's consolidated health budget can presently afford, would very likely have a net positive impact on the population's health status, by increasing the cost-effectiveness of public spending on drugs. Rationalization of the present exemptions policy would, in addition: (a) remove a significant barrier to entry into the drug trade by private entrepreneurs who fear becoming saddled with obligations that could threaten their profitability; (b)
 202 ANNEX 5 eliminate a major cause of the financial weakness of existing pharmacies and drug wholesalers; and (c) lead to an increase in private spending on drugs by patients and institutions that may be able and willing to buy drugs on the open market "out of pocket," but that are presently able to satisfy their drug requirements at less than full cost by taking advantage of the Government's subsidy. [The need to re- connect the substance of the exemptions policy with the financing of this policy, as discussed earlier, is a separate issue from the need to reduce the fiscal cost of the exemptions policy, although changes in either one will affect the other, and so both issues will have to be considered together.] Given these prospective benefits, the question needs to be asked, to what extent can or should changes in the Governments's exemptions policy be encouraged under the project? 44. Analytically, the fiscal cost of this policy might be reduced in one or both of two ways: either the list of exemptions (exempted patients) can be cut; or the cost of those exemptions can be reduced, e.g by introducing co-financing by recipients (co-payments, deductibles) and/or by restricting eligibility to the poor through means-testing. Either approach is very likely to run into difficult political and technical obstacles in practice. Thus, there are strong public health reasons for keeping the treatment of communicable diseases free; there are equally strong political reasons for continuing to exempt war veterans; and there are good economic and ethical reasons for exempting high-cost cancer drugs that could quickly bankrupt even the most affluent of patients. As evidenced already by the long struggle to compile the Essential Drugs List, every exemption category will have its defenders, on professional and political grounds, and paring the list in more than a symbolic way will be no mean feat. Nor will it be much easier to reduce the cost of the policy. For example, a very nominal, standard dispensing fee could be introduced, payable by all recipients; but it would be difficult politically to institute a fee large enough to raise a significant amount of money. Anything more elaborate--e. g. a variable co-payment (deductible) based on the price of the drug or the income of the patient--could lead to undesirable prescribing and/or dispensing behavior, or would become enmeshed in the same problems involved in efforts to limit eligibility (see below). 45. The most commonly advocated--and, at first glance, seemingly the simplest and most powerful- way to rationalize exemptions policy would be to limit exemptions to the poor and to require all others to pay for their drugs. [However, even at the level of general principles, there will be opponents arguing that health care, including the provision of essential drugs, has always been and should remain a "right," not a commodity.] Ordinarily, this would be a goal for the future, not a task for the present, because it usually is extremely complicated administratively and expensive to implement means-testing in a country like the Kyrgyz Republic, where a very high percentage of personal income normally is concealed, corruption is rife, and cooperation between different agencies of government is minimal. Nevertheless, in the course of the "social safety net" project, also supported by the World Bank, two broad classes of families have been identified, based on their income and need for supplementary public assistance; this same classification system, some have suggested, could be used to limit eligibility for drug benefits, and perhaps other social benefits as well. Thus, families receiving aid from the Social Security Ministry also could be designated as eligible to receive free or subsidized drugs, while all others could be required to pay for their drugs out of pocket. 46. In fact, instituting such a policy would be difficult. For one thing, it is unlikely that non-exempt patients would be made to pay for the treatment of serious communicable diseases, and the continued full exemption of these categories of patients will reduce the fiscal savings of such a change in policy. Much more important, however, is the fact that the cost of drugs for individuals and families--like the cost of other medical services, but unlike the cost of food, shelter, clothing, and transportation--is highly variable and unpredictable. In any given year, a few individuals and families will need no drugs; many will need drugs costing a small amount; some will need drugs costing more; a few will need drugs costing a lot; and a very few will need drugs costing an enormous amount. Accordingly, there will be strong
 203 ANNEX 5 pressures: (a) to cap the financial risk of any individual or family, by establishing a ceiling on monthly out-of-pocket expenditures for drugs covered by whatever exemption categories remain; and (b) to grade an individual's or family's financial risk according to income or cost of treatment, by introducing a variable co-payment required of non-exempt patients, applicable until the ceiling on total out-of-pocket expenditures has been reached, and based on the patients' income. Instituting even a simple cap on financial risk, although a simple concept in theory, would be a huge administrative headache and expensive; the complexity and cost of more elaborate schemes would rise geometrically. 47. In the present context it might still make sense to press for introduction of the simple, two-class system for regulating exemptions, if it could be shown that the financial savings would be significant. Unfortunately, this information does not presently exist. Indeed, not even crude estimates of the potential savings can be calculated until: (a) reliable data are collected on drug utilization at the patient level; and (b) a decision is made concerning which exemption categories will be maintained even for the [non- exempt" (i.e. families not receiving public assistance). 48. There is within the Government and among health professionals widespread awareness that the current exemptions policy is far more expensive than the budget presently can afford and that it needs to be changed. However, there is no consensus yet as to how this should be done, nor does the issue appear to be a high priority on the Government's agenda. Whether there is sufficient political will to tackle this issue now is, therefore, open to question. F. Expected Impact of the Project 49. Ironically, the fiscal cost of the Government's present exemptions policy should decline under the project regardless, as a consequence of the introduction of the Essential Drugs Programn, and particularly at the start of the third year of tl . project when public spending will be limited exclusively to those drugs contained on the Essential Drugs List. As discussed previously, a significant, sustained improvement in the cost-effectiveness of public spending on drugs is the most important expected benefit of the pharmaceutical management component. In addition, the procurement and distribution of $US 6.9 million of essential drugs will have an impact on the physical availability of drugs during the project, on the composition of available supply, and on the financial viability of the distribution system; and these impacts need to be considered separately. 50. Total Physical Supply. Because the drugs are to be sold--either for cash or for reimbursement from Article 10 funds--there is likely to be only a modest increase in the total physical supply of drugs in the republic as a result of the project. Consider the following: unless drugs are given away, total physical supply will be a function of aggregated public and private spending. As a condition of the project, the Government will assure that aggregated public spending will fall no lower than 1994 levels measured in constant prices. There already is a sizable amount of private spending; and the project will almost certainly have both positive and negative first-order effects on that spending. Specifically, the impact will be negative, insofar as some cash-paying patients will be able to get the same drugs they are buying now more cheaply; and it will be positive, insofar as other cash-paying patients are likely to spend more in order to obtain needed drugs that should be more available and more attractively priced than before. Sellers, in the meantime, will want to maximize their profits; if they are unsure about the prospects of reimbursement by local governments, they will likely try to divert as much as possible of their stock to cash-paying customers and to price their drugs at market-clearing levels. Intuitively, it seems likely that the net impact of the project will be (1) to increase total private spending, and (2) to depress prices somewhat (which will raise the buying power of both public and private spending); the total physical supply of drugs should rise as a result.
 204 ANNEX 5 51. Composition of Total Supply. Because drugs procured under the project will be Essential Drugs, a significant percentage is likely to be dispensed to exempted patients and, in turn, financed out of local health budgets. Thus, if total public spending for drugs remains constant, a higher percentage of that spending will be used to buy Essential Drugs--specifically those drugs procured under the project- even prior to the third year of the project when the Government is required to limit public spending exclusively to the drugs contained on the republic's Essential Drugs List. By the same token, a smaller percentage of aggregated public spending will be available to support the purchase of drugs NOT supplied under the project. In addition, because the oblast Pharmacias will be receiving drugs at very low cost, it may become more difficult for other distributors to sell the same drugs profitably, i.e. at a price high enough to recover their acquisition costs. Thus, it is possible that alternative sourcing of the drugs procured under the project could decline, particularly if quantities procured under the project represent a substantial portion of annual demand for the drugs in question. These uncertainties and risks with respect to the project's impact on the composition of the republic's drug supply--because the magnitude of these effects are nearly impossible to predict in advance, and because supplies of widely used drugs could be disrupted--are reasons why the lists of drugs to be procured under the project need to be chosen carefully and why disbursement is best spread out over multiple tranches. 52. Distribution System. The project's most immediate impact on the drug distribution system will be the re-capitalization of that system's weakest link: the oblast Pharmacias. Although still majority government-owned, these companies are now nominally independent and are supposed to be operating as commercial entities; eventually they are to be fully privatized. For now, however, the oblast Pharmacias appear to lack both financing and drugs: their warehouses reportedly are empty; they are deeply in debt; and they have no access to short-term credit which they might use to rebuild their inventories. By providing these regional distributors with a substantial supply of low-cost drugs, the project will, in effect, be giving these companies a new lease on life. If the oblast Pharmacias are permitted to retain a significant portion of their earnings from the onward sale of these drugs, it is possible than one or more of the five will survive and develop into a financially viable distributor with improved prospects of escaping government control and becoming a genuinely private competitor of Kyrgyz Pharmacia. There is, of course, no certainty in this result, although the potential gain surely warrants the effort. For by supporting the establishment of a drug distribution system based on privately- owned, competitive wholesalers and retailers, the project can effect a sustained improvement in the efficiency of drug distribution in the republic and, in turn, a sustained increase in the availability of drugs.

This program would include, among other things: ensure drug registration of the Essential Drugs, quarterly surveys of a national sample of pharmacies to measure availability and price of drugs, percentage of total prescriptions which are filled with Essential Drugs, and percentage of drugs dispensed to "entitled" patients which consists of Essential Drugs; annual surveys of physicians and pharmacists to measure awareness of and support for the Essential Drugs Program; and, random checks of pharmacies to measure quality of drugs offered for sale and extent to which pharnacies satisfy licensing requirements. (v) Convene and chair a small working group to oversee production and distribution of the Essential Drugs List. Specific responsibilities would include, among other things; the writing of introduction and commentary; and the widest possible distribution of EDL booklets, once these have been produced and delivered. Reconvene working group approximately every two years, or otherwise as needed, in order to coordinate revision, re-publication and distribution of a revised EDL. (vi) Participate, together with the Chief Therapist, other officials in the Ministry of Health, professional medical workers, representatives from WHO and other international experts in coordinated efforts to develop and implement new medical treatment guidelines consistent with the Essential Drugs Program of the Kyrgyz Republic. (vii) Convene and chair an organizing committee each year to prepare an annual conference on Drug Regulation Issues in the Kyrgyz Republic. The organizing committee would include representative from the Ministry of health, the pharmaceutical industry, and professional medical workers. (viii) Provide quarterly progress reports on the pharmaceutical component to be included in the TCC quarterly progress report of Project activities. PRIMARY HEALTH CARE A. 1: Women's Reproductive Health: Consultants to Develop National Health and Sexually Transmitted Disease National Policy and Case Management Guidelines. Objective: Assist the MOH to develop a National Policy and Case management Guidelines based upon WHO's "Mother-Baby Packages", and for Sexually Transmitted Diseases. This would include the translation of WHO materials into Russian, review and revise the materials with a committee of national experts to develop national guidelines for four levels of health facilities: i) Specialist tertiary and Oblast hospitals; ii) central raion hospitals; iii) polyclinics, SVAa and APTKs; and iv) feldsher accoucheur posts. Duration: Two person months of services in year one (February, 1996), and one person month of services the next three years for a total of five person months. It is expected that the Government will contract directly with WHO for the provision of a team of experts with previous experience working on health problems in the former Soviet Union. The team should include specialists in obstetrics, neonatology and venerology. Outcome: National Guidelines A.2: ARI/CDD: Consultants to Develop National Health Policy in Acute Respiritory and infectious Diseases, and Communicable and Diahhreal Diseases: Objective: To train hospital specialists to develop "Model Training Units" in childhood acute respiratory diseases and diarrheal diseases, develop a "Mini-Family Doctor Training Course" and training trainers for SVA, FAP and polyclinic staff, and assist the MOH to establish a data base for case management protocols and rational drug prescribing. The consultants will work with local expert conmmittees, appointed by the MOH, in the review and local adaptation of WHO and other internationally recognized standard clinical guidelines related to the treatment of common childhood illnesses. The expert Committees will develop National Case Management Guidelines to be entered into a computer database in the MOH's Department of Treatment and Prevention and to serve as training materials for a series of workshops for clinical personnel at four levels of health facilities: i) Specialist tertiary and Oblast hospitals; ii) central raion hospitals; iii) polyclinics, SVAa and APTKs; and iv) feldsher accoucheur posts.. Duration: Two person months of services in year one (February, 1996), one person month of services the next year and one half person month the following two yeafs for a total of four person months. It is expected that the Government will contract directly with WHO for the provision of a teamn of experts with previous experience working on health problems in the former Soviet Union. The team should include specialists in pediatricians and infectionists. Outcome: National Guidelines and Training Course Materials

Duration: 7 day each Outcome: Trained national officers who will train lower level officers. Consultant for Laboratory Course (1, Twice at the beginning of year I and 3) Objective: To formally train national and oblast level microbiologists on adequate practices in smear microscopy. Duration: 15 days, year one - 7 days, year 2. Outcome: Fully trained national and oblast laboratory heads who will be capable to train lower level staff. External Consultant for Monitoring Process Objective: To assist WHO staff in monitoring progress of implementation of the National Tuberculosis Program and to review results achieved, identify and address problems encountered during programn implementation together with a local team from the National Tuberculosis Institute, and prepare a report on progress of the project for use by the MOH, WHO and the World Bank. Duration: I mission at month 6 after the start of the project, then 2 missions every year of 2 weeks each. Outcome: Established family practice groups and a Primary Care Physicians Association. B.  243 ANNEX 11 KYRGYZ REPUBLIC HEALTH SECTOR REFORM PROJECT ANNEX 11: IMPLEMENTATION ACTIONS, REPORTING AND MONITORING A. Implementation Actions and Progress Reports Required by the Government 1. Specific measures need to be taken during implementation of the project to support the project's objectives and the wider objectives of the Borrower, as set forth in its policy statement. To this end, the Borrower and the Association have agreed on a series of actions in connection with the monitoring of the implementation of the project (the action plan) within the framework a schedule of regular monitoring and reporting. 2. During the execution of the project, the Borrower, through the TCC, will furnish to the Association regular annual progress reports and action plans. These reports and plans should be supplemented by shorter, quarterly reports. The annual and quarterly reports and plans should cover: (a) project implementation progress; (b) the level of funding of the health sector; (c) fulfillment of conditions in the Development Credit Agreement; (d) procurement activities, expenditures and disbursements in a format as set forth in para. 4.26; (e) details on management and operations of the project, including performance of the PCU and the TCC, and of consultants hired under the project. 3. The part of the reports and plans dealing with the action plan set forth in paragraphs 4-8 below should review progress made to date in the period covered by the report, and actions to be taken in the following period. Reports should address both the actions to be taken by the Borrower, as listed below, and the Performance Monitoring Indicators. 4. By December 31, 1996, The Borrower, through its Ministry of Health, will: (a) Present to the Association for review and comments its MANAS Health Care Reform Program and a schedule of rationalization of health facilities and thereafter carry out the program in accordance with that schedule, taking into account the comments of the Association (para. 1.49); (b) Combine services in the health facilities selected as Oblast Model Polyclinics where training under the PHC component will be carried out, so that services for pediatrics, women's health and general adult health will be offered in one building (para. 3.19). (c) Ensure timely supply and regular replenishment to all facilities where training under the PHC component is carried out of project financed equipment, drugs and other materials, and ensure that part of these drugs are provided free of charge to personnel of FAPs and ambulatory centers participating in the training programs as trainees (para. 3.19); (d) Establish new national case management guidelines, treatment protocols and enabling legislation (para. 3.9, 3.13, 3.25, 3.28, 3.62); (e) Issue guidelines, acceptable to the Association, to health authorities at all levels on leasing of publicly owned health premises to family group practices (para. 3.64 (a)); (f) Carry out a study of the levels of patients' referrals from primary care physicians to specialists and for diagnostic tests in Bishkek City and Chui Oblasts. Not later than June
 244 ANNEX 11 30, 1997 it will submit this study to the Association for review and comments, and it will subsequently implement the agreed recommendations (para. 3.64 (b)); (g) Appoint a standing committee for the Essential Drugs Programn, consistent with authority provided by the "Law on Medicines" and as provided by the rules adopted on compiling and maintaining its EDL (para. 3.78). 5. By June 30, 1997 and thereafter at the end of each annual drug procurement cycle, the Borrower's MOH will review drug procurement and distribution so as to assure that privately owned drug wholesalers and retailers are not disadvantaged compared to remaining state-owned companies (para. 3.80). 6. By December 31, 1997, the Borrower, through its Ministry of Health, will: (a) Design and implement a national health accounts system to be able to track allocation of resources for health and the flow of funds in the health sector (para. 3.64 (c)); (b) Establish a data base of National Case Management Guidelines for women's reproductive health, STDs, ARI/CDD and TB, based on the WHO recommended guidelines, together with treatmnent protocols for all those conditions, indicating that drugs used should be from its Essential Drug List only, and thereafter update and distribute these protocols regularly to health workers nationwide (para. 3.23); (c) (i) establish and thereafter maintain a Health Fund into which national, oblast, municipal and raion level health authorities will contribute and out of which medical providers will be paid; (ii) issue guidelines on the manner and level of contribution by these health authorities and the characteristics and costs of the services to be purchased; and, (iii) pass legislation allowing establishment of primary health care provider groups as non- profit entities and opening of bank accounts by such groups (para. 3.64 (c)); 7. By January 31, 1998 and thereafter, the Borrower will allocate budget resources for procurement and reimbursement of pharmaceuticals solely to pharmaceuticals listed on its Essential Drug List and registered in the country (para. 3.77); 8. In each medical facility to be renovated under the project the Borrower, through its MOH, will establish a stakeholder group consisting of health authorities and local government officials, before renovation is undertaken (para. 3.36 and Annex 3). B. Performance Monitoring Indicators 9. In addition to the reporting requirements listed above the TCC will be required to monitor the performance indicators. These indicators are broken into three types for each component: input, output and impact. Input indicators are activities which are aimed to improve parameters which have a direct impact on the health status, not do not themselves directly affect the health status, such as training. Output indicators monitor the impact of input indicators and include parameters which are expected to influence the health status directly such as number of patients being treated with new protocols. Impact indicators monitor the degree to which project related changes in input and output parameters will result in improvement of the health status, such as the improvement in the maternal mortality rate. Following is a list of indicators identified for each component and targets that are to be achieved through the project.

 259 ANNEX 14 KYRGYZ REPUBLIC HEALTH SECTOR REFORM PROJECT ANNEX 14: OTHER DONOR ACTIVITIES AND COORDINATION 1. Summary of donor activities in the Kyrgz Republic: The major donor organizations working in the Kyrgyz Republic's health sector are USAID, UNICEF, WHO, and UNDP. USAID, UNICEF and UNDP all have small country offices in Bishkek. USAID has a regional office in Almaty and the UNICEF country office is supervised by the Area Office for Central Asian, located in Islaniabad, Pakistan. UNFPA plans to set up a regional office with a regional advisor. GTZ, the German government's technical assistance agency, and DANIDA, the Danish government's development agency also have small offices with a resident country program officer. Several other agencies are working on emergency food programs (Red Cross, Mercy Corps International, France Liberte, etc.). 2. Summary of organizations involved in health reform activities: WHO/EURO, UNDP and TICA, the Turkish development agency are supporting the MANAS Health Care Reform Project. This project is due to finish in September 1995. The MANAS project has developed a framework for health planning and strengthened the management capacity of selected MOH staff. USAID is funding health fuiance reform through the Abt Associates demonstration site in Issyk Kul. ODA have funded study tours for key central and oblast health administrators to look at health reform in the U.K. and Scandinavia. In early 1996, GTZ will appoint a long term health policy advisor to the President and MOH, with particular emphasis on health education , health insurance and drug regulation. 3. Summary of organizations involved in essential drugs programs: WHO are providing technical assistance for the development of a national essential drugs and rational prescribing program. ODA, the British development agency provided $400,000 to DAP/EURO/WHO for this program. GTZ plans to bring in short term advisors to work on establishing a drug's regulation and licensing body for the Kyrgyz Republic. UNDP is administering the purchase of $1.2 million of emergency drugs in 1995, with money donated by DANIDA. 4. Summary of organizations involved in children's health activities: (a) Expanded Program of Immunization: UNICEF is providing primary series vaccines and supplies using a Japanese government grant. UNICEF is also providing technical assistance and has advocated for reducing the list of contraindications observed. USAID has donated emergency vaccines and provided technical assistance and strengthening of cold chain through the "Basics Project". (b) Acute Respiratory Infections and Control of Diarrheal Diseases: UNICEF has donated emergency drugs for winter and summer programs and funded training of health workers at the central, oblast, and peripheral levels. Case management guidelines and health education materials have also been provided. (c) Breastfeeding: UNICEF and USAID (through the Wellstart project) have supported some training of health workers. UNICEF has worked closely with the MOH to rewrite "Decree #55" which outlines birth house operations. The rewritten decree promotes baby friendly practices and emphasizes breastfeeding. It is now in the approval process of the MOH and should be adopted by the end of 1995.
 260 ANNEX 14 (d) Iodine Deficiency Disease: UNICEF is assisting the government develop a national plan for iodized salt. Legislation has now been passed which requires that only iodized salt is imported into the Republic. The GOK has set the goal of making iodized salt available for human consumption throughout the Republic by the end of 1995. 5. A summary of agencies involved in women's reproductive health activities: USAID and UNFPA are the lead agencies working on these activities. USAID, working through a number of contractors (Futures Group, SOMARC, JHIEPGO, AVSC, PCS) is providing technical assistance to government policy makers and health workers and creating a market for contraceptives through social marketing. UNFPA is supplying contraceptives and has begun developing an STD/FP health education program for Bishkek. Under contract with UNFPA, Family Health International is developing a pilot project which trains midwives to insert IUDs. The WHO Regional AIDS Control Office in Almaty is funding an sexually transmitted diseases expert to conduct a regional workshop on STD management in Tashkent. Key health personnel from the Kyrgyz Republic will attend this workshop. 6. Food and Clothing Assistance: Several donor organizations are active in providing food assistance to the country. Primary donors include: France Liberte; the European Union; Red Barnett/Save the Children, Denmark; The International Federation of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies; UNICEF; Mercy Corps International; and German Agro Action. 7. Planned assistance for the Fall of 1995 includes: German Agro Action supplying 2,000 tons of wheat flour, 200 tons of sunflower oil for distribution to the poor, the elderly, the disabled, and orphans in Djalal-Abad and Osh Oblasts; France Liberte will supply: 4,200 tons of Flour, sugar, oil, salt for 150,000 persons (10,000 prisoners) in Talas, Naryn, Issyk-Kul, Chui Oblasts. Mercy Corps International will distribute 1,500 metric tons of Rice and 800 metric tons of vegetable oil to institutions throughout the Republic in coordination with the Ministries of Health, Education, and Social Protection and be distributed primarily to schools, and maternity houses. UNICEF will continue to supply high protein food in the form of BP-5 biscuits and will distribute through schools and peripheral level health facilities. 8. Planned assistance for clothing this fall will include UNICEF's distribution of $100,000 worth of winter coats and shoes for children 3 - 11 years old. France Liberte will also distribute clothing this fall and will also provide hygienic products and bed linens (140 tons) to 40,000 persons in 45 institutions and 75 hospitals in Osh and Djalal-Abad Oblasts. 9. Coordination of Other Donor Activities with the Proposed World Bank Reform Project: (a) The pharmaceutical management component of the World Bank project will work closely with DPA/WHO/EURO and GTZ on the implementation of an essential drugs program. Meetings between these various agencies are ongoing and the coordination is good. (b) The health finance component of the World Bank project will have to compliment the ongoing USAID funded activities through the Abt Associates demonstration project in Issyk Kul. (c) A member of Abt Associates acted as an observer on the March 1995 World Bank Mission, thereby facilitating close coordination between the USAID and World Bank activities. (d) The primary health care component of the World Bank project has been developed to compliment the activities of UNICEF, USAID and WHO. The ARI/CDD sub-component
 261 ANNEX 14 will provide technical assistance and the long term supply of essential drugs to support UNICEF's ARI and CDD programs. The Tuberculosis sub-component will support the ongoing technical assistance provided by WHO. The Women's Reproductive Health sub- component will compliment the family planning activities of USAID and UNFPA by focusing on obstetric care, perinatal care and the treatment of sexually transmitted diseases. doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Health Sector Reform Project are the following: 1) reform and improvement of the health care system in Kyrgyz Republic; 2) improvement of the health status of the population; 3) improvement of the clinical effectiveness of the service delivery system; 4) improvement of the economic efficiency of the delivery system; and 5) extension of access of appropriate care, enhancement of the quality of care, and assurance of the long-run financial viability of the system. The project consists of the following four major components: 1) primary health care including: (a) strengthening of women's reproductive health management; (b) acute respiratory infection and diarrheal disease control; and (c) tuberculosis control; 2) facilities rehabilitation; 3) medical care provider payment; and 4) pharmaceutical management, which will support the following: (a) national drug regulatory organization; (b) essential drugs program; (c) procurement of essential drugs; and (d) national drug policy.
